Early Access Review
								First off, the game has a lot of bugs. Also to build rollercoaster sit takes a lot of thought, (Which can be better at times) whereas in rollercoaster tycoon 3 you could get in and build a rollercoaster coaster like that. No messing around with safety and the free form tool is messed up. However I'm personally a big sucker to when it comes to FPS (Frames per second) and graphics quality. RTC world delivers this really well compared to RTC3. Terrain editing is much nicer as the tiles are gone from RTC3 and blending is better. Although rides and rollercoaster scant go underground and after you've finished a rollercoaster, you can't edit the terrain that sits underneath the track! That sucks! Also when zooming out, peeps become more static. By that I mean there is no movement in there arms, legs and body but instead the shuffle along the ground as if your FPS is down at 2! As well as there is a lack of themes. I know that RTC3 only had an extra 5 themes through the platinum edition but come on Atari, add more themes and as well as there is no filter to filter themes like on RTC3; there all in one big list!To conclude I wouldnt buy this game yet. It has a lack of customisation and needs to be developed. I do realise this is early access and not everything is added and flushed out, exactly why you shouldn't buy this game just yet. Once the game is out fully then give it a go but stick to RTC3 or planet coaster.John

number of helpful: 113 of 211 people (54%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Most of the negative reviews of this game are completely unwarranted. I've been a fan of this franchise since the very first game, and this has the potential to be the best one yet, even though it does need a lot of work. Most of the people who seem to hate it either seem to ignore the fact that it's an incomplete early release, or simply didn't have the patience to actually learn how to play it. Finally, I think it does measure up to it's main competitor, Planet Coaster.First, let me say that if you're expecting an easy-to-play, piece-by-piece builder like the previous two where everything always comes out perfectly square and symmetrical with complete ease, you're going to be disappointed. The node-based coaster builder can be tricky, and it takes some work to get parallel tracks or symmetrical scenery arrangements. However, most of the people complaining about this seem to have completely ignored the snap and grid options. Once you learn to use it, I actually find these elements superior to analogous elements in other simulators like Cities:Skylines. It does take a while to learn to and optimize the path building, scenary placement, and coaster-building features, and it's a bit more difficult to use, but the trade off in difficulty pays off with the high level of freedom you have. Now, something very negative about this game, it is EXTREMELY buggy in its current state. It crashes a lot, the frame rate is really low, a number of the features (such as the coaster's physics engine) are woefully incomplete, and the AI in guests and maintainence needs a lot of work, but it is important to remember this is an incomplete game. It's probably more buggy than most games that are called beta or early access, but that's more the fault of Atari's marketing than the game itself. If they work out these bugs, it has the potential to be a really good game.The best feature of the game by far is the coaster builder. Judging by other comments and You Tube videos, most of the people complaining about it seem to have absolutely no clue what they are doing and haven't even tried to learn how to use it. It is in my opinion the best coaster builder out there right now. It's less complex than No Limits, and gives you way more freedom than the builders in the first three or the current version of Planet Coaster. Granted, the physics engine is probably incomplete and what's right now there is probably a place holder (there's very little friction on coasters, the breaks are way to powerful) and there are some bugs with the coaster builder (frame rate slows way down, some features cause it to crash, and there are a number of bugs with the breaks). It's also somewhat difficult to learn how to use (though should come somewhat naturally to those familiar with No Limits), but again what you lose in easiness pays off in what you gain in freedom. Again, don't expect an easy piece-by-piece builder, but do expect to be able to build really realistic coasters. I love the mixture of node and piece-by-piece builders.Since I also have access to the early bird version of Planet Coaster, I think it's worth doing a point-by-point comparison between the two. Granted, both games are incomplete, so all of this is subject to change, but it's worth mentioning how I think the two stack up against each other.So far, here's what's better about RCTW:-Better Coaster Builder with way more freedom than you have in PC, but PC's builder isn't even in alpha yet so this can change.-Better path builder. PC's path builder is easily the worst part of the game, it's so wonky and very difficult to build decent looking paths.-UGC. As someone who spent hours looking for and working with CS in RCT3, this is a huge plus. The integration with Steam Workshop is great, and it allows to add elements of piece-by-piece building in RCTW that aren't there yet. Also, it expands the potential for customization in the game in the future way out there.-Better looking flat rides.-Better camera controls. Though PC has very similar controls to RCT3, RCTW's controls are more intuitive and don't clash with other controls in the game.Here's what's better about PC:-Better overall graphics. Even though some elements in RCTW are more detailed, the lighting, shadows, and such in PC are way superior.-Better sounds. Sounds like guests on coasters are having sex in RCTW, and coaster sounds in PC are more realistic. Also, it sounds a lot less cluttered.-Better Scenery builder. Piece-by-piece building allows for a lot more freedom in building buildings and the scenery in general looks better.-Better AI. Peeps act and move more naturally, and there are fewer bugs. It gets you to think about the layout of your park a lot more.-Way less buggy, and better optomized overall.Here's what's neutral/debatable between the two:-Stalls. The Stalls in RCTW are more realistic, and the feature of walk-in resteraunts is a huge plus. But, the stalls in PC are more customizable.-Coster stations. Like stalls, they're more realistic in RCTW, but more customizable in PC. Granted, RCTW's devs said they're planning on allowing for blank coaster stations for mor customizations in future updates.-RCTW has more features, game modes, and such as of now but that's just where it is in its development.Overall, I slightly prefer RCTW but that's mainly because the main reason I've ever played these games is for coaster building and, as it stands now, RCTW has more features overall, but PC just needs to catch up in development. Both have the potential to be great games.In conclusion, do not by this game if you're looking for a completely ready-to-play, fully optimized, and easy-to-play game. It still needs a lot of work, and is difficult to learn to master all the controls. Most of the reason why people seem to hate it is a mixture of bad marketing and unrealistic expectations of how complete it would be. For casual gamers new to the genre of theme park simulators, it's definitely not worth the price. But if you truly love simulation games, and have the patience to work through the bugs and actually learn how to play, and want to support the development of a potentially good game, it's definitely worth it.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								 Having played and enjoyed the RCT franchise for most of my life, I was overjoyed when I heard this game was in development. I never thought a Roller Coaster Tycoon game could be butchered so badly. Boy, was I proven wrong. This game feels like a bad port of a knock-off RCT game for a mobile platform. There's barely any content, the graphics are sub-par, the UI is clunky, the guests lag the game, and you can't even move the camera with the mouse. They said this game was 80-90% done upon release? And after numerous release delays, they have the audacity to try and hide it behind an Early Access tag at the last minute to attempt to cover up how flawed the game is. There is no excuse for this.This game does not deserve to be called a Roller Coaster Tycoon game.

								I fell in love with RollerCoaster Tycoon, I gave hours of my adolescent life to RollerCoaster Tycoon 2. I had to fight my wife for the PC when RollerCoaster Tycoon 3 came out because she got addicted too. I love this franchise! However, after playing RCTW for less than an hour, I have requested a refund. I might purchase it again when it leaves early access and is a proven, solid game. Until then, I am sorely disappointed. content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Game has been released. Review updated as of 18/11/2016.Please scroll to bottom to read.THIS REVIEW WILL BE UPDATED AS THE GAME DEVELOPS.*****************************************************************I suppose to start with I will honestly say I am LOVING this game. So many people forget or don't realise that Nvizzio have only been working on this for about 18 months or so, proir to this 2 others had tried and failed, so there was and still is a LOT of work to be done before the masses get a finished product. This isn't something that will happen quickly either.At the moment it needs a speccy PC to run too, as it uses rather a lot of memory at the moment. Some users report upto 8Gb of RAM being used by just this game alone. Yes there are a lot of features this game doesn't have yet but these things will come, in time. And Devs are listening to the community feedback and more importantly, doing something about the problems being reported. They are doing Bi-weekly updates on the game, with a live stream to showcase the update content just a few days prior to each one. They too, like us want this game to be the awesome game we all know it can be. I am hopefull they can pull this off and will stick with it all the way through development. So, to recap.In my honest opinion its a good game. Yes it has quirks at the moment and there's a few glitch's here and there and the massive memory usage. But I am enjoying it and creating some wonderfull parks with some awesome coasters.Game updated on 07/06 - Review updateWOW. The new update has made significant imrovement to the game. It still uses a fair bit of memory, but with the new skybox and a few other tweaks performance is getting better, slowly. It still has more work to be done, but the game is now running a bit smoother. Peeps are working better and overall the quality of graphics is now better too.Game Update - 30/08 - Review updatePiece by Piece Building has now come to RCTW and is amazing to use.With the previous 2 updates breaking the game for most, I was hopeful to try the new update to see what, if anything has improved.Unfortunately there is still ZERO improvement in performance. It has now got even worse. Game lags like crazy and glitch's here there and freakin' everywhere. And although you may see me playing RCTW now and again, beleive me when I say I DO NOT AND WOULD NOT RECOMMEND RollerCoaster Tycoon World to anyone in its current state.Review Update - 18/11/2016So RCTW has now been released.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. STAY WELL AWAY.Yet AGAIN all they have done is add more content and brought more bugs and lag to the game. These people DO NOT CARE about the commuintiy. RCTW has loads of missing features and is NOWHERE near ready to be released

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												I felt duped when I preordered RCTW and it suddenly went into "Early Access" when it was supposed to be in full release form. At that time the game felt like it was alpha at best. I held on to hope that Atari valued their audience and were going to make the best of things by delivering a finished product by full release. I defended RCTW and told others to just give them time and they might be able to turn things around. Duped again apparently. *I think* they were pushed to some arbitrary holiday deadline, or afraid of Frontier's game, either way it has released in a very sub-par state. I tried to like RCTW but it's just not good enough. No matter how good this last group of devs are and even though they tried to listen to us they were given a task that was insurmountable. All in all I would stay away from this game, it had potential but they sadly bungled it. The best thing I got from my pre-order was the lesson to never pre-order another game. *PROS*-The Coaster Creator. You can build pretty good looking rides once you learn a bit about how it works.-When they work right the flat rides are not so bad.*CONS*(The Short List)-The path system. It has never worked right. They fixed it up as best they could but that's like putting lipstick on a pig.-The AI. Nothing like watching guests form a vortex at the paths between the food stalls and the bathrooms, never to ride another ride again. Or sit down. Or anything but eat and defecate.-Still feels like a beta state game. Memory leaks still reported. Game breaking glitches still present from early access.*TL/DR* Not worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								RCT WORLD is an unstable game that crashes constantly, even on high end computer systems.  The game likes to crash when using the bulldozer and has crashed while trying to save causing hours of coaster building to go down the drain.  I recommned that while you build or design coasters that you save the same coaster build twice under two different names.The look of the game is gorgeous, with realistic peeps, lighting, and textures. The coaster building freeform is interesting however requires some tweeking.  I recommend having more preconstructed options available like loops and helixes as these are difficult to make with the system...(at least smooth concentric loops and helixes.)  The curved paths are a bear to acclimate to.  I should be able to click on a start then an end position of the path and then adjust the curve as desired. Im sure that updates, fixes, and additional content will be forthcoming and constant.  Water, travel, and more thrill rides have been promised.  Tunnels will be nice too.  I have not yet attempted to create my own scenery, however, if I can play the game for 15 min without it locking up, seizing for half an hour, or out right crashing, I may attempt to import some buildings created in lightwave.  As it stands constant crashing is my bigest grip to an otherwise interesting game..the crashing makes the game unplayable in my opinion, at least at this point,  and requires some serious patching to improve stability, especially if they are charging $60 for the game.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I just downloaded this game and played for maybe 30 minutes. I read all of the reviews, and I still decided I wanted the game because I love all of the old ones. I figured it would at least be as good as the last one that came out years ago. I'm going to try it out a little longer and I'm hoping I'll like it more. Overall though, it's super laggy. I don't have a fancy PC, but it's decent and it was constantly lagging at least a little. I also really dislike the pathway builder. It doesn't really sound that important, but you have to build paths constantly on this game. It's difficult to even make the path go straight at times. Another thing that I didn't see anyone else mentioned, but it bothered me, was that on the old ones you simply hired employees as you needed them. On this one you have to build buildings for all the different kinds of services. I don't like that because it takes up room of my park for no reason. I haven't even built a coaster yet!! Not sure if I should try to get  refund yet, but let's just say I'd rather be playing the one that came out 17 years ago.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game should not be released, not even in "early access / beta", why ? - Path building is horrible, you have to demolish entrances because you cannot connect new roads, no upgrade or change of path looks / building stones without removing them.- Path building can be blocked by a small flower that is on the ground, which you can't even see from some zoom levels, you only get a "red path" signal. - The only way to build decent looking park is by using both snap & grid function views to connect attractions or even queues to your paths. - Terraforming the same as with path building, you do not get an error you can only see that some hills cannot be flattened. then you zoom in and you see a small bush blocking your (IRL) bulldozer?? - No water attractions, and except for rollercoaster the list junior & familiy ride is quite small.Again a game which you should not preorder, I hope this helps.Regards,Torzino

								Every review I see on here is bashing on the graphics. Honestly I'm not here to look at a pretty game I'm here to make a park and have fun. So graphics aside. This is my review.I've only played a bit and I'm not impressed!Camera: The camera in the game is awful. You use the WASD keys to move. Why can't I click and hold left and drag? When you zoom in it gets blurry and looks awful. Pathing: Don't even bother trying to put a que line or anything down. It's annoying. It doesn't work. Just don't. Also why can't I right click to delete stuff? Speaking of...Teraforming: OMG KILL ME. What do you mean I can't move the land up? OH because of that little stupid rose bush?! Well just move it up with it or just delete it. Instead you have to go to the delete tool, delete the tree/bush, go back to terrain, then and only then can you move it.Que Lines: Why do I have to BUY the ride sign? Why isn't it just on the end like it is on EVERY RCT?Overall: So sad. Wanted to like it, wanted to think everyone was wrong about it. But no. This game (I know it's early) Has a lot of issues. It feels like  the people behind this game have never even played a roller coaster tycoon. Off to check out Planet Coaster.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								If a player keeps from viewing others' views and opinions and allows an open mind before entering this world, then I think they can find themselves having an adequate time playing for a few hours. This goes especially to those players intending to do super-basic stuff like building basic rides, planting basic scenery, do minimal to no landscaping, etc.But when a game has so many glitches, so much lag, and so many errors and incomplete aspects within it, you have to sit and wonder who's bright idea it was to release this horrifically broken piece of software at the price of a full-fledged, fully-built, fully-complete-and-ready-to-sell-to-the-masses video game. I understand the game is listed as "Early Alpha," so this should be expected, but coming from a video game that was originally intended to be released summer of last year, I was at least hoping for it to be polished enough for more serious gameplay.I found the game okay to play at first and that the reviews many YouTube gamers were giving it to be just a tad bit exaggerated. But do heed their words, and do heed the words of the "Mostly Negative" reviews found on the Steam Page. In the end, it's really not worth it.I intend to keep my copy to play at another date and hope that they will improve it over time, but it will likely gather dust now and then until I feel ready to suffer through the tremendous lag and superabundant number of peeps puking for my generic janitors to clean. Your $50 could be better spent elsewhere. I promise, I promise...

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is terrible. It still is nowhere near release. You can't edit hardly anything on the pre-built rides, coasters, and structures. The peep graphics are choppy at any eye height beyond right over top of them. The coaster building interface is junk - it lets you build ridiculous track segments while defying logic and sense. The graphics are poor - RCT3 was better. The on ride cameras are choppy when turning or changing slope - very poor. You can't see the ride increase or decrease speed either, it always looks like it's going the same speed. The building system overall is bad, clunky, impossible to place things where you want them. The game is so far from ready, and there doesn't seem to be any promising sign that it's going to get any better. This is all coming from a very disappointed, huge RCT fan from day 1. Bummer.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game does not deserve to have the RollerCoaster Tycoon name attached to it. It is awful in every element of the "game". Sure this is Early Access but that is NO excuse for this horrible "game". This has been a failing project for years. The current screenshots all look good but then you get in the "game" (which is just over 1gb) and put all the settings on high, you still get something that looks worse than RCT 3 does and that game is 10 years old! Artai has been money hungry for years turning well known IP's into new, totally garbage games and RCTW is no different. A few things wrong with it:-Sound design (want to hear some adults only bedroom noises? Zoom into the coaster stations)-UI (everything is just wrong. Not user friendly, way to big, hard to navigate, etc)-Peeps are a joke. You will find quite a few that look the same. They don't walk right. Loading into rides is awful-Gameplay is just horrid. I had to force myself to play for an hour trying to find something good about it and there is nothing. -Graphics are awful-Just no fun at allAs soon as the negative feedback started rolling in on the forums, threads were getting deleted. You mention Planet Coaster on the forums (even when trying to compare the games to give Atari ideas), you get the whole thread deleted. Atari has become a massive joke and I will never buy another game from them again. It's a real shame that they have the rights to Roller Coaster Tycoon because I would love to see what a real game development company could do with this beloved series. Unforutnally I think it is to late and the RCT name has been tarnished by this total hunk of garbage they call a "game".

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a long time fan of the RollerCoaster Tycoon series, it really sucks that I have to give this review. I've been patient, given Atari plenty of leniency after reading all of their blog posts, and I actually bought the game expecting to get something that's at least enjoyable to play. (Luckily I got it for $30AU elsewhere)Sadly, that is not the case. After months of broken promises of the full release of the game, we get this steaming hot mess in Early Access instead. And it's not fun.The peeps look horrendous and the animations are all awkward, and there are quite a few instances where staff will appear to glide across the map. When you scroll out completely the peeps look like pixels moving jaggedly.The coaster builder, while innovative, is really not that pleasant to work with. While I enjoy being offered more flexibility in building a roller coaster, I still have a very hard time getting the pieces to work just how I want them to, and it doesn't integrate well with the piece-by-piece builder - which, by the way, doesn't have the option to place pre-built banked curves. Moreover, there's no way to change the speed of a whole section of chain lift at the same time - Why isn't this feature present here when it was present in all previous RCT games.The stalls are oversized, the transition from individual staff to staff-rooms is terrible, the path system, while innovate, also lacks from terrible implementation and lack of piece-by-piece building, the rides look tacky, blah blah blah...I could go on for ages, but to sum it up, it's...not fun to play at all. I'm not vibing it like I did with the first 3 installments, and I honestly would have faith in this game, but considering the amount of times Atari's been blowing smoke up our♥♥♥♥♥ I can't give credit to anything they say anymore. AAA game my♥♥♥♥♥ Mattlab.I could only justify buying the game if it was $10, but that's stretching it. Don't waste your time on this game right now. If you have a real itch to immerse yourself in a beautiful theme park sim, fork out the extra money for Planet Coaster.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really really wanted to like this game, and now after playing the PlanetCoaster alpha early release I may be a bit clouded but this game lacks improvement, and growth after such a long time of un-comparable theme park sim/roller coaster park simulations. You know you have problems when a really early PlanetCoaster build is far more polished and feature rich than RollerCoaster Tycoon Worlds beta early build.All of the comments and opinions I have are with me knowing that yes it is an early access/release. Although I know this, it really isn't an excuse considering we have passed the original full game release date, and second full game release date.RollerCoaster Tycoon World severely lacks customization, and depth. Everything about it seems dull, and dumb (not like this game is dumb, but nothing in it seems smart, guests, employees, rides, etc). Everything just seems like its moving a long a set path with no real logic or process to give it a unique feel. Guests still hover around as if they are on an inviseable hovercraft, they are generic, and not very creative. There is no joy in the guests eyes, just walking "sticks".The rides look quite a bit better than the previous incarnation of RCT, but still lack a bit of a real feel, and detail. It is almost like they took what made the rides tick in RCT3, and threw a new graphic on them. IN theme parks/amusement parks some rides in a park will be the same ole spin and go up and down, but other rides do not necessarily have a pattern to them. I may be splitting hairs here, but after so many years what did you bring us that was new and imaginative? Not much.Objects, paths and scenary are a pain in the butt to use. Paths are finicky on where they can connect to each other, and you will find sceneary won't attach in that one special spot you saved open just for that particular piece of scenary. Unless you are a master of the poorly implemented way to use the paths tool, or plop sceneary expect to be spending a lot of time deleting things, replacing paths, and starting over on parts of the park if you are a detail oriented person. I could go on for awhile, but I will just say this.The game lacks depth, and ties you up in regards to creativity, and customization. If you are happy with just throwing down rides, making money on peeps, and cleaning up garbage, then you may not think this is to bad of a game, but to be honest there are better games that are 12+ years older than this one that will give you that experience. I don't feel like I wasted my money as I still hope the devs put it into high gear and turn this franchise around, but it is really looking bleak at this point. They have a whole heck of a lot of work ahead and them if they want this franchise to survive. I have a feeling though they pretty much just killed it. The new champions of the theme park tycoon series I have a feeling isn't going to be Atari.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								We can take for granted that an early access game will be rough round the edges, and we must be prepared for plenty of quirks and bugs. However one has to wonder just how far into the development this game is, when core functionality is so fundamentally broken. Take as an example, when you begin a campaign, besides a extreme stutter, which I will get into shortly, after picking one of just three areas to start in, you will often find yourself with only one build option; rides. Granted, the intention is of course that different creation options will unlock for you as you progress in the game, however on numerous occasions, besides the rides category, the other options would unlock much later than necessary (that is assuming they ever unlock). Like in the previous Rollercoaster Tycoon games, you need to place rides and shops far enough from the paths to provide space for a substantial length of an entrance queue. After placing a number of rides, you may notice that you have no means of drawing a path to them. What this leads to is hundreds of visitors entering the park after paying the £5 entrance fee, merely to walk back and forth on the small stretch of preset pathway at the entrace, getting increasingly tired and frustrated, and feeling understandably ripped off. To make things worse, if you have opened those rides in the vain hope that these visitors will get off the beaten path and make the trek across the grass to ride the helter skelter (heads up: they won't), soon enough the rides will inevitably break down simply from normal test usage. Nevermind, you can get mechanics on the job because it looks like the Buildings category finally opened up! Oh wait, you can't build a pathway. Right, that's really brought things to a halt.The interface adds insult to injury when notifications pop up, giving you a series of requests like "hey, it's kinda dark, can you please add some lamps?" or "hey your customers can't get to this ride, can you build a pathway to it?", and "hey, your ride has broken down, can you get your mechanics on it?" - And my response to them all is "I WOULD IF YOU LET ME!".In spite of this locked interface bug occurring a couple of times for me, I was lucky enough to start a campaign where the interface did function normally, and all the features unlocked for me within a reasonable time, more or less consistently. Besides the slightly cumbersome building/ride rotation mechanic (an 8 way snapping rotation would be preferable), and the fact that the auto rotation assignment (based upon the path you are placing the building next to) works less than half the time, the game actually feels surprisingly functional in spite of those finnicky issues. As for the coaster creation, it is fantastic! I had a blast designing an intricate coaster with ease. However it can be a little tedious to keep testing the ride every time you make a change to ensure that it works. It would be preferable if there were a feature that allowed you to simply test the last segment that you added, rather than the whole ride from the begining. Indeed, it does not seem to be far-fetched to assume a finished product could be comparable to Cities: Skylines in terms of quality and design. There will undoubtedly need to be a lot more in the way of content, as there is not even close to the amount of building and ride option or design variation compared with the previous Rollercoaster Tycoon games- but of course a lack of content is to be expected in early access. Perhaps one thing which really leaves a gaping hole, is the lack of in-depth creation. For example, the paths are laid with a line-drawing tool rather than a grid system which prevents creating little patio areas or plazas by hand, forcing you to use the preset ones. I am not sufficiently convinced that this will be changed in future patches or indeed upon the final game's release, because the Tycoon game industry seems to be moving towards this more "accessible" route, at the cost of player's creativity. I noticed this with Thrillville and Zoo Tycoon and other games of this style, but I would love Rollercoaster Tycoon World to prove me wrong and break away from this trend. I mentioned before that the game was stuttering. Although my PC's hardware is decidedly outdated for this 'generation', the parts exceeded the minimum and recommended specs for the game. For perspective, I can run Cities Skylines on Very High settings with smooth and responsive performance, even when my city spans across 5 regions and is filled with tens of thousands of people. I can also run Grand Theft Auto V at very high settings at around 50FPS. So, I cannot say I was not disappointed that the performance for Rollercoaster Tycoon World is abysmal. The game is not bad looking (though I'd argue not nearly as attractive or impressive as Cities Skylines), it is perhaps the best looking theme park tycoon game, and to be honest, it is a more up-close and personal style of tycoon game, with far more attention to detail than others in the same vein, with a naturally more dynamic environment. When you zoom into your park, you can get a lot closer than many tycoon games usually allow, and you can witness how the branches of palm trees sway in the wind,  a person behind the desk at a ride's entrace with the ride's buttons and controls, and see the little gate swing open for the customers, see kids running with excitement holding the balloons or other souvenirs they bought, etc. I expect that the finished product will look beautiful with just a hint of polish here and there, and perhaps a bit more detail in buildings and shops (most of the shops are identicle besides the large mascot/statue on the top). I would, for example, to see t shirts actually displayed in the window of the t shirt shops, and fridges with drinks actually displayed in the drink stalls, and burgers being made in the burger stalls. I recall the game The Movies by Lionhead allowed you to zoom into a burger stall and see a man actually cooking the individual burgers.... that was over a decade ago, so I am sure that in the $CURRENT_YEAR, it shouldn't be too much to request that the team behind RCTW are able to put at least a similar amount of effort into detail that Lionhead was able to achieve 11 years ago. But sadly, even if they did, that would only make the performance issues worse. It is already extremely uncomfortable for people who even meet the recommended system requirements, and even more-so when you choose to speed-up time. Freezes, unresponsive UI and generally horrendous stutter are present even on lower graphics settings. In conclusion, there is a lot that needs to be fixed and improved. I would certainly recommend fanatics of the franchise to get the early access game if they have ridiculously strong hardware, as when the game GUI is not misbehaving, the game shows a lot of promise and it is certainly quite enjoyable. I apologise if most of the review is criticizing rather than praising, but I felt that the negative did outweigh the positive for the most part. So, unless you fall into the category of "fanatic with future-proofed hardware", avoid the game for now but keep your eye on it, as I expect great things to come. If by the game release, there is a solution to whatever is undermining performance, the content is greatly expanded upon, the visuals are a little more refined, there is more free-rein and features that enable creativity and of course providing the remaining bugs are ironed out, I have no doubt that this game could be absolutely amazing. Especially with Steam Workshop support. Don't let us down, people, you know what you need to do!

If you want a good Theme Park simulator, or even just want to be able to build cool, interesting (not to mention large) coasters, RCTW is not for you. 								In it's current state, I simply cannot recommend this. number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been a die hard RCT fan my whole life. I still play RCT3 all the time, 12 years after its release. I have been following RCTW since it was first roumered, and I was extremely excited for it. I had waited over a decade for a new RCT installment, so you can imagine my anticipation for this game. I am sad to say that this game is not good. I was okay with it being released in early access rather than a finished game, but it isn't even close to ready. I was expecting all of the features of RCT3, plus a plethera of new features, rides, scenery, interface, and better graphics. This game has none of that. It is basically a stripped down version of RCT3. There are hardly any rides, there are less themes than there were in previous games, the graphics are bad, and it is poorly optimized (it freezed and lags on my PC that can play virtually any game on ultra settings). On top of all that, the path system and the terrain system are totally broken. They claim to fix it them in every update, but it still doesnt work. The best part about the RCT series was that you were able to imagine a dream park, and then build that exact park. RCTW doesn't let you do that, and most final products come out uglier and more awkward looking than you imagined. As of right now, I cannot recommend this game. I don't know what Atari was thinking charging $50 for a game that is years away from being complete. If I were you, I would pre-order Planet Coaster. It looks like they will be releasing a complete game with all the features we want.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a huge RCT fan, this is a tough one. On one hand this game is (head scratchingly) in early access. On the other hand, they've had multiple games in the series to pull from in terms of content and roadmapping as well as several delays before the official release date. As an early access game, it's not bad. It's completely playable with the money and simulation basics in there to actually run a park.However, as an RCT game it is a major letdown. We were promised an evolution in the series and what's here is simply the framework for the next step. Is that a bad thing? Not exactly, if something isn't broke then don't fix it. But it's nowhere near what Planet Coaster is doing. Right now you have 3 themes and over half of the scenery/props are locked. I'm not sure if they are locked behind some sort of in-game system or locked out because they aren't finished yet... the game doesn't say. My park ran smoothly enough for me but after I had built 3 coasters and 8 flat rides, I had 1,300 peeps in my park. At one point my menu disappeared so I had to exit out and reload from the main menu. After it sluggishly reloaded, the framerate was in the single digits. Making it unplayable in my eyes.As for the coaster builder, I didn't care for it much at first. I made a clunky and ugly first coaster. The second was a bit better and the third was almost exactly what I wanted. It's not a bad system and I actually think it works great once you learn how to use it. You can attach set pieces, just like in the older RCT games, or you can go off the grid and make whatever you want! You just have to play with it. So, the coaster builder is on the short list of positives for this game.The biggest problems I see right now is the amount of content, lack of in depth management tools (staff management, etc.), ugly peeps, and poor optimization. Luckily these are things that can be addressed and fixed. The menus aren't particularly eye pleasing but that's not a big deal.Also, the mission objectives that are given to you in game are so HUGE they sometimes occupy 75% of the screen so you can't look at the tasks while playing with your park. You have to look at them, close it out, try to finish the task, then open it back up to see the next one. It's mind bogglingly annoying!The truth is that there is a lot of potential here but right now it's not worth the asking price. Wait for a sale or the full version to see if they can polish this up a bit.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								At first glance (30 mins in) I am a bit disapointed. Remembering though that it is EARLY ACCESS - but also remembering that they were going to release the game about now as 'finished'.Definitly not a finished game. Graphic issues everywhere. Glitchy and lots of clipping around the place. Peeps tend to hover and not walk about. Staff members do the same. Paths clip. The on-coaster Cam needs a fair bit of work - there is no detail in the coaster, but the scenery is good looking a far.The ambience is a bit quiet or sterile so far. It seems pretty dull for a theme park, even with a few hundred people in. You dont hear the hum of people, just the random moans and screams of some ladies - which sounds like pornography tbh. And lots of money cha-ching noises from your rides. I was expecting a bit more immersion and realism.At this stage I'm on the fence. Im not excited but it has some potential. I am considering a refund and trying Planet Coaster Alpha instead - it looks more polished. I would give it probably a 5.5 to a 6/10 in its current state, but I will give it more of a go over the next few days and update. My advice though... is to wait. The Atari team could turn this around and make it into something great.*UPDATE* I gave this game a really good go and played for a few hours and have decided on requesting a refund. Already I feel I have played enough and done everything. It doesnt feel like an RCT game - theres no atmosphere. The coaster builder and camera is also horrible and VERY hard to use. 3hrs into the game and I dont feel like playing anymore - now you all know thats not right - not to mention my fingers are sore from clicking (the bulldose system sucks too).I may consider re-purchasing down the track if there are some significant improvements, but until then, the Planet Coaster Alpha actually looks a lot better than this is in its current state, so Id suggest at least taking a peek at that. The best way to describe it is: RCTW = SimCity 5 (a major let down). Im hoping Planet Coaster = City Skylines.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												So I played the game over the weekend pretty much none stop and I can say I was super excited about this game. The graphics are pretty awesome.I like some of the news things they have put into this game but it still is nothing like the original. Which to me this is a good and bad thing. It is great that we have so much more customization to this game. Circle paths, large, small, medium paths, lights, trash cans, benches, etc.I enjoy the fact that you can make a roller coaster now almost as you wish and it is not constrained as it was in the old Roller Coaster Tycoon. But with that being said, the magic of the old games is not completely present here.I want to build a roller-caster, test, add my scenery, my queue and be off. I don't want to spend almost 2 hours on building a coaster and than not be able to finish it because my train car is always hitting a bar that was placed in the wrong area by the game. I don't want to spend close to an hour and a half just to complete laying out my track. I want to put able to select the section of the track and place it how I like. There are alot of advantages to this new UI and I do recognize them but I am not a roller coaster designer. I am a average player that wants to build a roller coaster in the game as quickly and have it enjoyable. At the point, it is not that enjoyable to build a roller coaster because it is super frustrating.Here is an example on why it is so frustrating, If I am building my roller coaster and I am zoomed out to see what it looks like. If I click on a portion of the map where i would like for my track to be laid, that game from now where lays a very large piece of track randomly that the end of the new piece of track is laid down all the way to the edge of the park. WHAT?!!!!! That is not what I wanted. Now I have to zoom back in to make the track smaller, than angle the camera just right, and than either shift and any of the 4 number to adjust the track as I want. That is just ridiculous.If you are going to show a grid, as I like building on a grid, don't give me just a small piece of grid. Just display it on the whole map.For sure there is a learning curve for this game. But so far my initial review of this game is not all the stellar when building coaster. This is something that is NOT going to change for this is pretty much the hole core of the game.I am still at a maybe..... I wouldn't recommend this game but at the same time if you are a die hard fan as I am, I wouldn't turn you away either.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWSo here is the thing, I love this series, all the way from RCT to RCT3 and the process that this game took to get here caused me to cancel my pre-order, buy Planet Coaster and play it on release date. However after the launch I got curious and re-purchased the game and here is what I think....NVIZZIO HAVE A LOT OF WORK TO DO!!!!Pro's:Well it feels like it tries to be RCTArea themes are goodand well in my opinion that's about it for pro'sCons:*UPDATED 16/9/2016*THE COASTER BUILDER IS A LOAD OF BULL - How did you screw this up??? Press 1 and scroll mouse wheel to raise and lower, press 2 and scroll mouse wheel to tilt, press 3 and scroll mouse wheel to pitch and pressing 4 and you guessed it scroll that mouse wheel and it does something else. This is the WORST coaster builder I have used, its just so clunky and time consuming compared to, dare I say it, Planet Coaster's which they hid in Beta due to they thought it wasn't great but let me tell you it is the quickest precise builder I have used. It systems don't fully work, I struggled to get two trains running on one track, it kept failing with no information on how to fix it, the coaster preview while building is clunky, you click to build and then the preview of the next piece dissapears, it only reappears once you click and then click to build again. It's just pretty much, in my opinion, the worst coaster builder I have ever used.THE RIDES - Okay I get it realism is in but they just don't feel real and oh no the signs, the terrible ride signs. Yes you can rename and it shows up on the sign but there is just no character to them. It feels robotic and no this wasn't a sci fi theme.THE GRAPHICS - Just no, this is not 2016 worthy level of graphics, I can see that maybe you were trying to capture the feel of RCT3, or it's just an "optimization" thing but seriously that's why the game was delayed and it STILL SUCKS.********************************NEW**************************************************** THE LOAD TIME - Oh I could make a cup of tea and drop it onto my expensive PC by the time finally kicks itself into gear and you know the fun part?? Becaus of how great Unity is, if your graphics settings are incorrect or you want to tweak, you have to EXIT YOUR PARK, do the tweaks and then you guesssed it, WAIT FOR THE THING TO FREAKIN LOAD AGAIN!!!PATCH CONTENT - I'm getting increasingly worried now, it's been a few months out now in the world of play testing and I'm really not seeing improvements. Yes more rides and buildings have been added, do they look nice and attractive? No, graphic style has not had an update, it still looks like poop and zoom out and all your peeps become pixels that jutter to their destination. They released grid building and customisable buildings, but Planet Coaster had that from day one! Too late on that part, whether it was always part of the plan or added so that the game could keep the players it still has, whatever the reason it was too late and, in my opinion, badly done.Just general things don't seem to be improving, comparing it to Parkitecht and Planet Coaster whose updates have been consistent and fix bugs but add new exciting features and improve graphical quality all the time. They seem to be striving for the best while RCTW seems to be hanging on to the lifesaver surrounded by sharks.Below is my original closer and it still stands apart from my belief now that this game will never be at that high standard, in fact my belief is that the developers have given up. They are making this to an acceptable level where they can retain maybe a few people but enough so that Atari aren't on their backs and then dumped, never to be updated again for the trouble it has caused. Somewhere inside me, for the sake of the name of RCT, I hope I'm wrong.**********************************************************************************************This game could have been great, COULD HAVE BEEN, but competition in the market from Planet Coaster and even Parkitecht did not do this game well. I mean Planet Coaster literally beats it on every level, yes it has flaws but that's what development time is for, RCTW HAS HAD 3 F***ING YEARS TO GET THIS RIGHT AND 3 DEVELOPERS. Seriously get this game to the high standard it now has to live up to or congrats to Nvizzio for killing off one of the most beloved franchises of Theme Park building.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Edit: The RCTW developers have actually been very proactive in communicating with the community and fixing what needs to be fixed. Since this review was written, there have been several bug fixes and graphical improvements made to the game. While the game still has it's slew of bugs and some needed changes to gameplay (the path system still sucks but they're working on a redesign), it is better than when it first launched. While I still can't recommend this game in it's current state, I have no doubt that if Nvissio continues to act on the feedback of the players, this will actually turn into a worthy successor in the RCT franchise.Graphics: 6/10 Better looking than its twelve year old predecessor, but still dated for 2016 Gameplay: 4/10While the coaster builder is fun, bugs and minor annoyances detract from its overall enjoyment and poor optimization means even the most powerful computer might only scratch 15 fps.Series Innovation: 5/10While a lot was added to this entry (fully customizable coaster builder, restaurants, curved and larger size paths) a lot was also taken away. The amount of rides and coaster styles you can build is less than what it was in its predecessors, and you can’t build rides that go underground or roller coasters that don’t connect to the end (e.g shuttle loops).Overall: 5/10Rollercoaster Tycoon World (RCTW) has the potential to be a worthy addition to the famed Rollercoaster Tycoon (RCT) series, but in it's current state it's bogged down by bugs, missing features, and a stack of minor annoyances which shouldn't exist in a game after two years of development.I absolutely loved the first three RCT games and in 2014 when RCTW was first announced I was excited to see what the newest game could bring after ten years of new and improved gaming technology. Then the original developer was replaced, and the replacement developer was also replaced and the release date for RCTW kept getting pushed back from its initial “early 2015” date. Finally, at the end of Q1 in 2016, Nvissio and Atari released their Early Access Beta, a year after originally planned, and still not the final release. After playing RCTW for a couple of hours, I must say that I am somewhat disappointed in the progress that has been made after two years. While the graphics are improved from it’s predecessor, RCT3, the game does look dated for 2016 and what game engines and computers are capable of (at a 1GB download I was kind of expecting that). Polygon reduction when zooming out is very noticeable, and trees go from leafy to a three shaded blob without any middleground. Additionally, the park visitors just look kind of… weird. They have a tendency to run almost wildly flailing their arms which just looks funny and the look only marginally better than their now twelve year senior counterparts. Rides on the other hand do look much better than back in 2004, but look more like they would be in a game released four or five years ago, not now.The game is hampered by a number of bugs, with many people reporting that the game won’t load past 57% ( I have not had this issue myself). Additionally, there are issues with the game freezing and crashing at random times during gameplay, and on the “Frolicking Forest” map, the terrain editor only removes the polygons of the terrain and you still can’t place paths or rides unless they are above the previous terrain height.Gameplay wise, it’s actually kind of fun but there are a lot of annoyances that really cut away at it after only a few minutes. The coaster builder is pretty fun, but it’s also pretty hard to just get a straight line out of it. It would also benefit from having a stand alone coaster builder built into the game instead of only having the option to load a map and build it during a game. Additionally, for a “beta” there is a wide variety of shops and stalls, but it is very limited ride wise, with only a handful of roller coaster styles and a few different “flat rides” with varying scenery to choose from which seems interesting considering it’s a game built around building rides at its core. Additionally, the roller coasters have to connect, no more building shuttle loops for an easy payday. The main annoyance that’s been plaguing me is that there is no area demolish. Every bush, shrub, and tree that is there when the map loads needs to be individually clicked on to destroy, with is rather tedious. I do like that there are now larger paths that can be built, but there are times when the game won’t let me make a straight path, especially when making a short path that connects to another path. Another annoyance is that you have to build shops and stalls offset from the main path, and have to build a path to connect it to the main path which adds in an extra step and is also tedious, especially when your path doesn’t want to just go straight.Playing RCTW, you can see hints of the potential that this entry has, and with some polish and more development work, I do think that this can be a good game. However, with the way Atari has been treating this game over the past two years, I don’t really believe any major amount of progress will be made, and the game will forever be one of those “What could have been” examples.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game still has a lot of problems. At this moment it's really an early access. There are really some good things about the game, the way you can design you're own rollercoasters looks good and is fun to play with. The paths are a lot better than in RTC3, you kan now make corners and lay them down as you like them, make them bigger or smaller.It works and looks OK, but it does not make me really excited about the game yet.The controls are really bad. Most is done through the keyboard, it works but the right combination of mouse and keyboard makes it really easy to control.The mouse controls you have like zooming in with the scroll wheal is way to sensitive. When giving it a single little scroll it goes all the way down or up. Maybe it's a setting, but I would expect this to work like it should with basic settings. I have found the side screen scrolling with the mouse, so that makes it somewhat better, but overall the controls are really not great yet. The graphics are not great, it looks OK, but it's not the graphics you expect from a game today. Beside that it the graphical performance is not so good. Lot's of frame rate drops.Peeps are sometimes walking of the paths trough bushes and trees and some look like there are floating over the path.Sounds are missing from peeps when you ride allong. Sometimes when you ride allong with a rollercoaster you keep hearing the lift chain all the way in the ride.But at the other hand I think this game can have a lot of potential, but it does have a long way to go.If they make the graphics better and put some time in bug fixing, better controls and some more content and senarios to play it really can be a nice game to play.I would not recommend the game yet at this moment, the main reason for this is especially the price and what you get for it at the moment. On the other hand, if they will really make the game a lot better to play in the upcomming months with more content and features without extra costs the price is acceptable, but that's is something you will only know in time.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												I remember how much I loved playing RollerCoaster Tycoon when I was a kid. So many good memories ! Last week I learned that there was a new game of Roller Coaster ! So cool ! So happy ! Yay for the nostagical me ! But...This game is a complete waste of money and time. After only two hours of playing, the game just stoped working. (I was at the « Influencer challenge », you know, when you have to buy a souvenir shop for kids ?) Okay, this happens sometimes. I tried launching the game again. After clicking « resume », it stoped working. Okay... Maybe something wrong happened. I tried launching another park. Same thing. I even desinstalled the game and reinstalled it. Rebooting my computer. (which is not the problem, since I just bought it a few months ago) Same thing. Plus, the game isn't THAT good either and I am so bored with the bugs. Really, I do not recommend this game. I asked for a refund, since I just bought this game last week. I hope I will receive the money back soon. Right now I am downloading Planet Coaster, and I hope for a better experience ! A review of Planet Coaster will follow.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is hugely dissapointing. Finally another edition to the iconic loved series comes along and this is bearing in mind i played the beta weekends and felt disappointed then, it hasn't got any better. GAMEPLAY - Load times are somewhat slow, i run on a i7-4790k, GTX 970, 16GB RAM and just loading a blank sandbox park takes me 42 seconds, yeah not the end of the world but loading a blank park.. Lots of framerate drops too for seemingly no reason. I see no difference in the gameplay mechanics, the grid facility is pointless as it doesn't match up with anything, they say they completely overhauled the coaster builder since the beta. Well again i see no difference in the coaster builder now compared to the beta, it's really not good, it's incredibly difficuilt to get any smooth turns/curves/corners. Alot of placements of objects, scenery, paths etc. aren't 'allowed' when there is nothing blocking them from being placed. It's just frustrating, it's all these features that are the most fundamental part of the game and they still just don't work. Everything is just very tedious and frustrating to do, it should be easy! But instead, i feel it's very very poor.GRAPHICS - I wouldn't even go as far to say that they are OK, i understand graphics aren't everything, however after Roller Coaster Tycoon 3's release date of October 26th 2004 the graphics feel like more of a remaster apposed to up to date graphics. It just feels lazy, and it simply doesn't look refreshing or exciting. Nothing new or high tech going on here. Framerate drops all over the place even on low settings, changing graphical settings hasn't seemed to help in any scenario.CONTENT - Unfair to say considering it is now in early access and more content will be released, but don't expect a lot to begin with. There is barely a campaign. There are specific 'scenarios' such as 'Turn a failed park around' which are ok but not exactly a lot of thought put in here either. A sandbox mode which is great to have still so thats a positive!! FEATURES - Really the only noteable new good feature, is the curved paths and having the ability to not be restricted by a grid (however as previously said, neither work as you'd expect) other than that, there isn't a lot of difference. The social hub is a good idea to be able to share creations but i haven't seen it working yet so i can't comment.OVERALL - Bringing the franchise back again sounds like a fantastic idea, and what the developers are telling us and raising our hopes for just hasn't happened. Everything feels lazy and sloppy, just as if there is no passion put in anymore. It's such a disappointment, if you are a Roller Coaster Tycoon fan i can't imagine you are going to feel anything but disappointment which i hate to say. Once again, it's early access so there are features yet to come so this is as of now, but considering it has been delayed and now shoved in early access. Things don't look good.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wish this game turned out better than it has but the coaster creator feels...constricting and the amount of freedom in the game is much more limited than in previous installments. I took a big chance on this game since I have been waiting for a good theme park creating game to come along and take the podium previously discarded by RCT 2 but this one failed. They seem to have looked at the coaster creator and said, "hmh, it seems good enough". Whats even more insulting is that they cannot seem to create decent coasters on their own even though they have had plenty of time to play around with the creator. For instance I pulled up one of the parks that was already made and one of the coasters that was pre-built couldn't even complete the circuit. One of my favorite parts was the pre-made coasters with Liberty Loop from RCT 2 being my favorite premade. Feeling dissapointed but going to just get this over with by returning the game and waiting for planet coaster.

								Ok, first off - I remember going to EB games as a kid to buy the very first Chris Sawyer RCT back in around 1997. I have always been a loyal and dedicated fan of the franchise. I have spent entire summers in earlier editions of this game. I love the idea of this game!~This roller coaster tycoon...... I started playing this way back after the beta test in february. Since then, nothing much has changed. The game isnt even fully functional yet. its missing a few things still like transport and water rides, etc.. But whats worse, is that there are fundamental elements don't even work properly. I keep on trying to play it and then some bug starts ruingin everything. Today for example, in mid game - TWICE, the ability to click on rides and interact with them in any way with the mouse just completely stopped. More then one train ona track doesnt even work, hasent ever worked. Pathways are still wonky and force connect to nodes which leave you with all sorts of weird awkward results. Its just a mess... one thing gets added, two more things break. The most recent bug makes the game unplayable. I was really looking forward to this game, but with each passing day I am loosing more and more hope that this thing is ever even going to make it to a playable level...

content:
Posted: April 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Although this game is currently in 'early access' i'm not going to be too lenient on it as I originally pre-ordered it to come out in December 2015. For me, it has recreated the old 'Rollercoaster Tycoon' games but just removed the fun. Pros:- Despite what some people say, the rollercoaster builder is actually quite nice to use and I was able to create some good designs with it.- The ride cameras can sometimes be fun (if the framerate keeps up enough!)Cons (Where do I even start?):- Such a simple task of building paths is such a pain.. the game is so fussy about what connects where, and even with grid and snapping, I was unable to create a simple straight path system- The ride a building placement is equally as unpredictable, refusing to allow buildings to be placed in open areas next to paths, also not automatically joining to a path when placed directly next to one.- The staffing system has been 'dumbed down' and the janitors walk off and do what they want. You find yourself constantly building new staff buildings as the staff have seemingly disappeared and I cannot find a way to track them individually.- There is little to no customization on certain rides (especially pre-built ones).. Again, this removes a large portion of the fun.- The game seems to include food and souvineer stands from 4 set themes, limiting your creativity.- Only 3 maps that you can start from scratch on.- No autosave feature, so I lost over an hours work due to a power cut. In 2016 I would have thought this would be a standard feature?- Now for probably the biggest con.. graphics and performance... For a game that was supposedly meant to be 'retail ready' by December 2015, its appauling. The graphics look like a mobile phone game, or a PC game from 2004. Also the performance on highest settings is really bad. On my GTX 970, I can get around 30-40fps scrolling round my park. When I zoom in to watch the customers glitch around the footpaths and disappear into rides, however, i get as low as 15fps. The framerate is also very unpredictable when using the ride cams. I could go on and on about how I am disappointed by this game, but I'll cut the review here. I was looking forward to this so much last year that I didnt cancel my pre-order when I heard about the beta. I also eagerly downloaded it the minute I saw it was avaliable. I tried to enjoy the game and ignored the criticism, but all it did was make me want to play 'Rollercoaster Tycoon 2'!

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I had high hopes for this game. I thought that people were exaggerating when they claimed that not too far into the game, there would be performance issues. Unfortunately, they were not lying. About one hour into a small park I was making, the lag began to hit. At first, it was because of the short periods of the day in the game switching from day to night. I then locked it in the day phase and it had helped at first. However, not too long after, the lag continued to worsen. I understand that the game is still being worked on so hopefully they work on improving the performance issues. I know it's not my computer because it affects other users as well. On to the next topic, one thing that ruins the experience is the lack of custom buildings, like the ones in the previous games. I really miss creating buildings for my ride queues and what not. My park seems baren and the lack of decor doesn't help. I wish we had a larger selection of roller coasters as well. It'd be nice to have water rides or dark rides but they're unavailable right now. I think they should work on adding more theming and improving the performance issues. At the moment, I would not reccomend this game but hopefully in the future my opinion will change.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am a life long RCT fan, a huge fan of the series. I have player RCT 1, 2 and 3. And I have been VERY EAGERLY looking forward to RCTW!! I pre-ordered the Deluxe Edition of the game to get the extra bits and pieces and to give some extra funds of support to Atari and Nvizzio. It was a very expensive price for a game but I thought it would be well worth it... I was wrong! Yesterday I got the game, RCTW installed and I launched it, and within the space of ten minutes I was totally deflated by what I saw... I work in software development. I have used BETA's to get feedback on software from BETA Testers. I have taken part in software BETA's and early access. And yes, the software is buggy and needs a bit of polish, but I am STUNNED that the state RCTW is currently in is what Atari and Nvizzio only recently classed as a nearly finished game that was getting some polish and optimisation. Are you serious!?! REALLY!!! I know RCTW has gone through some rough patches. It's passed through the hands of a number of developers and I have backed them all. I had real admiration for Nvizzio as I saw the work they were doing and it looked great!! But I can tell you now, the RCTW game I have on my PC right now doesn't look anything like what I saw in the videos and screenshots used to promote this game. I didn't get to play the BETA back in October as I was away, so seeing RCTW today is my first real introduction to it, but what I see in RCTW today looks worse than what I saw of the BETA. The graphics seems to have degraded completely! The peeps looks terrible!! There are animation glitches, gameplay glitches, sound glitches, and the game just doesn't grab a hold of you and make you feel good about playing it. There is no soul to the game at all. The whole atmosphere is just wrong, no, it's missing completely!! If this was BETA 2, I would have been stunned by the poor quality of it... If this was really early access I would have been stunned by the poor quality of it... But the fact that Atari have said, prior to the "current" early access release, that this game was nearly finished and it was just getting some polish and optimisation for release... WOW!! I can't believe that THIS is what Atari classify as being a polished 2016 PC game. So I have a question... What happened...?!? Seriously, what has happened here? How can this version of RCTW that is "nearly finished and receiving some polish and optimisation" look so poor, so bad, and is so buggy and holds very little fun, be considered as good enough for release as a game??? I have to be honest, I have ZERO faith in Atari and Nvizzio that they can bring this game up to a good enough standard to make it the game that it should be! I also am wondering just what have Atari and Nvizzio being doing the past few months when there was silence on the forums??? I was, at the time, hopeful that they were busy making the game great! But I certainly don't see it... I see a very poor game that is nowhere near ready for release and I find it insulting that they classed this as a nearly finished game, receiving some polish and optimisation to get it ready for release. For the record, I don't have access to the Planet Coaster ALPHA, I do have the game pre-ordered, but I can tell you now, their ALPHA looks a LOT better than the RCTW nearly ready for release game. I will keep watching to see what Atari and Nvizzio do to save RCTW but I'm not expecting a miracle to happen and that's what needs to happen. Let's be honest, if this is what they class as a game nearly finished and getting polished for release, then it's an utter shambles!

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I can't recommend this game at the moment. I was prepared for it to be different to the other RCT games but it's just no good.The staff huts don't seem to have proper pathfinding for the staff so I can have a large hut with 10 janitors and the paths are absolutely filthy. I've got about 40 janitors and mechanics in a reasonably small park but rides remain unfixed for absolutely ages and the paths are rammy. I've set the inspection times to 20 minute intervals, my rides still breakdown all the time and then remain unfixed for ages, even when right next to the mechanic hut.I can't see any way to easily see what staff I've got and where. I placed a large entertainers hut... 1 month later  (game time obvs!) I saw 2 entertainers leave the building. And there were 6 'employed' apparently but no sign of them months later.There's no way that I can see what excitement levels or intensity the rides I'm building have before I actually build them. I don't know whether I'm getting value for money or not as I used to use that information to determine how much I can charge for the ride etc. Also doesn't say how big the ride is going to be until you actually select it.I was playing the campaign on frolicking forest, deleting trees and shrubs was a frickin nightmare and levelling the ground left me with several rock outcrops that wouldn't flatten so it was a little bit pointless. You should be able to delete trees and bushes by dumping a ride on top of them and all land you own should be able to be flattened easily.I want to like this game but I don't right now. I know it's early access but it should be better than it is.

								Not reccommending yet anyway.... this game has promise, but at this stage that is all it is... i love the RCT series and played all of them on PC since the first and put many hours in.... The major thing for me at this stage is the coaster builder, you can do anything with it which is great, but the problem is you can do anything with it and it is so hard to build anything complex or overly quick without it going wrong... you cannot delete multiple pieces of track, you have to select each one, it is pretty much impossible to build one using the track building as per RCT3, this has taken a backwards step IMHO, the people in the game are idiots, they are complaining they are hungry outside a huge selection of food shops and still complain, there is sick everywhere and no janitors ever clean it up, you cannot scale, or amend prebuilt rides or flats, the drop tower should be much higher and you should be able to amend this to suit, no monorail or trains (Yet, hopefully they will come).... I guess the main question should be what has changed since RCT3..... not a huge amount really.. yes the GFX look a bit better and the menus are different but is it really 10 years newer???? I guess the answer is no and unless they sort the coaster builder out so it makes sense and you can do what you want to do then i guess its kind of a backwards step vs RCT and when that came out.... I hope the DEV's can bring this into the 21st century as i want this to be good, but its just a bit lacking in every department.... this is an early release so i am holding out hope but i was hoping and expecting so much more..... PS if anyone can tell me how to do a straight bit of track using the builder then im all ears!

Early Access Review
								Total rubbish - Un-finished, unmarketable dross. I dont write steam reviews; Mainly becuase I am rubbish at them. In fact, my reviews are on par with the state of this game......The animations are awful and the UI is clunky. The 'Early Access' branding of this iconic game was always a mistake. Loyal fanbase back in the forum have been kept in the dark for months, but were informed by dev's the game was under going 'optmising and polish' a few weeks before the announced 'Early Access.' This was clearly an attempt to keep up with the competition, that released an Alpha before Atari and an attempt at trying to control media and user opinion with the usual cavet of 'Its early access.'Poor choices, poor devlopement and poor management have left this title lacking in all of the areas the old games excelled - Avoid right now, Come back this time next year when the title may be in Beta stage, with better graphics, performance and UI.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is in reference to the Early Access build released March 30.The good news first: The core engine is fairly solid, and is more than adequate to build a robust park-creation sim upon.The bad news is that they haven't done that yet. There's very little of the Early Access build that can be considered robust. The press release for the EA build boasts 4 different themes, and tons of scenery; the '4 different themes' bit is technically correct, but only because they didn't include the word 'complete.'  The 'tons of scenery' boast is an outright fib, unless they were estimating the raw, real-world tonnage of the simulated rock formations and generic foliage that comprise the mass of your 'theming' options. Actual theming options -- statuary, themed plants, facades, animatronics, landscape textures, etc. -- are extremely slim. As a strange contrast, there actually IS a fairly robust selection of fences and path textures, quite possibly more than were available in RCT3, so if you were hinging your plans for a dream park on pavement options, brother, this could be your train. A building sim lives and dies by its building options, and RCTW just doesn't have them, yet. It's hard to imagine what Atari was hoping to accomplish with this EA build; while this move ostensibly beats Frontier's "Planet Coaster" to the Steam marketplace, the lack of options can only result in unflattering comparisons and bad press.  I remain optimistic that the missing theming options are forthcoming (particularly if they have any hope of properly implementing dark rides, as they've announced), but as it stands right now, they have a long, long road ahead if they desire to catch up to RCT3, and much longer still if they hope to surpass it. For now, there's not enough here to justify a purchase. Will update review if this changes.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								To review the game I will just paste my comment on the discussion board, hopefully people will understand;"We have taken all the good from previous games and made it better" - I don't think soFirst off before I begin I want to point out that this isn't a BAD game, but the videos the devs released gave it a bit too much hype.Now as the title suggests I am here to point out the stuff that was good from the old games but the devs seemed to think was not important.The ability to modify your staff's roles, assign them to specific paths and to customer their uniforms.Now come on guys, really? This was a key fuction (for me anyway) as a kid to keep my park at top spec, now I am unable to make sure litter and other things is kept off paths as the janitors decide they just don't need to go up a ramp.The ability to modify/customise pre-built coasters/rides.Again, really? What harm would it of caused allowing us to change the colours of thrill rides or stores? My early parks in previous games were all colour coded sections and themes, now I know I can sort of have a theme BUT who says I want my sci-fi section to be blue and blue only?The graphics are really dated.This is another thing I don't quite get, you have the potential to make an amazingly good looking game, yet it looks like RC3 a couple of years later. Then it also seems your optomisation for powerful machines is a bit lacking too, when I put details to very high, I expect more than just block colours.Custom built coasters need some work.You build a piece, then you click it to move it, then you add bits, the you tell it to build another piece, then you move it....you are over complicating something that has unlimited potential.Like I said, it's not a bad game...it's just not a good game at this stage, yes yes, I know it's in alpha but they have had plenty of time to polish it up more than this...
