content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you're looking for the successor to the excellent RCT3, you're looking in the wrong place if you are considering RCTW.  RCT3 was created by Frontier Developments, and *published* by Atari.  RCTW is being delveloped by NVIZZIO (the 3rd developer hired by Atari for this project), and published by Atari.  The ONLY relationship between RCTW and RCT3 is that Atari has a license to the RCT name.  That's it.  This is Nvizzio's first stab at a RCT game, and it shows. Planet Coaster, however, is the true successor to RCT3, and is made by the same team, Frontier Developments.  It's simply doesn't have an RCT name because Atari paid Chris Sawyer for rights to the name.  Frontier has TONS of experience creating a great roller coaster park sim, since they did RCT3 and many other games in the theme park genre.  The attention to detail in Planet Coaster is amazing.  Just watch some YouTube videos and check it out yourself.  Frontier uses their own engine for Planet Coaster (PC), and it's obviously up to the task of making beautifully-rendered environments with thousands of animated guests that react to your park.So, I'm not going to repeat all of the negative reviews of RCTW here.  Those are all (mostly) true.  I've moved on, since Planet Coaster is far, far, far beyond where RCTW is.  If you want the ultimate in theme park simulation experiences, don't walk away from RCTW... RUN!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								So after playing for a couple hours, id thought I would share some of the things I like and do not like.So first off my major gripe is the AI, or lack of it. Workers hardly ever clean no matter how many janitor stalls you build, You have a park full of sick and trash. And people who seem to be ill, that look like Zombies.The visitors just seem to flock to the newest ride, there is no real equilibrium. The Animations and overall quality of the visitors is super poor, if you zoom in its tolerable, although nothing like the quality of Planet coaster, think more "Theme park animation / graphic quality" What is with the visitors animations? if you zoom in they seem to walk fine, but if you zoom out to the normal distance its as if the FPS drops on just the visitors animations. Looks ugly, seeing the "peeps" lagging. While the rest of the rides animations are fine.I dont like the themed buildings, it seems half arsed and an after thought. The shops look bad as they are, but you have to have 20 of the same ugly buildings because the "peeps" have a preference of which ugly building they buy from.The sounds OMG the Sound design is terrible. Tinny sounding music, constant screaming of children. I had to play on mute. The times I have been to parks, I dont hear screams over the ambient noise, like its the "Hostel" film.They clearly have got allot of inspiration from City Skylines ie the path placement, the style of UI, the land system. But have not translated all the quality and charm Skylines has.The game just seems to lack depth, I want a research tree. To have goals to unlock the rides / shops i want.I want better Animations on everything but the rides, I want better quality graphics, I want scenery that matches it surroundings so rock formations and things dont look so artificial. I want a more in-depth staff system, that I control. But after 5 hours of play the thing that is bugging me so much that I have to stop is the buggy visitor animations / AI / quality.I dont feel like spending hours building something awesome, to watch these freaks walk around my sick/trash/zombie filled park.I like the Coaster system, I like the variety or scenery. I like the terrain tools, I like the pathing system and the UI although it lacks depth.You say you went the EA route not to add polish but to add more "functionality" The game needs WAY MORE polish. This does not look like a game released in 2016.The core is there and some of the systems are in place although they lack allot of depth. I pre-ordered so long ago, I really wish you had not of released it in this state, even as EA.You only get 1 real launch and first impressions mean everything. Im unsure whether to refund this or not.I im such a fan of this series even after pre-ordering so long ago and let down after let down. Everything I stated is meant for constructive purposes, not as hate or any other BS. I hope this helps.This is for the developers, not a PR person you delete my post and ill post it somewhere you cant delete it

number of helpful: 11 of 18 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This Game does not live up to its promise. They pushed it back and back since they cannot meet the deadlines apparently. Then they have applied the smart marketing trick of making it early access: meaning no money left but they desperately need it. Which would be ok I guess BUT:There is the tiny problem of an important feature missing: stacking scenery to build buildings etc. Their response: I could go into a 3D software and create my own models of scenery but in game I cannot because it would be too complicated. So a major NO! Rides cannot be customised at all (except for colors and a couple of trees) and thus it feels like a smartphone game rather than a real RollerCoaster Tycoon (even when just considering the graphics). Maybe they will activate that feature in an in app purchase way or add high resolution textures as a DLC. But they stated that they will add rides and scenery and tweek the physics, but that the basics of the mechanics are pretty much done.If you are ok with all of these limitations, I can recommend you the game because it does exactly what you expect. If you don't, then keep far, far away from this game!Finally, on a personal side, due to this "clever" marketing trick and these false promises, I am no longer elegible for a refund of the game: I preordered 2 months before the official release date, the game came out 4 months after the official release date as an early access and I requested a refund with 5 minutes of ingame play - steam says sorry, you have purchased it more than 6 months ago - WHAT? So another thumbs down but this time for steam. I will still try to get a refund though!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I know this is an early release version of the game - but honestly, it is even light years behind the previous instalment in the series, RCT3, in terms of graphics and game physics. In terms of usability, it is far too complex in places that could be a lot more simple, too, and for a game that I've wanted since I was about fifteen, this has really let me down. If this was £10, then I would say it was worth the expenditure. But this much money? I definitely would not recommend it. I have honestly never felt this let down by a video game in the past, and I can see a lot of people jumping to this game's direct rival - coaster planet - Upon its release. This is the kind of quality that I would expect from a tablet game. I'll check back in the future and see if RCT can revive my faith in the series, but as of now, it's looking extremely unlikely. Farewell, RCT, and farewell my hard earned £30. You will be missed!

The coaster builder is tough to control, the path building system is pretty limited, and the graphics are not very good for a game that is released in 2016. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								I tried to stay positive, even though this game has had its fair share of negativity in the, ehh, recent past. I remained hopeful for the EA, and this review is keeping in mind that it's EA. Having played a few EA titles, and knowing how much a title can improve to final release, this review is negative, because I just don't see that it will improve enough to final release to warrant a positive review. Yes, it will improve, but I just dont see that without starting from scrath (again), this game can be salvaged. In any case, keep in mind that this review is of the first EA release.But let me start with the positive. For me, at least, it runs smoothly and without problems. Performace wise, then, it's good. That is about all the positive I can say about it. Other than that, nothing positive to report, unfortunately.The graphics are, without question, horrible. Nothing close to the "in game" screens we were shown before. The rides, the scenery, foliage, ground textures etc... I haven't seen any redeeming quality to any of it. There are several things I compare this to: RCT3, Planet Coaster (the competitor), Cities Skylines (built on the same engine), other similar sim-type games from the past 10 years. Without fail, I cannot think of any other high-profile game that is worse than the current state of RCTW.Animations of rides are adequate I guess, but nothing to write home about. They could do with better physics simulations.Animations of peeps - how they move that is - is atrocious. Even RCT3 did a better job at this. They perform several actions and show their emotions (e.g. having to go to the bathroom, hunger, anger, being sick etc.), but the animations are honestly just bad. Even their standard walking and running actions are awkward. On that note, peeps look horrible. Colours, textures, shapes, everything. If you're into misformed yellow and brown blobs with creepy unexpressive and oversized eyes, this may be your thing. But no, they are not "cartoony", they just look like they stepped out of a game from the mid-90s. What I may forgive the EA for is peeps, park workers (cleaners, medics etc.) walking through fences, buildings, off-grid paths, each other, to their destination. I may also forgive cleaners sweeping footpaths about 6 feet  away from where the dirt actually is. These can be fixed in future updates. But what will be a tall order to do is the seemingly faulty pathfinding of peeps to their destinations, which at this stage seems worse than in RCT3. The workers also seem to have a wonky work/pathfinding method to get to their next destination. For examply, just in RCT3, janitors are happy to walk straight past 10 puke piles to get to a dropped cup half-way across the park. These kinds of AI behaviours I am less optimistic can be fixed easily. Paths are very hard to use. The three widths are ok, but their snap points are hard to use. This is a similar problem that Planet Coaster suffers from currently, that foodcourts with tighly packed shops are basically impossible to build. Maybe something that will be resolved. This is personal preference, but should be inclued in the review: I am no fan of the pre-made and themed large food stalls and buildings. I much prefer a smaller footprint basic stall and build my own scenery/building around it. For me, at least, Planet Coaster has an advantage here. This is personal preference, if you like plop and forget, then RCTW is for you - just not for me at this time. The coaster builder is actually not that hard to use. If I compare it to Planet Coaster's, I would say it's about the same level of difficulty to use. From me, no major complaints with the basic construction side of things. On the other hand, the graphics of coasters, their supports and the physics seem wonky to put it mildly. Much work needed here, but I think it could be done. Overall mechanics and park management is basically a carbon copy of RCT3. Yes, the heat map and extra graphs may give you a bit more information about the park, and in the future there may be a few extra options in buildings, but overall it is exactly the same and nothing new to see. I also don't see any "placeholders" for future expansions in this realm to get me excited. TLDR - in conclusion: very unpolished, which may be expected for EA. I personally don't see, however, how it'll be the game that was promised to the community - feels like at this point no matter how much the turd is polished, it remains a turd. Maybe there was too much hype from Atari (understandable marketing) making my expetations too high, but compared to my own expectations, this game falls short. If you have tons of $$ to buy both PC and RCTW, do so. It may be a fun game for a little while and worth the investment down the line. If you only have $$ for one, I'd recommend waiting and spending it on PC, because I don't think this one will be PC's match even at final release. I have both, and will keep both. But I am a sucker, and wouldn't recommend it to others. I wanted to add a little edit to the end of this review to maybe clarify one point. This review may have been positive, but it is - and I fully acknowledge this - skewed by expectations. This is not my own preconceptions about what I expected the "next-gen" RollerCoaster game to be like, but rather by the expectations I had based on the promises made by Atari reps this past year or so. While Planet Coaster does look much better than RCTW right now, at least graphically, in terms of features it offers much, much less. But - and this is a big but - they folks at Frontier have been very honest with where the game is currently, what they are releasing in the Alpha and why, what they want to test and what kind of feedback they want. On the other hand, the folks at Atari have been spewing AAA, the best, so exciting, full of features, looks awesome, and other such language, which this game is not. At least not currently. So yes, a large part of the negative review is part of the humongous PR failure on Atari's part. If they had kept expectations realistic (not low, but realistic) and were honest what is actually being released - an unpolished pre-alpha stage of the game, I may have had a positive review. But not like this. If I take their word that this game has been in "final optimization and polishing" for the past four months, and is 90% complete, then no, I cannot give it a positive rating. Just wanted to clarify this point. :)

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Has potential but needs a lot of polish!First and foremost - fix the camera when building a coaster.  Give us an option for the camera NOT to follow the track additions.  Every time I chnage a track peice, size, lenght, etc. the camera moves me farther away (usually up) which makes finishing a coaster very frustrating.  I've managed to play for about 3 hours and in my last session finally copmpleted a custom coaster - several times before I gave up & quit the game.Second, keep fixing bugs.  Once I finally completed my first custom coaster the trains crashed off the track in a straight spot of track.  No reason for the coaster to fail????  I quit the game after that...Third and final rant for now - we need an option to sync same selected option across stalls.  This was added to previous versions of RCT because it just makes sense.  Its no fun clicking on each & every stall to chnage a setting (turn music on) or adjust a price.I understand this is "Early Access" and it is a shame that this is used as a tool to ship incomplete product to the consumer.  Early Access was certainly not mentioned when I pre-ordered.  Wish I could recomend but not in it's current state.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								It scratches an itch for $20. I would not recommend paying $50 for something that has had the troubled development cycle this game has had. the game crashes, lags when the park is near capacity, the peeps are downright stupid and sometimes don't even stay on the paths correctly. The graphics are not great, including the scenery which looks particularly bad when trying to design something nice to look at. This would all be forgivable considering it's "early access", however they may not be trustworthy to fully fix the issues. They've swapped developers twice, have delayed a year and at the last second decides it's early access and then wants $50 from you. If you can find a sale for $20, it's got more than enough content here, buggy and all to justify that price point. Not everything is horrible and I had fun building my scifi park. It's just not worth $50 for something that's possibly not a sure thing. Planet Coaster looks really great too, however $75 for early access is outrageous.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								RollerCoaster Tycoon World has several problems in its current state:- The Grid and Snap on function doesn't always seem to work as intended. Making two roads parallel to eachother is far more difficult than it should be.- Making rollercoasters the way you want is nearly impossible. I can't even make a simple loop.- Coasters can't be tested while the time is paused.- The building/editing tool for both roads and coasters takes time to get used to. - To edit terrain doesn't work correctly, and can make permanent holes in the ground. - Peeps (AI people) seems to have problems with pathfinding at times. - The few tutorials they do have are useless.Despite these problems I did have some fun with the game, however the older games have so far been better. I hope they fix the problems as well as improve the controles for building/editing tools. At its current state I cannot recommend the game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								As someone who has been defending RCT with how slow they have been releasing this game, I am compeltely disappointed in the Early Access. First of all the tutorial is a FAQ of text. Altering the terrain really tests your patience with such a tiny brush size and no strength option. You cannot flatten terrain with trees and bushes, however to delete them you have to click on every single bush and tree (which the majority of the time the cursor doesn't sync to what you're trying to delete) - there is no drag a box to delete or brush tool deletion. There is also no undo button, which is extremely handy in building sim games. Laying pavements are frustrating when there is no freetool option and the grid tool is buggy. Camera controls are very limited to WASD to move the camera and scroll wheel adjusts zoom and angle. Basically, TLDR: Worst than previous RCT (buy RCT3) and it's a terrible Early Access Game, save your money until proper release and see what everyone says about improvement/ save for Planet Coaster which looks epic.

Early Access Review
								Got banned for making critical comments about the 2 years they had my money and didn't deliver the game.  I had pre-purchased the game 2 years ago and the developer kept giving false release dates...and then finally released it as a "early access" a day or two ago.  They banned me because I was critical of their false advertising and false reporting of release date.  And just before they banned me...they kept deleting all my posts that were about game ideas and comments about game progression.  SO...whatever discussions you are reading....have mostly all been santized already. They are not letting any critical posts or anything that might even be a suggestion to help the game get better.  All they want to do is let the discussions appear as if the game is completely fine.  All suggestion discussions are being deleted to give a false impression of game.    As a side note, to move around the map you need to use your keyboard.  It's not like RCT3 or any other game like this....when you move the mouse to the side of the screen, you should be able to move around the map w/o using a keyboard.  Very frustrating.  When they unban me...i MIGHT change my negative review.

content:

Early Access Review
								I feel like this early access release was a valiant effort on Atari's part to fix all the problems that were definitely evident in the first beta. However as I have come to play this early access now, some of the problems within the coaster design and potential layout of an entire theme park have almost become worse. In the first beta of this game I knew the coaster builder needed quite a bit of work done, I did slowly start to get used to parts of it while I was building and managed to get a few functioning coasters going in my park. This new release of the coaster builder places a very opaque sphere where your cursor is to build the next piece, but it is very hard to adjust and manover the placements. It also becomes very jumpy when trying to edit previously added parts to the coaster. Also there is no way to turn it off if you just want to go by segments which I felt was a good addition they said they were going to add in. I would be much happier if I had a button to manually jump between the two, ironically it would make building a coaster much more seamless. The other big issue I have is that we no longer have the options to place entrances and exits, I'm not sure if this will be adjusted before release but it removes a degree of customization out of theme park building which we have always had in the RCT series. I also find the pathing system a little too jumpy. Even the old RCT 1 and RCT 2 pathing was better. The benefit to the game that I find is finally the implementation of buildings for mechanics and janitors, instead of just dropping them in the game like the old days. It will be interesting to see how much they need to radically change when they exit out of this early access program. I may pop on occasionally over the next little while to see if they take in anymore of what the community is describing as flaws to the game. And if they are successful, I could definitely see myself spending a good amount of time on this game much like my oodles of time spent on the previous games and change this review to a positive.I guess time will tell.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
A terrible ride...After giving this game many chances, after defending the game after its terrible beta, after waiting for months... I think I can safely say that this game is nothing like a RCT game!I have been a fan of the RCT series since I was 8 years old, I loved it! I remember owning almost every edition of the game, I even had to rebuy RCT 3 as a kid cause I broke it by playing it so much!... But this... Oh man, this is a terrible retake on the series! It does not even feel like an RCT game, it's that bad! While I believe that there are people that enjoy this game (like 1/4th of the people do), it should've never been launched with the name RollerCoaster Tycoon! I respect the developers for keeping their heads up and keep pushing out updates, really I do appreciate the hard work from Nvizzio Creations... But they are in a bad spot! While I believe that Nvizzio Creations is a great company it is ruined by Atari's greedy mindset. You can push out a few more updates, but please... Trust me on this, it will never get out of early access, and if it does... The game wil be completely dead. *Update (17/11/2016): it got out of early access... But it's still terrible...*If you really want to get a copy of this game, get it when it's only 10 euro/dollar. It is not worth a full charge of €45,99 *Update (17/11/2016): It's €31,99 now, still not worth it...* It's ridiculous!* What's Good:- Consitent updates...- It's hard to find something good...* What's Bad:- Engine choice (Unity, really?)...- Paths are terrible...- Physics...- Everything you can imagine actually...

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								RCTW Is a  coaster building game from the creators of RCT1 and RCT2... During my playthrough I quickly set up my rides and pathways, even tried out the coaster builder a few times... However we're going to narrow this review down to the good the bad and the ugly parts of the gameTHE GOOD- Killing Peeps on rides and drowning them is back! And more fun than before!- SOYLENT GREEN shop oh my ♥♥♥♥ing god if you're a sadistic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like myself you'll include this in your park... It's kinda mandatory.- The graphics aren't bad, they are close to being on par with Sim City and Cities Skylines, but they're nothing special.- The sound is great! Hearing the bustleing of peeps and chains pulling coasters over a steep fall, it feels good and sounds appropriate.- Modding is there for those who can mod and whatnot and steam workshop will provide adiquate mods for people to try out.THE BAD- Coaster Builder will often Crash your game and your computer! Throught my multiple attempts to use it my monitors will often cut out when the game crashes, causing me to restart constantly. This issue MUST be fixed immidiatly -Some peeps are just UGLY and the shopkeepers are absolutely terrifying "THEY STARE INTO THE DARKEST DEPTS OF YOUR SOUUUUUUUUL!!!!:-On occasion the framerate will dip and bog down the pc.THE UGLY-Lack of customization. You cannot customize the rides the same way you could in previous rct games, you can't make your own ride entrences and exits, instead there are preset buildings that you can plop down... I absolutely despise this-Coaster Builder is VERY tough to use at times, as you can try to make turns and lifts and dips, your mouse curser may spaz out and cause the track to expand into the♥♥♥♥♥end of nowhere...-Severe Lack of themes for your park... With previous titles you had wester, spooky,industrial, fun themes, ice themes, lava themes, dino, retro, suburbon, in this game there's hardly even a third of what previous games had in terms of themes... I thought this was a Theme park! (I can't even make a bad joke by locking sections of the park off to peeps unless they cough up money, so no paywall joke/ dlc joke for me")FINAL THOUGHTSWhile the game can get addicting, and can be quite fun when it works, the glareing issues this game has is unbearable, even for an early acess game... I thought they delayed the game so that they can fix the issues, instead I see some the same issues I saw in the Beta!I guess I'll wait till planet coaster comes out and see how it fares.

Early Access Review
								small update now i run a amd fx-8350 cpu and the game still runs like a hobo's fart after a can of unheated beans with to many onions -_- sigh where to start my system has a r9 380 4 gb model from xfx and geus what the game does it starts normally in menu full 60 fps (60 mhz screens)i go into a game with any possible settings configuration possible and the grafix chip drops to between 400 and 666 mhz yes 666 and the fps goes max with very very mutch luck to 18 and guess what after 2 hours i looked into the game folders and what i was sigh the game uses unity and yes i know if done right unity can be a good engine but damn ive seen kids make better running stuff with it ow and my system has a amd phenom 2 x6 1090t clocked at 4.5 ghz stable with a full load 40 degrees Celsius (don't ask how because i wont share my methods)20 gb 1666 ram and it can run anything i throw at it with a stable 60 fps but i soldierd on for a while with the really bad performance and trust me it wasn't the last of the problems the paths the snapping system the grid system fun idea's sure but executed horrible but i still had a bit of fun with the game however possible i hope they will fix it and learn from all the negative feedback they give and well start working on the problems because if♥♥♥♥♥♥isnt fixed soon i think this will be the last rct game that people look out forbut there is one upside for me i got the game from a friend and didnt pay a dime

Everyone's open to their own opinion but this is mine...THIS IS EARLY ACCESS, BUT MY FRUSTRATION IS ALSO EARLY ACCESS!!i apologise in advance to any diehard fans or anyone that's affected by what i write but this is simply as how i see it..Do I Recommend This Game? Damn It!!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Currently, RCTW will run at a *measured* average of 19fps at 1024x768 / lowest settings.  That's on my Core i7 / Nvidia GT 940 laptop.  At 4K on lowest settings I get around 2fps.  I haven't tried the game on my desktop yet, but it's really not worth my bandwidth at the current state.  Fully maxed at 4K, I'm not really impressed at the looks of the game - it reminds of me of RCT3.  Gameplay wise, there's no in-depth park management, building straight paths is a nightmare (even with the grid on), and tbh there's just no fun in building a beautiful park like in RCT 1/2.  The charm is gone and replaced with flashy menus and thrill ride designs.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is really sad for me. I've been a RCT fan since the first one, and I was overly excited to RCTW as the start when Atari announced back in 2014. Just bought it in November, I was upset with the launch delay, but ok, I understood.But now, this EA (which is not an beta or alpha) looks really bad. I gotta say, not everything, but here are certain things that really dissapointed me, and I hope that Nvizzio will fix. Some of them was in the previous RCT games.- Everything is just too much big. (Even the food store, which I think is the smallest thing in the game)- The path tool didn't work to attach some things (some ridiculous things, it's hard to attach the queue lines in those)- You have NO CONTROL of the employees, and it's unnecessary to need a giant building to hire them. (You can't even set a specific place for them to stay)- There's no research for the things just like was before. You can unlock the things only completing the goals. I didn't like it.- You have very poor information and control of the guests (You can't ammount them by sorting the thinking or the feeling.- A simple roller coaster (yeah, really small and smooth track) it's getting a extreme-high level of Nausea, making about 80% of the people throwing their stomachs out by the exit of the track, making the paths incredible dirty.I will not talk about the graphics, the lagging, the low frame rate, and the visual of the peeps, which you can find more complains here in another review.It's playable. But it's kinda sad, really is. And don't worth the paying right now.I hope they'll fix all of this soon, making me change this review. I really hope.6/10

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
												The game itself is very confusing compared to previous installments (1-3...all of which had a more autocad like feel). They had a steep learning curve, but made easy with ten times the automatic coaster piece options. Once a person got the hang of it, the world was their oyster. On WORLD however, every button, control and feature is all jacked up. Maybe they lost certain rights to use the previous interfaces, button configurations and script interface methods so they had to change it to a foreign design. The game industry is doing that a lot. Some games claim to be "different than Call of Duty" but really they just switched the grenade and jump buttons and confused a bunch of noobies. Another thing is the 2014 release date...woops. Fast forward to the 2016 version that is for some reason sitting on shelves at Best Buy and Walmart with (full game must be downloaded from Steam) written on it...SO WHY THE DISK?! It is almost like we are loving shooting ourselves in the foot with this game. I want a refund and continued access to this game for free. Complete waste of money.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								For this review I am gonna do a fair comparsion between RCTW another game in the same genre: Planet Coaster1 Game Basics1.1 GraphicPlanet Coaster 8/10Good Color Filter and good cartoon graphic in general, very good!Rollercoaster Tycoon World 4/10Bad Color Filter, too yellow and grey, graphic is bad as a game released in 2009, park detail is horriable and store models are repeated.1.2 SoundPlanet Coaster 9/10I really like the catchy BGM in the main menu and devs also use the BGM properly in every detail of the game (like the one played when the park is loaded and we start playing).Rollercoaster Tycoon World 6/10Not Bad Background Music, still the same style (but changed a bit) of the 1st and 2nd generation.1.3 HUD (UI)Planet Coaster 6/10Generic Park Simluation UI, the globe in the main menu is static and not rotatable, and the icons on it are repeated, very ugly. Please redesign it.Rollercoaster Tycoon World 7/10Simple and beautiful flat designed UI, with cool animation, easy to get started, but there are some translation errors and menu selection bugs at the current stage, which should be fixed after I believe.2 Game Elements2.1 RidesPlanet Coaster 8/10Rides totally functioned and animated beautifully, guests can interact with the rides perfectly, coaster can be easily built and mounted.Rollercoaster Tycoon World 7/10Rides totally functioned and animated beautifully, guests can interact with the rides but due to the awful guest model, it's ugly, coaster can be easily built and mounted.2.2 GuestsPlanet Coaster 9/10Perfect cartoon guest art style, featured tons of differnet animation which makes the park alive and artistic, but guest types are too narrow, too repeated.Rollercoaster Tycoon World 0/10Totally piece of sh1+, dumbass motherfcker super b1+ch puzzy cun+. What the FK is this? Guest? Peep? I'd better watch Justin Bieber dancing rather than watching those lame cheap craps walking and running. Don't release the game until the designers who designed those guests are fired by Atari.2.3 Park LandscapePlanet Coaster 8/10Great Lanscapes, piece by piece building system (MOD), very good vista and flexiable terrain system with infinte possibilites. And many themes available.Rollercoaster Tycoon World 5/10Acceptable but still needs to be polished, the cars parked outside are repeated and meaning nothing, and there are only 2 types of themes (meadowland and western). Vista is super ugly,2.4 PathPlanet Coaster 3/10Very bad path algorithm. I can not build stright paths and build linear stations, too bad, please redesign your algorithm for path system.Rollercoaster Tycoon World 6/10Path system is OK. I can build stright and bend paths as I want but still a little bit harder. And another very bad thing is the path seems to be floating on the land surface instead of stay right on the land surface, which makes the game looks cheaper.3 ExtraFor the rest of the parts such as optimization, advanced graphic or steam workshops and so on, I am not gonna review at the current stage because the game is not actually finished.Final Score:Planet Coaster(8+9+6+8+9+8+3) / 7 = 7.3Rollercoaster Tycoon World(4+6+7+7+0+5+6) / 7 = 5.0

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I understood why the first beta weekened was bad, and didn't judge. Then they skipped the next weekends for the pre-orders. They lied about the December release date, then did not post any news for MONTHS. All of the sudden they come out with early access, and the game is just as bad as it was last October. Terrible FPS just trying to play (I have verey good specs.) The path system is a joke, I can't connect paths without FPS loss, and weird snap issues and bugs. Coaster editor... What? It makes no sense. RCT 3 is so much better than this, even graphics wise. It was released in 2004. I reccomend buying Roller Coaster Tycoon 3. Not this.

								Had it since last year and was hoping for a full release.Then they came whit the early access program and i was like "ok maaaaybe it will be good"Yesterday i tried it, boosted all my graphics to max and was hopeful to try the game.I was speechless, How can a game, that had many release changes and after the planned release date went to early access status, be sooo bad!After 5mins in game it hurts to see that the name rollercoaster has become this …… well to be polite “bad”It’s really a shame that seeing this game, my hopes for a good new rollercoaster tycoon named game is gone.I had no choice to ask for a refund and thx to steam for the fast response because this kind of stuff can’t be supported especially when you had all the time to make things perfect.Kind regards from a hurt tycoon fan.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I truly belive this will be a great game once it's finally finished, but for now there are some serious problems.  My main complaint is with the new paths engine.  This is the way you build and connect paths and queues in the game, and it is borderline unusable becuase connecting to existing paths is difficult and building grid-aligned paths has been made harder in order to support more organic shapes.  The developers claim this is one area of focus for improvement, which is the only redeeming factor.Beyond that, there are various graphic bugs I've noticed while playing and sometimes the rides just stop running and need a manual stop and start.  The game itself has even locked up while loading and exiting.  Maybe in a couple updates I can change this review, but for now, older versions of the game are better.

Early Access Review
								I bought this game in the hopes of great fun! But instead I got afustrating not simple game which i am not keen to play again until some drastic updates has happened for the game! I really am sad that the mouse cursor when moved to the corner the map moves with you like previous games also I spent half hour trying to make a curvy pathway and failed. Also i couldn't rotate my rides like previous games ONE simple click to turn it right or left with simple arrow icons. PLEASE MAKE IT EASIER TO ROTATE THE RIDES AND MAKE IT SO THE CURSOR MOVES WITH YOU WHEN MOVED TO A CORNER. That will help a lot in making the game more simplistic and more fun to play. Graphics are great, lovely colour but the game is sadly too complicated compared to the older versions of this game which i love playing.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is not ready to be published.  If they would just  play the game for like 5 hours before releasing it, they would know that the game is messed up.  The system of deletion and snapping are jacked.  The mechanics get stuck and stop working.  The thoughts of the peeps just dissapear, never to return, but don't worry, they still get mad.  There is no easy way to find where your staff are, or figure out what they are doing.If you make the angle of the path exiting your rides at any more than 45 degrees, it won't allow you to make the queue and visa versa. I've also had a little trouble with connecting new paths to already built 1paths (not an issue of angle),The maintnence guys go back in as soon as they come out of the door of the buildig.  If they do make it out, pretty much all 10 of them are stuck together walking around.I am very dissapointed with this game.  I love the idea.  The problem that I see is that in the last couple of years, many gaame makers have been giving us broken games.  This is unacceptable.  The game litterally doesn't function.  I feel like I should be able to return this garbage and maybe buy it back if the designers get their crap together.It's appears that they focused so much on how the game would look, that they completely neglected making sure that if functioned propely

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Holy mother of god. Absolutely awful. 107 minutes in and I just couldn't take the mess any more. Already requested and received my refund.  This game was supposed to be out months ago... and here we are, 3 months late, and it's still 'early access'? I can understand a few glitches here and there, but this is ridiculous. 60% of the time, the game won't load, and when it does load, functions of the game won't turn off when switched on..... for example, I turned on the 'heat map' feature to find my most popular ride. The heat map would not disable and conveniently covered the menu button so I could not save and reload the game... 45 minutes of game gone to a rookie league glitch. The peeps are glitchy and half of them just 'float' instead of actually walk and move... the ride camera stops working and the peeps on the ride appear to detach from the ride and kind of hover over the seats.. this game that is incredibly late is almost unplayable. I wanted to like it. I really did. I've loved the genre since game 1, but Atari really screwed the pooch. I will be buying Planet Coaster which is made by the same people who created the first 2 rollercoaster tycoon games... Atari merely bought the name "rollercoaster tycoon" and destroyed it.Awful, Atari... just awful.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Really had high hopes for this game, but they faded very quickly. I've put 3 hours in so far and I don't see myself reaching 4hrs any time soon. It just doesn't feel like it has evolved enough from RTC 3. It's still way too restrictive on placement and positioning and the spline coaster building had so much promise but is failing to deliver. The peeps are graphically no where near up to the standard they should be and look lost most of the time with poor animation to boot. It is currently possible to develop a good park but I don't feel the same enjoyment as I do with other similar games. Sadly would not recommend. I sincerely hope they continue to develop this game to a higher standard, but I think other titles out there are way beyond the reach of Atari. (Luckily game cost me less than £15 so I will keep hold on n see)

I would probably love this game if i could actually play it.So the point of my review is: You need a $600+ computer to run this game.

Early Access Review
								I was NOT pleasantly surprised by this disappointing Early Access simulation. The interface offers very few options for tailoring the way you move around, and in its present form is frustratingly clumsy. Paths and Cues are hard to join up. Path lights and rubbish bins wont install on any path that is elevated, so some large parts of your park are in darkness. There doesn't appear to be any way of placing paths and tracks through hills, and etc.This game is not worth it for the price you pay. If it had been half what I paid for it (knowing that later I would have to buy addons like the RCT franchise has always worked) I may have taken the time to give feedback, and bide my time with it.Conclusion: Don't waste your money. By something else like I did.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								In short, the game is still broken from every point of view, and looks worse compared to an alpha version of its competitor, Planet Coaster.I've been playing this game for some time now and on the positive side, it IS addicting to play the game. It's great to finally have a follow up in the Rollercoaster Tycoon franshice and for now i'm happy its here.Some complain about graphics, but I don't really mind looking at what amount of details I can put into the park and how large the park can get. The cartoony still looks great in this game and scrolling down to human level is beautiful in my opinion. I really want to give kudos for the devs for not resizing the levels into a Sim City disasteres small squares.But there is were it stops. Looking back to the beta, and now the Early Access (not release) no progress has been made at all. Building coasters is still as broken as it was in the beta. Random impossible twists are added as soon as you place a new piece that looked perfectly fine before placing it. And for some reason, a simple circle coaster is good enough to make everyone vomit and not liking your track. The only thing they fixed since the beta, is that they blame the user for not making a good coaster. THAT IS NOT FIXING THE BUG!The game is this bad, that even connecting two paths that run side by side is nearly impossible to do. It just doesn't connect! How can this problem still be in the game! Even when it starts to work, its a big hassle to make it do what you want to do because it just doesn't do what you want.In case you're into making the park look nice with a lot of small details and such. You're out of luck with this game. For example, adding benches or lights is a BIG PROBLEM. It's really incosistent and just doesn't allow you to create something nice. The game is keep saying you can't place an item there, when it is able to do it on the other side at exactly the same place and conditions.AI is also broken. People are 100% hungry, and walk like they really are hungry. But even with a street full of different shops to eat (with prices at $0, and food quality high) they won't eat. The cleanup crew randomly walks through everything and everyway, but barelly cleans something up. I've got over 500 people hired, and it's still a big mess. They even walk over the vomit or trash not doing anything.I even got a coaster that went broken as soon as I opened it. Even over 500 mechanics, even a few buildings next to that coaster wasn't going to help me having it fixed. And fixing it manually isn't possible. So I had to redo the coaster. Great!The other big promise is that you can use User Generated Content. Thats great, but they have no search or filter functionality. No sorting, nothing. It's as bare as it can get. And even than... even than, they can make it crash the game almost everytime you try using it. Losing your game process.Thats anothing thing. In what age are we living in? 1995? Are we still getting "Oops I forgot to save, now I lost everything because of a bug/crash" conversations. Has any of the devs ever heard of autosaving / creating backups?The game is as bad as it's beta, and even with the current trend of people hating the game, the money and time the devs will be allowed to fix it will be even more limited. This is just another cash in, a way to steal our money.Don't buy it, hopefully Planet Coaster will do better. But that is something we only can see in the future. I hope this game doesn't ruin the franchise and the next game will be better!

Early Access Review
								Despite all of the negative reviews, this game really isn't that terrible. Although there are some annoying bugs and some funky features, none of them are really game destroying. There's been a lot of hate about things not snapping correctly, or things not snapping at all, and although it is a bit annoying, there's really easy ways to work around it. People have been commenting about the graphics as well too, and although they aren't top notch, they are pretty good, and much better than RCT3. Let's just hope for some basic fixes too, and I'm sure this game will pull through, just like the others did! :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8
												Pros: Fun. Cons: Freezes constantly.  I honestly love the game, when it actually works for me. The negatives that I've seen, not from other reviews, but from my own experiences, out weigh the good, but only  because I can't experience good features of the game if I can't play it. It either freezes up, causing me to have to restart my computer because not only do I lose the ability to move the mouse pointer, not one shortcut to the desktop will work, or it stalls so long that I think it's frozen. I tried giving it time to load one night. It literally sat on the loading screen, trying to open my park, for roughly 10 minutes, then an additional to wait for the game to work and become unpaused once it was open. When it's not freezing or stalling, there's other glitches like peeps showing up where they shouldn't, paths for some reason not being accessable even though they've been checked several times, and just other things that aren't really huge, but frustrating and make game play unenjoyable. I have played it alot lately because I will load my screen, get really into my park, loving the graphics, the way the rides flow, and then it'll crash and I'll have to hard reset or open task manager if I can even get it to go back to the desktop to close the program. I've gotten in a few hours like that, I'll play for a while, then BAM, frozen, and always at the most successful or suspensful parts of my park's development, then because I want to continue with my park, I'll hop right back in just for it to do it again, sometimes not even making passed the menu. But, don't get me wrong,  I have played for hours on the good nights that it functions well too, it can get addicting. But it's sad when you really like your park and before you can save it, it freezes. To be honest, besides the bad glitches, I really enjoyed the game, I just have to save my it between every 5 and 10 minutes so that I don't risk losing what I worked on.  I cautiously recommend this to my friends who enjoy these games, but I advise you to try using patience before immediately calling it a failure. I really have liked it, it just works your nerve up more than it probably should.  It's new, so hopefully some updates can fix the problems. I'll have hope.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Game demands a lot out of the cpu, FAR more then the recommended spec, so either the spec is a lie or the game is SERIOUSLY un optimized. This wouldn't be an issue, if the game wasn't delayed so damn long making me believe that it will never get fixed. This is compounded with a shocking lack of content, and questionable time management, as the food stalls have 3-5 themes each, while rides and coasters are lacking. The little positives things I can say about the game are its far easier to build a working coaster and get people to ride them then prior games, building the roller coasters is fun but when ridden first person you see how lumpy the things are even when building them with the button placements apposed to the... what is this called, nurbs... I don't know, I don't like that way to build coasters at all.I don't know whats under the hood of if its fixable but there is no excuse for how badly this game runs. Lets also be clear, I'm no fan of planet coaster and think so many aspects of that game are worse then this one, largely due to me not being creative enough to build custom things that look nice. If you want a roller coaster game, rct2 with the opencrt2 mod, some people love rct3, or the new and possibly best roller coaster game, Parkitect are what you should be looking at, the 2 big hitters (this and planet coaster) rely to much on mods and community to be fun for me... I mean how much worse can I feel when people put crap up with the in game tools and I cant make a single thing look presentable? Its entirely possible this game will turn around, be very optimized and with mods be the best game around... and if it is ill buy it again then, but I'm not holding out hope.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay. When I first made a review for this game, I just did standard criticizing. However, the game has updated since and deserves a fair review, as they have fixed many things. I will break this game up into parts and review each one seperetely.Interface:By interface, I mean the translucent, white bar at the bottom of the screen ingame. It is, well, okay. It gives you what you need, but it does not do it efficently. It seperates rides from rollercoasters, but that is just small nitpick I have. I really hate how stall types are merged into 4 small sections with only 2 being useful. It is okay, but you cannot search for stalls as a whole. There have been many times I have wanted sci-fi/western/normal/adventure theme only and had to look thouroughly to even find the stall itself. In tries to go for a more modern look by making everything unocolored, line drawn icons. It only makes things harder to pick out. It also is inneficent in other ways. In one tab, there is a whole entire area dedicated to facades. It, however, contains barely anything. Instead of trying to make more, they just created a tab of them and put a few dumb things in to make it look complete. Not to mention that I usually go there looking for terrain coloring and clicking on it (because it is a spray can). Maybe I want to look for a roller coaster and click on rides? Though that, itself, is a small issue, it is still ANNOYING and easy to prevent. The interface does have it's pros though. It moved on from RCT3's circle interface that was literally everywhere and hard to navigate across and instead had a normal interface at the bottom of the screen. It also does look nice. I would just rather functionality over design. I give it a 4/10.scenarios:I have to be honest, I hate the new scenarios. I had true fun playing the sceanarios in RCT3. I have no fun with the new scenarios, and I knew I would hate them all when I played the first. Instead of being put in a well established park that has a lot of room for improvement, I was put in a nearly 100% complete park and told to make new stuff with a predefined pathway (yes, I know I could change it if I wanted to) in 12 months. It already had about every resturaunt, and it had no "Discovery" feature that would let me unlock new stuff as time went on. I do like the return of the scenario creator, however. I have no dabbled in it that much yet (I will explain why later), but I love that they have reintroduced one great feature in the series. While I like that scenarios are included and applaud the developers for taking the time to make what would otherwise be a sanbox game into a game that you can actually PLAY for a reason. While I hate the scenarios, I do appreciate the scenario editor and that the developers even added them in. Therefore, I give this feature a 7.5/10sandbox:This is the true reason (and in my opinion one of the only reasons) to buy this game. While limitations do still apply, I still love the ability to be able to create the theme park of my dreams. I have had hours of fun in sandbox mode and have even spent a whole day working on my park at one time. It was a mess, but it was fun. I do, however, not like the restrictions that are applied. I will, however, get into that in a later area. I really do like the sandboxes of othger games better though. This one is good, but it is not the best. It lacks features that those ones have, but it is FUN, and that is what mainly matters. Though this area is short, that is because I really do not have that much negativity for it. Therefore, I give the sandbox mode an 8.5/10. It is mainly good, but I have see better.Items:By items, I mean stalls, decorations, and paths. Let's start out with stalls. I like the new twist on the game by adding buildings as a bigger form of stalls, but I am dissapointed with smaller stalls and am indifferent on the choice to add staff buidlings. The small stalls are pretty bad. There are small things, like ketchup and mustard bottles on sci-fi souveneir stores (which is just outright laziness), but there are alsobig things. I really hate the lack of stall types. There are many, yes, but explain to me why the only small stall that has a drink is the soda stall. That is PURE laziness. It is hard to be creative with stalls when I have already placed every single one in a small park 3 times already. Now, staff buildings are OKAY. It is cool to have a building with workers that makes it where you don't have to spam the hire button, but it makes staff take up so much space. It is outright annoying. Even bathrooms (which are not staff, I know) take up a ton of space. I like the new bathrooms, ya, but the developer's were too lazy to implement the tiny, dirty stalls that is so common in theme parks It is just annoying. I rate this third of this section 4.5/10. I will now be moving onto decoraqtions. Theya re what really spice upthe park, and I have mostly postive words to say about them. They look nice, and even trees are randomized. I will rather be criticizing what is NOT added. There is one big thing missing, buidling materials! How can you make a good aprk when you cannot even add a wall! Parkitect and Planet Coaster do this so well, so why does Roller Coaster Tycoon World fail? Onlt the developer's know. I like the return of UGC and the new addition of using the Workshop to find and apply it easily. I, however, don't like how they are just lifeless statues. In RCT3, I had a poorly made McDonalds stall that actually worked! In RCTW, I have a giant building with incredible detail... that does nothing. Atari really messed up here. I can only hop that they will fix this. I really liek the decorations, but I hate what they don;t have. Therefore, I am giving them a 7/10. Next, we have paths.I have a sort of love hate relationship with the paths. They are good, yes. However, they are such a pain to use! They give them dumb rules, like "You can only expand this path if you delete this one then put it back in the exact same place after you are done." That is so dumb. Curved paths, while being a nice addtion, are impossible to use! I ill struugle and struggle with them,a nd I usyually give up on REGULAR paths! Plus, if you don't use grid or snap, they will be all wonky and off center! They could try to reintroduce path blocks, but I don't think they will. I do, however, really like them with grid/snap. It makes using them so much easier! I just don't like that they are basically required! Because of these mixed views, I give paths a 7/10. Therefore, my overall rating for these 3 are 6.2/10. I wish I could have given them a better rating.Terrain:Terrain sculpting is really nice, but I don't have many words to say about it. The only real things I would change are the lack of the ability to make caves and the fact that I want more terrain colors in the paint tab. I do wish that they fixed placing items of bridges, however. They will just fall through (not when I place them but I literally cannot place them on the path) , and no one ikes that. I give terrain an 8/10.Fun:This game is actually REALLY fun. It is not great to any extent, but I like it. There is not that much more to say besides that it is fun, and that is what makes a game good. I give this an 8.5/10DLC:I liek the DLC, ya. I however wish it added a bit more. We get the classic mascot, 2 new themes, and a gold park entrance on those 2 themes. There is not much in this section because there is not much with DLC! It is good, but it is dissapointing. 7/10FInal Thoughts:Roller Coaster Tycoon World is a good game, but do I recommend it? To be honest, I really want to, but I don't. It just is not good compared to Parkitect and Planet Coaster, the 2 rollercoaster games of 2015-16 I absolutely love. Overall, I give RCTW an 8.1/10.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Game demands a lot out of the cpu, FAR more then the recommended spec, so either the spec is a lie or the game is SERIOUSLY un optimized. This wouldn't be an issue, if the game wasn't delayed so damn long making me believe that it will never get fixed. This is compounded with a shocking lack of content, and questionable time management, as the food stalls have 3-5 themes each, while rides and coasters are lacking. The little positives things I can say about the game are its far easier to build a working coaster and get people to ride them then prior games, building the roller coasters is fun but when ridden first person you see how lumpy the things are even when building them with the button placements apposed to the... what is this called, nurbs... I don't know, I don't like that way to build coasters at all.I don't know whats under the hood of if its fixable but there is no excuse for how badly this game runs. Lets also be clear, I'm no fan of planet coaster and think so many aspects of that game are worse then this one, largely due to me not being creative enough to build custom things that look nice. If you want a roller coaster game, rct2 with the opencrt2 mod, some people love rct3, or the new and possibly best roller coaster game, Parkitect are what you should be looking at, the 2 big hitters (this and planet coaster) rely to much on mods and community to be fun for me... I mean how much worse can I feel when people put crap up with the in game tools and I cant make a single thing look presentable? Its entirely possible this game will turn around, be very optimized and with mods be the best game around... and if it is ill buy it again then, but I'm not holding out hope.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay. When I first made a review for this game, I just did standard criticizing. However, the game has updated since and deserves a fair review, as they have fixed many things. I will break this game up into parts and review each one seperetely.Interface:By interface, I mean the translucent, white bar at the bottom of the screen ingame. It is, well, okay. It gives you what you need, but it does not do it efficently. It seperates rides from rollercoasters, but that is just small nitpick I have. I really hate how stall types are merged into 4 small sections with only 2 being useful. It is okay, but you cannot search for stalls as a whole. There have been many times I have wanted sci-fi/western/normal/adventure theme only and had to look thouroughly to even find the stall itself. In tries to go for a more modern look by making everything unocolored, line drawn icons. It only makes things harder to pick out. It also is inneficent in other ways. In one tab, there is a whole entire area dedicated to facades. It, however, contains barely anything. Instead of trying to make more, they just created a tab of them and put a few dumb things in to make it look complete. Not to mention that I usually go there looking for terrain coloring and clicking on it (because it is a spray can). Maybe I want to look for a roller coaster and click on rides? Though that, itself, is a small issue, it is still ANNOYING and easy to prevent. The interface does have it's pros though. It moved on from RCT3's circle interface that was literally everywhere and hard to navigate across and instead had a normal interface at the bottom of the screen. It also does look nice. I would just rather functionality over design. I give it a 4/10.scenarios:I have to be honest, I hate the new scenarios. I had true fun playing the sceanarios in RCT3. I have no fun with the new scenarios, and I knew I would hate them all when I played the first. Instead of being put in a well established park that has a lot of room for improvement, I was put in a nearly 100% complete park and told to make new stuff with a predefined pathway (yes, I know I could change it if I wanted to) in 12 months. It already had about every resturaunt, and it had no "Discovery" feature that would let me unlock new stuff as time went on. I do like the return of the scenario creator, however. I have no dabbled in it that much yet (I will explain why later), but I love that they have reintroduced one great feature in the series. While I like that scenarios are included and applaud the developers for taking the time to make what would otherwise be a sanbox game into a game that you can actually PLAY for a reason. While I hate the scenarios, I do appreciate the scenario editor and that the developers even added them in. Therefore, I give this feature a 7.5/10sandbox:This is the true reason (and in my opinion one of the only reasons) to buy this game. While limitations do still apply, I still love the ability to be able to create the theme park of my dreams. I have had hours of fun in sandbox mode and have even spent a whole day working on my park at one time. It was a mess, but it was fun. I do, however, not like the restrictions that are applied. I will, however, get into that in a later area. I really do like the sandboxes of othger games better though. This one is good, but it is not the best. It lacks features that those ones have, but it is FUN, and that is what mainly matters. Though this area is short, that is because I really do not have that much negativity for it. Therefore, I give the sandbox mode an 8.5/10. It is mainly good, but I have see better.Items:By items, I mean stalls, decorations, and paths. Let's start out with stalls. I like the new twist on the game by adding buildings as a bigger form of stalls, but I am dissapointed with smaller stalls and am indifferent on the choice to add staff buidlings. The small stalls are pretty bad. There are small things, like ketchup and mustard bottles on sci-fi souveneir stores (which is just outright laziness), but there are alsobig things. I really hate the lack of stall types. There are many, yes, but explain to me why the only small stall that has a drink is the soda stall. That is PURE laziness. It is hard to be creative with stalls when I have already placed every single one in a small park 3 times already. Now, staff buildings are OKAY. It is cool to have a building with workers that makes it where you don't have to spam the hire button, but it makes staff take up so much space. It is outright annoying. Even bathrooms (which are not staff, I know) take up a ton of space. I like the new bathrooms, ya, but the developer's were too lazy to implement the tiny, dirty stalls that is so common in theme parks It is just annoying. I rate this third of this section 4.5/10. I will now be moving onto decoraqtions. Theya re what really spice upthe park, and I have mostly postive words to say about them. They look nice, and even trees are randomized. I will rather be criticizing what is NOT added. There is one big thing missing, buidling materials! How can you make a good aprk when you cannot even add a wall! Parkitect and Planet Coaster do this so well, so why does Roller Coaster Tycoon World fail? Onlt the developer's know. I like the return of UGC and the new addition of using the Workshop to find and apply it easily. I, however, don't like how they are just lifeless statues. In RCT3, I had a poorly made McDonalds stall that actually worked! In RCTW, I have a giant building with incredible detail... that does nothing. Atari really messed up here. I can only hop that they will fix this. I really liek the decorations, but I hate what they don;t have. Therefore, I am giving them a 7/10. Next, we have paths.I have a sort of love hate relationship with the paths. They are good, yes. However, they are such a pain to use! They give them dumb rules, like "You can only expand this path if you delete this one then put it back in the exact same place after you are done." That is so dumb. Curved paths, while being a nice addtion, are impossible to use! I ill struugle and struggle with them,a nd I usyually give up on REGULAR paths! Plus, if you don't use grid or snap, they will be all wonky and off center! They could try to reintroduce path blocks, but I don't think they will. I do, however, really like them with grid/snap. It makes using them so much easier! I just don't like that they are basically required! Because of these mixed views, I give paths a 7/10. Therefore, my overall rating for these 3 are 6.2/10. I wish I could have given them a better rating.Terrain:Terrain sculpting is really nice, but I don't have many words to say about it. The only real things I would change are the lack of the ability to make caves and the fact that I want more terrain colors in the paint tab. I do wish that they fixed placing items of bridges, however. They will just fall through (not when I place them but I literally cannot place them on the path) , and no one ikes that. I give terrain an 8/10.Fun:This game is actually REALLY fun. It is not great to any extent, but I like it. There is not that much more to say besides that it is fun, and that is what makes a game good. I give this an 8.5/10DLC:I liek the DLC, ya. I however wish it added a bit more. We get the classic mascot, 2 new themes, and a gold park entrance on those 2 themes. There is not much in this section because there is not much with DLC! It is good, but it is dissapointing. 7/10FInal Thoughts:Roller Coaster Tycoon World is a good game, but do I recommend it? To be honest, I really want to, but I don't. It just is not good compared to Parkitect and Planet Coaster, the 2 rollercoaster games of 2015-16 I absolutely love. Overall, I give RCTW an 8.1/10.

								Although still in the early stages of the build, it is nice to look at but I don't find the graphics very much different than 3.  However, it is an improvement in the way it looks. content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												The game is very buggy and it will crash a lot. But remember this is the first beta weekend and we are 2 months away from release. They still have time to bug fix.The coaster creation has a very big learning curve because the game takes physics into account. Your coaster will not be able to make sharp hairpin curves, you need to bank your turns, slow the coaster down if its doing 90mph in a turn. This is why people are having issues and why it has such a higher learning curve than the other games. They should give you the option of the current system and the original piece by piece for the inpatient.Content in the game has all but been locked out for the current beta, because they want feedback on the coaster creation system. If you are patient and enjoyed the older games, then yes I reccomend this game, I loved the wild designs I created in my coasters. But again, it has a learning curve, do not expect to just jump right in and make a great coaster, physics, speed, gravity are now factored in, you are not going to make a turn if your coaster is flying at 100+mph.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. RCT3 had been such a hit for me, and I have and still do enjoy it. I really wanted this game (RCTW) to continue this fantastic franchise - and so, I bought it. Sure, it has it's positives here and there, yet the majority of the game is negative. I do not recommend this game - however I do believe that with a long, hard revamp there might still be some potential in it. Why?Mainly because the few positives are excellently done. The coaster builder itself is fantastic, completely customizable and it the coasters look great too! If the game was redesigned I sincerely hope that this is one aspect of the game they keep, as I can tell some real thought has gone into it. The physics engine is also decent and does complement the coaster builder well. In my opinion the customizability of this coaster builder and the features of the coaster builder are far more advanced then the current state of Planet Coaster's rollercoaster designer.However, the rest of the game is seriously lagging behind when compared to Frontier's Planet Coaster. The framerate is TERRIBLE. I have many games with much better graphics that RCTW and yet they can achieve up to 6 times the framerate I get here - i've never exceeded 10fps in RCTW while I mantain roughly 50fps in Planet Coaster. Graphics - even on the highest setting - struggle to compete in appearance with Planet Coaster's "medium-low". The peeps look like they were designed by 8 year-olds and there is no real variation in them. When zoomed out the peeps glide along the ground and ARE NOT ANIMATED! The number of original coaster types in Planet Coaster also seems more realistic, while Planet Coaster's scenery options and variation beats RCTW by a long way. The main menu of RCTW is disgusting, as is the User Interface.This game needs an urgent, complete revamp. In that unlikely scenario, I'll consider changing my review.Until then?Buy Planet Coaster. It's so much better - and probably what you were actually looking for.

Posted: April 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								I am a big fan of RCT1 and 2 with all expansions they made. In fact RCT 1 was the best. So many levels you can play with different goals and lovly created maps. You really can see how much love the developers sent to RCT 1 and 2. But after RCT 3 was released it wasn't mine at all. The gameplay wasn't the focus anymore. Instead the graphics and the possibilties to drive your coasters were gone to be focused. But there were no lovely levels at all anymore.... So far to the old ones....Now to RCT W: This game, in fact, is nice to watch. The graphics are very well created and animated.... but that's, by far, is all I can review positve at all.I mean, you have to know it's still an Early-Access so it's still under development. But: There are so many bugs that the game is still unplayable. The service personals are stuck on roads. They neither move nor do their work. Some functions told in tips can't be used, e.g. the service personal's route. You can't change or even select anythin like this.The placement of roads, coasters and buildings are terrible. You made a road and cross it with another. Then, because of the crossing point, you aren't even able to put bins or banks onto the roads or lanterns.... Banks, bins or anything like these are small tiles which cannot be placed on a big road because another is crossing it... there is a big place you cannot build onto... Hope they fix it...People's movement is broken. They do not walk over the raods, they are flying over it when you scroll out of the map.The pathfinding is better then in RCT 1 where people run completly random on the raods. Here they take the way they want to get the coaster of their choice. But the movement is still buggy and broken...And at least, to make it more funny... I only have a notebook with notebok graphics... but it is still a GTX980M. One of the heigher graphic cards.... and After each building and attraction my framerate drops little lower... I begin this game with 60 FPS. After 3 Coasters and several other attractions my frames cannot climb over 21 per seconds.... That's not normal... I have tested different maps and coaster types and everytime the same issues... Building more attractions decrease FPS. Seems that the graphic is rendering everything in the park even if you are not focusing the attraction in the active window.... And by that: The game is using 3 GB RAM (active) and the cpu-usage ist too damned high... Even a mondern shooter or anything like that is not using more 20% of cpu  (got a Intel core i7-4720 HQ) but this game is using up to 70%... I do not know whether the cpu is supporting the graphics and whether the graphics are made within the cpu... but at this level with all this bugs and mistakes and mismakes... the game isn't worth to be bought... And never worth to be bought at this price...I will look forwards for updates and may update this review when updates make it better... otherwise I won't spend any time at all in wrinting for this game... Seems that I need to look closer to planet coaster too :/Chris Sawyer.... please come back and rescue this amazing game you made early we all loved

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. RCT3 had been such a hit for me, and I have and still do enjoy it. I really wanted this game (RCTW) to continue this fantastic franchise - and so, I bought it. Sure, it has it's positives here and there, yet the majority of the game is negative. I do not recommend this game - however I do believe that with a long, hard revamp there might still be some potential in it. Why?Mainly because the few positives are excellently done. The coaster builder itself is fantastic, completely customizable and it the coasters look great too! If the game was redesigned I sincerely hope that this is one aspect of the game they keep, as I can tell some real thought has gone into it. The physics engine is also decent and does complement the coaster builder well. In my opinion the customizability of this coaster builder and the features of the coaster builder are far more advanced then the current state of Planet Coaster's rollercoaster designer.However, the rest of the game is seriously lagging behind when compared to Frontier's Planet Coaster. The framerate is TERRIBLE. I have many games with much better graphics that RCTW and yet they can achieve up to 6 times the framerate I get here - i've never exceeded 10fps in RCTW while I mantain roughly 50fps in Planet Coaster. Graphics - even on the highest setting - struggle to compete in appearance with Planet Coaster's "medium-low". The peeps look like they were designed by 8 year-olds and there is no real variation in them. When zoomed out the peeps glide along the ground and ARE NOT ANIMATED! The number of original coaster types in Planet Coaster also seems more realistic, while Planet Coaster's scenery options and variation beats RCTW by a long way. The main menu of RCTW is disgusting, as is the User Interface.This game needs an urgent, complete revamp. In that unlikely scenario, I'll consider changing my review.Until then?Buy Planet Coaster. It's so much better - and probably what you were actually looking for.

Early Access Review
								I would not recomend this game, the main reasons being that A: it has no modular building system (so a heck of a lot of creativity and freedom lost), B: the graphics are pretty appalling and un-optimised (i guess there's only so much quality you can get in unity) and lastly C: the price is way too high for what you actually get, when Planet Coaster is selling for £19.99, (in my opinon the better one of the main two AND you get more with it...) it is a no brainer to go Frontier's way.In conclusion, if you want something that pushes your creativity and allows you to freely build the park you wan't, this game is definiltey not for you. Just either pre-order Planet Coaster and save £10 or wait till the full release and get it for thirty. Don't buy this, you will regret it.  2/10

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played and loved the RollerCoaster Tycoon games for years. Unfortunately I do have to agree with a lot of the negative reviews.The game is nowhere near ready. It's poorly optimized, very buggy and is missing important features. But on saying that it is a early access game so I didn't expect it to be perfect.I love building rollercoasters, I never used pre made coasters in RCT3 and I don't plan to in this either but after 2 hours of trying to build a coaster I gave up because you have to mess about with to many things just to get the right angle on the track. I do like the fact that there are more options in coaster building but I think they took it slightly to far.A few things I want to see in the game is a 'basic' and 'advanced' option on coaster building, basic being the same as RCT3. Edge scrolling is a must for me to, I hate having to move the camera around with the keyboard all the time. Bulldozing is annoying to as you can only delete a single thing at a time so if you have a load of trees, plants or scenery you want to get rid of it takes ages! They need to add a click and drag system to delete multiple things at once and when placing objects and rides, auto delete trees and plants that are in the way.I could go on but at the moment I can't recommend buying this game. The devs are saying they are working hard on the game but it isn't getting many updates yet.I really hope they get this game right in the end but its looking like 2 or 3 months before I can make a final decision.
