number of helpful: 51 of 102 people (50%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This is the same review as i posted on the RCTW forums. So it might not be fitting for a steam review. TL:DR at the endI want to say at first that i am a HUGE RCT fan.I played RCT1 when i was like 7 and i loved the francise ever since. Even RCT3 which alot of people dislike i found still amazing.Now the the World Beta.The graphics are really good i have to admit. But come on. No graphical options?? Are you serious? Not even sound?I literally threw my headphone off when i launched the game. How can you give us a beta without these small options. I was lucky enough that i could turn off AA and such in Nvidia options. But i still got around 40-50fps with NOTHING in the park. I will post my specs and the end of the thread.Another thing is the RAM usage. I hope this improves because 5-6gigs of RAM when you only launch a game that is in a beta state is pretty bad.Now to the game itself.The scenery is pretty good. Just where are the custom buildings that you make wall by wall? I reckon they will be in the full beta but if they are build the same as fences it will be a living hell to make a decent building. The fences are SO bad to place. You cant make a decent fence unless with the grid. But with the grid you cant place em next to curve pathes. And no end pieces. Your fences end with an open spot.Pathes are good. Nothing wrong with them. Easy to place easy to use. Though a few options of queue pathes? Must be intentional i guess but still. And no curved queues? Why is that?All the foliage is really well done. Bit few options on shrubs and flowers but that will probably change on full release with the workshop. Trees are fine in my opinion. More palm trees would be nice though.All the other path addons are fine. Trash cans, lights etc. They look good, are good to place and nothing wrong with that.Now to the coastersFirst off all, the color options are so low. Where is the create every color palet?? You would expect a game from 2015 to have atleast a color palet that lets you make the colors yourself? (Red, Green, Blue sliders from 0-225 or something)I guess this will be better at release although i dont have my hopes up for that.Now to the building of the coaster.Its awfull. Dont get me wrong here. Controls are pretty good. The way you control how you edit the coaster with your mousewheel etc. works good. A few bugs here and there like a coaster has 0degrees roll and is still banked. And a few other small things which i know for sure have been reported already. If not i will report them later in the bug tracker.The spline based building (without the grid) is not working at all. Atleast not for me. You cannot make a good lifthill without the hill being a little bit off to the left or right. Which is very unrealistic since lift hills are perfectly straight. Then there is the marker under the track that shows how "Safe" the coaster is. Its not accurate at all. How is a left turn that is banked inwards safer than one banking outwards?? How seriously dont understand how that works. Maybe i am just stupid and dont know at all how coasters work at about 5000+ hours across all the three previous games and after visiting alot of real life coaster. But for me this is wrong.You added the ability to edit the coaster on the spot itself where there is need of adjustments so you dont have to remove the whole track. It sucks. The moment you add a new edit point (the green bulb) you have it locked to your mouse immedietly. The track instantly goes up or down a little and you have a little bump in it. No matter how i try it keeps happening. I might not be used to it yet but after about a 100 times i think i should've known how if there was a way to do it right.There is no real way to make a good looping are any other element. Sure you can let someone else make it for you, download it from the workshop and add it in your coaster. But what is the fun in that. I want to make them myself. Its just SO hard to finetune the track pieces because of the issue above (the green bulb issue).Since when are block brakes wheeles? Seriously guys. Where you drinking to much whisky that evening? You have normal brakes that look like brakes. And block brakes are wheels. Also, the Accelerator Coaster doesnt have a launch track. Only the tiny piece at the start that you cant drag out so why even conisder putting it in the beta? Same for the Dive Coaster, there is no Dive element (the Holding Brake). So why add this one aswell? And where is the normal B&M Sitdown. You add all these unique coaster types (Wing, Accelerator, Dive) But you forget the most basic one. A Hyper Coaster doesn't make inversions. I reckon its not that hard to think about that. And that while you guys even cooperated with Six Flags.TL:DRThis game needs ALOT of work. And to much to be do-able in 40 days. This game needs so much work it probably needs to around end Q1 2016. Buggy (i know its a beta but to much stuff isnt working correctly), bad coaster builder. The grid system back in RCT1-3 was SO much better. There werent many options to tracks as there are now for sure. But they worked perfectly and were always right. The overall game as it stands now is awfull. As it is now i wish i didnt buy it and instead bought Anno 2205 or Planet Coaster as Anno will never fail and Planet Coaster is cheaper and as far as dev blogs go really promising. I hope you guys (the devs and forum users) understand my frustration about the game in the current manner and hope that my feedback will be taken into consideration because you have atleast one sad costumer as of right now. As i stated earlier i love the RCT francise and was so excited for this game. Its just bad as it is.Greets,Azrail

number of helpful: 30 of 60 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
Early Access Review
I have updated this review with content relating to the Early Access release. It is following the beta weekend review.BETA WEEKEND 1What do I think of Roller Coaster Tycoon World? I was hoping it would be great and wow everyone, but this game is never going to be ready by the posted release date, if the roller coaster module is anything to go by. In attempting to build a wooden roller coaster (simple enough, right?) I never once was able to complete a circuit with the train. The physics engine in this is horrible, and if I try to make a tight turn with banking, the only think i ever see is 'SLOPE TOO STEEP'. I think I hate this game. Absolutely hate it. I know the devs are desparate to make some money on this, but this game is not okay. Unless the second beta is better, I'm going to be one of many thousands who return their pre-release orders.SO MANY DERAILMENTS!!! (literaly)Early Access: Day 1In my first experience with the now long-term beta of this game, I must say it's really in need of optimizations. As of right now, this game is still not ready for a full release (thank goodness they went EA if they HAD to release it now, but they could have waited...). So, how has the fourth installment of the Roller Coaster Tycoon franchise fared? Not as well as I'd hoped.The GraphicsThey're not bad, but they're not good either. Visually, they're very pleasing. However, the peeps are flat skins (clothing is not a separate layer) which is disillusioning. In addition, the feel of the ride textures leave the tiniest bit of nagging that something's missing. Overall, though, the graphics are actually very good to look at. BUT, good luck getting a good framerate even with a Titan. The game set my settings on high and I run a GTX 970. There is 1 setting above that which a single GTX 980 or Titan should be capable of running at 60 fps. For the graphics, to be honest, I'm surprised my computer couldn't run 60 fps.There is a plus, though. Since the devs know framerate is bad, they went and added a tickbox that reduces the graphics demand in favor of a more playable framerate, so that you almost never dip below 20 fps. Almost. When building new things in a park that already is a bit crowded, you can dip down all the way to the 1-3 fps region.GameplayWell, it definitely feels like a more open and controllable world than previous RCT games. Because nothing is stuck to the grid, a whole new variety of layout options become available. That said, because of the size of the park, a whole lot of creativity has been thrown out the window. It would take dozens of this park to fill the parks you built in RCT 1-3. This park is only big enough to house 1 large coaster or 2 smaller ones (what the ♥♥♥♥, right?), in addition to your arsenal of small rides needed to keep the less extreme peeps happy. Speaking of those peeps, the way they scream when on a ride is all at once, so you just have an occasional scream that hurts your ears instead of constant enjoyment from your peeps.Building ToolsThe path and stall building tools are fairly intuitive. With the freeform option, you draw in any direction you like. With the grid turned on, you can keep everything aligned to a coordinate system (perpendicular and parallel to the park entrance, mind you). With snap turned on (this will turn off grid, and vice versa), you can place your paths at 90 degree angles to each other, even if they're not on the grid angle. It also allows for a few other things, like placing stalls directly onto existing paths, and more controllably placing trees and other objects adjacent to paths. All in all, having the three building modes is very useful, but I would like a localized grid aligned with a path I just drew if I had both grid and snap enabled. That would be very useful.Specific Building Tools:The path building tool - While this tool is great for building paths on the ground, you don't have nearly enough control with the path height. The only interval for heigh is 7 feet, which is too much, especially given the small spacing the grid has.The Flat Ride Building Tool - Well, it's just placement and angle rotation. On the other hand, unlike in previous RCT games, you can't choose the locations for the entrance and exit to the ride, which was part of how we were able to tightly pack tons of rides into a small space in the last games. And given how much smaller this game's parks are, we really need as much control of the arrangement as possible.Roller Coaster Building Tool - The roller coaster building tool really isn't bad anymore. Unlike in the beta weekend, coasters no longer crash for no reason, and the tool is relatively intuitive. That said, the station platforms are very sparse in selection and have MASSIVE footprints. There's already a significant queue and a horrendously long exit walk for every single station platform. And you can't pick where the entrance and/or exit come from, or the direction of the train. Also, track banking doesn't actually listen to what you say. For example, if I have a tight turn on an incline with steep banking, the track is actually rendered as flat and level. Decrease the banking, and the track banks outward (why?). Most of the time, using the building tools is fairly intutive. You have pre-built segments that you can adjust the scale of, or you can click on the ground away from nodes and build your own track. Working with nodes is intutive, but not getting to node mode. If you make a mistake, I have no clue how to abort the new piece without quitting the editor entirely. But on the plus side, you can create and delete nodes in the middle of the track without disconnecting it all. Overall, it still needs a bit of work, but coasters don't crash for no reason, and using it is largely intutive.ConclusionThis game is labeled appropriately as something that's in Early Access. It's glitchy somewhat, and some of the controls don't feel quite finished. That said, there are other problems with this game. Flat rides don't have configurable exits, roller coaster stations are massive and just as unconfigurable (and lacking in variety), and the park size is WAY TOO ♥♥♥♥ING TINY! Will Atari and Nvizzio Creations pull it all together? Maybe. I wouldn't put any money on it happening this year. I would LOVE for them to pull it together and give us something amazing as though they've been holding out, but it really doesn't seem like RCT is on top any more. Planet Coaster, even being in alpha, is already incredibly customizable, allowing for every building to be custom made, a huge park size, and lots more detail. On top of that they're the brains behind RCT3 who did a very good job for the first 3D implementation of the series(no offense, Nvizzio). I expect a lot more from Planet Coaster in the near and far future than I do from Roller Coaster Tycoon World. For now, I'm getting my refund.

												I was very excited to get my hands on the beta for Rollercoaster Tycoon World, being a fan of the series since RCT2 when I was a kid. However, the beta has shown that the game is definitely not ready. (From 60 to 10-15)The game eats RAM like it's candy.In conclusion; I know it's a beta, and I know the game has tons of potential, but with the release date being right around the corner, I feel like it's going to either get delayed to 2016 or have a crappy launch. I really wish the game becomes the RCT of my dreams.

Early Access Review
								It's early access, so I tried to be open minded, but the game is really bad. The roller coasters are trickier to make, and they are full of bugs. It lacks charm, or any of the draw of its predecessors. The pathway tools are incredibly frustrating. What features there are, are incredibly limited, even giving it the benefit of the doubt of its early access status. The game never crashed for me, but the gameplay itself is at best glitchy, and at worst, they make the game unplayable. Taking into consideration the repeated times the game was pushed back for release and its steep price, I can say with all confidence that even one after more glitches have been cleared, it is not a game worth buying.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Despite all the negative feedback, this game really isn't that bad. It offers a lot of content for an Early Access Game. More than some AAA-titles these days. I'm also a fan of their spline-based coaster editor. Once you learn how it works you can build any shape with it. The graphics are mediocre but that's okay for me.There might be some performance issues and bugs but I'm sure they'll fix that.Keep it up Nvizzio!EDIT: About a year later the game still doesn't run great. It definitly got better but it's just not enough. So that's a bummer. They improved the graphics, fixed some issues and added more content though. The workshop is a nice addition too. I guess I'll try it again next year. I'm still confident that Nvizzio manage it at some point, but I doubt that the game will recover from its negative reviews.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is fun and all. But after playing it from release, it kind of left a sour taste in my mouth. I understand the early access blah blah blah. But still. I hope to get back into it when they finalize the game. I'll see where they end up and compare it to how it was when I first played it. I havn't played this game since april. And I only have 4 hours total on it. We'll see how my view changes when they finish the game, if they do, and then I'll be able to give a better review. I love the Roller Coaster Tycoon series, this one just doesn't bring home the bacon just yet. One complaint I have so far is the way you assign staff.... In previous games, you bought staff people one at a time. Now You have to build a building that has a set number of staff members in it. I dislike this option. It takes up a lot of space. I understand a break room, and that can be arranged but, building multiple staff buildings is really annoying. Hopefully someone will see this and consider another way to change how we buy staff.I do recommend this game, as I feel it will have the potential when its finished, but that being said, I don't currently play it at the moment. I may get back into it some day. It just doesn't have the vibe I remember getting back from rollercoaster tycoon 2.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Was looking forward to the end of EA, but I have to say this game is up to now a disappointment. The things that annoy me the most are:-	The visitors of the park are not animated but slide across the field if you zoom out-	The graphics are OK for a game like this, I do not expect much here but the problem is the inconsistency of the framerate. Sometimes the counter fluctuates for no obvious reason at all giving an overall leggy experience-	That I am not allowed to place the entrances and exits of my rides -	Building paths is sometimes extremely annoying because the paths will connect to each other only at certain positions leaving you at time with a very crooked layout -	The huge size of the rollercoaster entrance stations-	Micro managing the staff by building staff support buildings.In the end I would not recommend this game to anyone except for those more interested in landscaping or modelling because the tools to create and design parks are quite good once you get a hang for it. Except for the pathway system which I do not like at all.

Early Access Review
								Absolutely terrible. I pre-ordered it for a full-game, not this early access nonsense. Unfortunately I pre-ordered off Steam so I can not get a refund. Fortunately I only paid a fraction of the cost and even at ~$20 this is a complete waste of money. I pre-ordered back in January before any mention of going early access. No way I would have gone through with that had I know they'd pull this stunt at the last minute. I just feel I got taken advantage of. The game is completely broken. Even with my GTX 980/i5 4670k and modest medium settings the game suffered FPS dramatically and dipped into the 20's. I played for about an hour, did multiple restarts and new games and I was never able to build a roller coaster. I was able to build buildings and such but after I rebooted the game I could no longer build any buildings. I kept getting spam notifications to "BUILD MORE LIGHTS YOUR PARK IS DARK!" well guess what? Couldn't even access the scenery builder. I just.. I can't even fathom this. Wow.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Amid the rampant negativity surrounding this game, I feel compelled to give this game a glowing recommendation. WHen Early Access finally became available, and the flood gate of negative reviews opened, I was nervous and held off on buying the game until a few days ago. When I did, I was acutally quite shocked at how much hate the game was wtill recieving, because my experience was nowhere near as horrible or even remotely bad as so many people have warned in the reviews. In fact, my partner has Planet Coaster, and he actually plays this game more than he does that one, and swears it is better in nearly every way.The game is not finished, and understanding this is paramount if you are even remotely going to enjoy playing. If occational glitches and crashes is a problem for you, then DO NOT BUY THE GAME. Too many people marring the reputation of this excellent game because of their own unachievable expectations of a game in Alpha. That said, it is still very much the RCT that I love and remember fondly, with a fresh coat of paint and a vast majority of new features, both experiemental and not. It's updated often, and the developers genuinely do want to make this as excellent as they say. So if you can spare your patience, and would like to see the evolution of this game, do yourself a favor, because I was skeptical as well, but I feel it was worth it. I'm even considering upgrading to deluxe. If you don't have patience for crashes and bugs (yes, the game has crashed on me twice), then wait until it's out of Early Access.

												Okay, as a huge fan of the previous games there is a massive gap between old rct and new rct. If you were a fan of old rct do not buy this game. That's the early TL:DR.Here are the likes1. Terrain and water editor is nice2. music isn't bad3. more coaster editor customizationand dislikes1. coaster editor is far too complex for average user, even above average users. See below for more details.2. takes way too long to load sandbox mode. SANDBOX MODE!3. can't right click to delete things such as pathways4. MUST move camera with arrow keys, no more mouse movement5. None of the coaster styles have relevant pictures to determine what they are, only stick figure sillouhetes.6. you don't have a setting to remove cars from your trains. To add you simply click on where the extra cars should be7. Terrain editor wont change the already existing support height leaving terrain indents that are quite ugly8. Scenery isn't separated by group anymore. Oregon Trail Wagons apparently fit in with UFO's and pumpkins.Here is my report of my experience on coastercrazy.com's forum skype chat regarding the game:- alright rctw gimme what you got- the music reminds me of a mix between sims 3 and a merry go round- really not sure why a sandbox mode took MY $3000 custom build 2 minutes to load- why can't I right click to delete things?- can't move the camera with mouse apparently even with the highly unnecessary "move tool". you need to use the arrow keys, something never needed before. WHAT AN AWESOME NEW FEATUJRE GUISE! [/sarcasm]- None of the coaster styles have relevant pictures to determine what they are, only stick figure sillouhetes.- wow the coaster editor... take everything you knew about rct and throw it out the window.- make a kiddie coaster. A good looking kiddie coaster. What was a 3 minute build is now 15 minutes.- this coaster editor is way too complex for any casual or even a step above that user- it's so customizable but that doesn't mean better. Sure it'll be able to make somewhat realistic coasters even WITHOUT A STRAIGHT TRACK SETTING AT ALL but it won't be recieved well by anyone that wants a casual non stressful experience.- as far as track is concerned imagine a spline editor that automatically detects radius- they took a simple game idea and added infinitely more steps- on the bright side making death coasters is way easier- For extra ride settings, you don't have a setting to remove cars from your trains. To add you simply click on where the extra cars should be. - THIS IS NOT ROLLER COASTER TYCOON!- I love this new terrain editor I do but it wont change the already existing support height leaving terrain indents that are quite ugly.- The water tool works very well and something I really like.- Scenery isn't separated by group anymore. Oregon Trail Wagons apparently fit in with UFO's and pumpkins.- Overall a very sub par experience, definitely should not be named under roller coaster tycoon.

Posted: April 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Absolutely terrible. I pre-ordered it for a full-game, not this early access nonsense. Unfortunately I pre-ordered off Steam so I can not get a refund. Fortunately I only paid a fraction of the cost and even at ~$20 this is a complete waste of money. I pre-ordered back in January before any mention of going early access. No way I would have gone through with that had I know they'd pull this stunt at the last minute. I just feel I got taken advantage of. The game is completely broken. Even with my GTX 980/i5 4670k and modest medium settings the game suffered FPS dramatically and dipped into the 20's. I played for about an hour, did multiple restarts and new games and I was never able to build a roller coaster. I was able to build buildings and such but after I rebooted the game I could no longer build any buildings. I kept getting spam notifications to "BUILD MORE LIGHTS YOUR PARK IS DARK!" well guess what? Couldn't even access the scenery builder. I just.. I can't even fathom this. Wow.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												 I was so excited to finally get my hands on the new coaster builder but once I actually started using it I was extremely disappointed. The coaster builder did not seem to want to follow what little instructions the game provided. When I told the game to make the track go straight up, it made a loop. When I changed the incline so it would not loop it twisted the track in the process. When I tried to tried to move my cursor to straight out the track it made the track appear on the other side of the map. Then when I tested the failure of a track the new trains kept crashing into the old trains that would not go away. That little piece is beside the point. The point of the weekend one beta according to their FAQ was to show off the new coaster builder. It says on their FAQs that all of the possible coasters are unlocked. I put in my request for a refund because the coaster building tool is so bad that I will have to wait for reviews on the game's coaster builder before re-purchasing this game. The developers themselves have already promised updates after release and based on how poor the coaster builder is right now I do not feel like paying for a "beta" on release waiting for the developers to fix later what they should have done right the first time.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								So, before I start with my review, I want to clear up one thing that many people who gave this game a negative view missed: YOU CAN EXTEND THE SIZE OF YOUR PARK IN THE SAME FASHION AS YOU CAN EXTEND YOUR CITY IN CITIES SKYLINES. Now that's all cleared up, lets continue. Okay, so there's only 2 problems I have found so far; 1: The game isn't fantastically optimised, but is still more than playable at medium settings. 2: The roller coaster manual builder is quite tricky to get the hang of initally (however after a couple of goes, it's really easy to understand). Aside from that, the game is absolutely amazing, I've been on it for 4 hours straight so far and I'm loving every minute of it, I can't wait to see what workshop content will bring and how much the game will improve over time! So far it gets a 9/10.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												At this time, I could not recommend this game to anyone. I'll change this review later if the game redeems itself, but for now, there's just too much to be disappointed with. This is currently not looking to be the fun the first three games were.First off, the coaster editor.Yes, it's a spline based system which means more flexibility in how you can design your coaster, but it also means more weirdness. I've had issues where a stright, flat, non-banked piece of track gives me the error "Curve too steep", and similar issues with a gigantic turn (probably at least 150 feet in radius) giving me the same error with little to no banking. After I figured out a few of the quirks I was finally able to build a coaster, but that took almost the full half hour I played.Second, the actual coaster operation.Say you manage to actually complete your coaster. Now it's time to test it. Which, by the way, you can't do while paused. Perhaps it'll crash into one of the nodes mysteriously left by the editor that didn't get removed. All right, it's a beta, weird things happen. Next run, it'll pass through it just fine, only to clip into the track and crash a bit before the station. Next run, it'll crash into the *other* node left by the editor. Finally, we get a run that succeeds.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having been a Rollercoaster Tycoon fan since the game first arrived in 1999.I remmeber the weeks leading up to it they had it at virgin Records in their game department. The thrill of that game still excites me, even 2 and 3 are designed the same as the Original Game. This however is not, atleast not yet. The game is still an Early Release, that being said its just a slight step above being termed a official beta. There is alot of good aspects to this game, the coaster design system being one major possitive note. The major negavitve atm would prob have to be the pathing system, its not as clear as 1-3 was, however you can make diaganal paths which i dont recall being able to back then. So for paths its a improvement that just needs further mechanics to par with the mechanics of either previous gens of RCT or just something all together more modern. The game will take alittle adjusting to if/when compared to previous versions. While alot of people have given it a bad review and i could imagine asked for a refund, I am not going to do that. I will admit i did consider it. I also know as the improvements get implemented I would want to play it again and rebuy it. I also would like to see firsthand the improvements and modifications to a series I grew up enjoying. In the end my review might not be the most helpful because while i give the game a thumbs up, it is a early release and I could respect peoples opion to not like the game. But those of you who grew up with this series like I did might find a appreciation in seeing its future unfold.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Review is for 3/30/2016 Early AcessUm, no more like early beta. Need more maint, cleaner and medic buildings than rides. Entertainers ...don't entertain. Number of cars are locked to 1 on coasters. Scenery is bland and will be quickly workshop replaced by real talent. Footprint of smaller rides dispropotional. Peeps are generic and very repetitive. Google 'amusement park crowd' and click images, that is what peeps should look like. Hungry peeps will only eat at their preferred food stand so you have to place 5 food stands that are bigger than some rides everywhere to feed the puke piles at the end of every ride, yes every ride including a slide. Cotten candy, ice cream, sno cones are all great shops, but not in this game, just a one sweets vendor, yet 5 different food types, lol. In november they handed us a turd, we handed it back. Now it is still a turd with sugar poured on it, but it still tastes like a turd. On the plus side they seemed to have improved the coaster builder, but that is all that was fixed. No billboards generic or custom. No custom music. Tiles look like 80's sidescroller tiles. Other sim games from 2006 did better at tiles than this one.Finally would I recommend....um NO! Still early beta, wait a few years for the community to fix.Review is for 11/1/2015 BetaPhysics are severely broken. Coaster works fine in test, then kills everyone on first hill. Coaster cars from failed runs lay on ground or track preventing modification or testing. old track still ghosts so after so much editing, coaster can not be moved to rid self of wrecked cars. Don't speed up time or cars will fly off map. Customers have no personality and look like ghosts(Come to find out this was a Halloween intended prop). I understand it's still beta, but just say in patch notes that you want to make sure it boots up and nothing works right still. No custom billboards found either.Don't bother spinning your wheels, it's not ready yet.11/2/2015 edited typos and Peeps coment. Still would not recommend till a lot of bugs are fixed. It is still beta and I hope that is the reason, but this is not my first beta rodeo and this is the buggiest game I've beta tested.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
 Comparing development (continuously updated review)  As most people tend to compare quasi-similar games to each other, perhaps it's best to provide a review that does so without any bias or prejudice, as the vast majority of reviews lack the most important elements these should have: honesty and objectivity. So let's get to it. Both Rollercoaster Tycoon World (RCTW) and Planet Coaster (PC) are halfway through their alpha stages (or beta, the difference in meaning has become insignificant over the last years) and both games show great promises and annoying bugs at the same time, which is completely normal for any game under development of course. PC has just seen the release of its second alpha (the second out of three) and RCTW has had major and minor updates over the last two months, since it has entered early access on Steam. Let's start with pointing out what PC delivers and lacks at this point in time.PC is a game which features a more or less cartoonic graphic style and is mainly focused on building custom scenery and constructions by using various structural elements and decorative items. This way no two parks will look the same and the possibilities are numerous (not endless, as that's technically impossible), especially with the latest update in which it has been made a lot easier to fine tune the movement of objects on multiple axes. The amount of different structural elements to obtain such a desired beautiful park is quite decent, although it remains to be seen how many will still be added in the future before its final release in autumn 2016, as the amount of newly added objects was amazing during the first alpha, but rather disappointing in the second. Another main focus within the game is the animations of the park guests. These are far from optimal at this point, but it's obvious to see that the creators tend to accomplish guests who accurately reflect their mood, appear to be responsive to their environment (including the rides of course) and behave as natural as possible. This feature still needs development, but it's too soon to tell whether they succeeded or failed, as the park management (which includes this feature as far as I'm concerned) will be released in the third alpha stage next summer, so I will leave this part of the consideration for now. Moving on to the flat rides it seems the developers were bereft of any resourcefulness, as most rides are mere copies of previous rollercoaster tycoon games (RCT 1, 2 and 3) and in the second alpha they even added a second Ferris' Wheel, whereas one would have been more than enough (and don't forget that another flat ride - the Whirley Rig - is also a Ferris' wheel to tell the truth). Is it really that hard to come up with rides that are actually different from predecessors and at least somewhat different from other rides? Let me give you another example: the newly added Insanity ride is just a copy from previous rollercoaster tycoon games and it's also remarkably similar to the Hammer Swing. Why don't they add rides which they've actually come up themselves instead of merely copying others and/or existing rides (just compare the Brain Surge from Nickelodeon Universe to the Psychola ride in the game). To be fair, the same mistake was made with the development of RCTW, as they added two slides (whereas one would have been more than sufficient) and they failed to provide rides which are different and interesting enough from my perspective, just as the developers of PC did. The number of flatrides is still quite low within both games, but I'm sure this will improve on both fronts. Finally, let's move on to my biggest disappointment of PC: the coaster builder. It contains some nice features, such as being able to change colours of the tracks and the supports (although the colours of the carts can't be changed for some unknown reason) and there's a good amount and variety of coaster types, but the building itself is downright frustrating and tedious, as you constantly have to move the cursor from the screen to the interface at the bottom of the screen and back again to build track sections. The building process is also rigid and doesn't feel natural due to a lack of flexibility and a poorly designed interface. This feature has barely been improved upon since the release of Rollercoaster Tycoon 3 in 2004, which is clearly an impairment in this game. The second alpha delivered us the finished coaster builder according to the developers, so apparently they deem it to be completed.Let's now move on to RCTW. This game features a style similar to parks like Six Flags or Hersheypark (as opposed to PC which is more in the direction of Disneyland or Disney World) and is mainly focused on the coaster builder, although various flatrides and scenery items have been included of course. The coaster builder is not perfect (which will be improved in upcoming updates), but building coasters has quite a natural and flexible feel to it, does possess a good interface to make use of all the different functions the spline based building tool has to offer and provides the option to change colours as well. This feature has clearly been improved upon since its last installment of 2004, whereas PC failed to do this. On the other hand, the flexibility and possibilities PC offers for scenery items and custom constructions are not included in RCTW, as the latter does provide a freeform placement system, but is not aimed at allowing players to make their own buildings within the game at this point in time. This feature will be added to the game later on, probably once the game is pulled out of Early Access, which will happen given the amount of regular updates since its release (although many claimed it never would). Moreover, the animation of the peeps (park guests) is fairly poor in RCTW in comparison to PC. They behave and move unnaturally and need quite a few improvements, but the developers are still working on this. My aforementioned criticism on the flatrides also applies to RCTW. Several other missing features are more striking in both games, however, as both games don't include water, dark or transport rides (although both the developing teams promised to add these to the final product of games) and both games don't contain any kind of weather system or simulation (this feature has been promised for RCTW, but not for PC at the moment).So, which game would I recommend to you ? Both, as long as the promises that have been made regarding both games are met. Which game should you buy? That's up to you (I bought both games). To me it all comes down to preferences. Do you prefer a theme park builder which mainly focuses on beautiful scenery items and custom buildings just like Disney World, then go for Planet Coaster. If the building of amazing coasters and parks such as Six Flags is more to your liking, then go for Rollercoaster Tycoon World. I truly believe that both games are on the same level at this point in time, as both contain both good and bad features and both offer promises and bugs, which is utterly normal for games under development (as I already said). Let's hope that we will have two good theme park building games coming out at the end of this year.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay so I have been a huge fan of the RCT games since the launch of the first one.  That being said, I know there are a lot of things that are still sketchy with RCTW.  I was not fortunate enough to have been able to play this during Beta.  However, I wish people would not be so impatient and give it a chance.  I realize RCTW was in the works for a VERY long time and I was one of the people who was very much looking forward to its release.  I think for an Early Access game, it's quite good!  Some of the best games I have played have been Early Access games and while they were a bit low grade at their release, they are absolutely amazing now!  I believe RCTW has more than enough potential to be one of those games.  The devs did state that some things were limited due to the fact that it is Early Access and that they are still putting work into it.  There are definitely some graphical issues that need to be worked through and I would like to see the ability to change the colors of rides and incorporate our own music.  I can also see the some minor glitches in free form tracks and paths where it is difficult to create the exact shape that you want.  However, I feel that overall, it is a wonderful game!  I am really shocked at all the negative Early Access feedback.  It's EARLY ACCESS!  Meaning.....the devs want to know what the community wants to see done to create a better gaming experience.  They don't want a bunch of nasty comments about how their product was a flop and you should just go play some other rollercoaster game.  That is not at all constructive.  Anyway, yes, I would highly recommend this game and if you go into it with an open mind, looking at its future potential and not its current failures, then I think you will have a lot of fun!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I want to put a break in the train of hatred this game seems to be getting. First off, yes. I have not played Coaster Planet. Does Coaster Planet look nice? Yes. So does this, however. Are there things that I'd like to see improve? Well sure. That can be said about many games and this, fortunately, is still being worked on. For what I've got, I'm more than happy. Now that my little rant is over, allow me to explaid why I recomment this game:Gameplay: Overall, the game plays more or less exactly like RollerCoaster Tycoon 3. The game does try to move away from the grid system, however there is an optional grid you can enable to make your work more precise. While the grid feature does require some touching up to allow for things to be more exact, it still works and helps. The Coaster Builder is also updated to bring a, in my opinion, more indepth and detailed construction process. You no longer are restricted to certain angles allowing you to have a lot more freedom in your design. It will also display data on how your speed is distributed on the track, how fast you are going at a given place, etc. I had a good amount of fun playing with it. Going back to paths, you can also make curved paths this time removing your restriction to blocky pathways. Overall the game plays the same, just with some slight tweeks and updates.Graphics: This seems to be another contested area. The game definitely went away from the cartoonish theme of old in favor of realism. This doesn't bother me too much (Yes, I've played every RCT game. Yes, I understand the style was cartoony in all of them. Sure, go ahead and call me a casual, not a fan, etcc.) The overall user interface looks clean, perhaps not "super uber professional" with its art direction like some may desire. However, it works, it looks good, and I like it. A lot of what you would expect out of a RCT interface is there.Overall: There really isn't a whole lot for me to pick on with this game. It is exactly what I'd expect from a RollerCoaster Tycoon game, there are definitely some improvements over RCT3, but there are defintely areas to improve on. I will still continue to play it and enjoy it and definitely looks forward to what will come in the game's future. If you are on the fence of buying this game, do understand this is a work in progress, and understand that it really is not half as bad as people seem to think it is. You will enjoy it nonetheless if you enjoyed past RCT games.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Just to clarify, this is in early access, there will be bugs, I feel like the PC community would have figured that out already before giving early access games bad reviews because of bugs... ANYWAYS. After having spent the last 6 and a half hours playing this game, I can without a doubt say that this game is living up to my expectations... Having been a fan since the original RCT and seeing it progress to RCT3, a trainwreck of a game, I had high hopes for this game since Atari had 12 years to think and improve. Atari has improved. The interface is insanely simple yet effective, also it has a very slick design to it, props to that. All the editors for scenery, rides, shops, etc... is easy to use and simple. What I love most is the coaster editor. The freeform builder has just enough complexity to it that you may create whatever you dream of, within physical boundaries of course, but it is simple enough and straight forward that basically any 14 year old can hop on here and start building coasters. I feel as though this is finally the game I've been waiting for. RCT3 had some good features to it, like the ride cam for instance, as well as the magnitude of scenery and ride options. When I play this game, I feel like I'm playing a near perfect combination of RCT1 and RCT3 and I am okay with that.UPDATE 07/05/2016:For a good month I have been sitting back and watching how the devs react to all the negative reviews. At first I expected this to be another PC game that the Devs just kind of stick out there and abandon. THIS IS NOT THE CASE. These guys have been hammering away constantly at problems. They have been really transparent and dedicated. In every update log I see where they have read the reports and reviews and put into action a way to fix player's problems. This game is really coming along. If you haven't bought this game and want a finished game, wait another month to buy it. It is really coming along great! Thumbs up Devs! You're doing an awesome job!

content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Confused by some of the reviews on here.  There are top rated reviews that have nothing about the actual game, so I figured I would write my own.My first thoughts 7+ hours into playing this early access build of RCTW are that I am rather enjoying it and cannot wait to see what the devs add on! Here are the pros and what needs work through early access, I'd rather not consider them cons yet as they can be fixed.PROS:Once you spend some time going through the tutorial, building becomes easier and easier.  I had a few issues at first jumping in, but once I took the time to go through the tutorial, most, if not all of my issues were solved and made easier.  The social hub is a nice feature and easy to share blueprints for coasters.  My girlfriend is far better at building coasters than I, and I was able to grab her builds from here.  There were also others in the larger community that caught my eye.  Plenty of talented people out there and awesome to be able to use their coasters.Scenario modes are awesome! I like the variety of different problems the player has to solve in the different scenario options.The U.I. is nice throughout and clean!  Always know where to click for what I want.  No confusion even from when I first started.Game ran well on my Laptop which has a tendency to overheat with most games.  I see people listing better specs than I, but claiming their performance was poor.  Perhaps they should adjust their settings, because I'm wondering how in the world they had bad performance.  There is an occaisonal fps drop, but it was rare.  Probably something that will eventually be optimized by the developers completely.  No where near unplayable as some of these reviews would have you believe.  Trust me, I'm on my laptop. It's fine!Good amount of pre-built coasters and rides.  I expected the early access title would have less, but there is plenty to choose from.  That isn't counting the social hub and custom builds.Options were good.  Can adjust various audio levels, graphics,etc.  There are even options to favor fps over graphics if you should need that for your set-up.Notifications can act as a "to-do" list that you can easily clear or X out one by one.  It let me know when there was something I could be doing better in my park.WHAT COULD BE FIXED IN EARLY ACCESS:like with most early access titles, you can expect some bugs.  The main ones I ran into were peeps sliding rather than walking on occaison.  Peeps in general could use more work.  They would have strange graphical glitches within the riding cameras on most rides.Setting theme music on rides could sometimes overlap with other rides' music and create messy music.  I guess in a way it makes sense, but I wish this was more seamless.Nausea levels could be tweaked on the peeps.  Some odd instances where rides or peeps & staff will stop working for a moment.  Fixes itself within a minute or so.Overall, I would recommend RCTW.  I enjoyed the previous titles, and this one is fun and easy to jump right into.  Though in early access, it is more put together than many tycoon games. If the devs continue being passionate about this game and listening to the community, which it seems they will, this will be an amazing title!

content:

Early Access Review
								A lot of people are "rating the game" on an UNFINISHED Early Access game (But its what steam is calling these games). It should be called a Beta really . This might define it better for people thinking this is an oppurtunity to play a finished game before its released to everyone. If u hate buggy games that arent ready, the Beta and Early access games arent for u! It has the makings of a half-decent game, bugs are expected. I have personally played a lot of Betas, test environments and Early Access games. So i expect bugs and report them. Find me one game without bugs, but its already released? lolThe game has the makings of a good new RCT, only updated to 2016. It should become better than RCT3 if it keeps on track and fixes the problems. I could point out lots of the "bugs" but that would only put u off, the same as the other negative reviews, Again judging a game on its current state, instead of how great it could be on release. Its not all about better graphics and animations. It is well on track to have better interaction between player and the NPCs (seeing what they need, what they have spent, what they think of your park, etc). It has more shops, rides and a rollercoaster builder (for you to create your own great ride) and custom content, that will be shared on the Steam Workshop between players.If you are worried about its current state, hold off buying, dont read more into the negative youtube videos and reviews, etc. Remember, its about the finished release version 1.0 that you should be concerned with. THEN read the real reviews and pass judgement on the game and then decide to buy or not!

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								I typically do not write reviews, however I almost did not buy this game based on all the negative reviews that seem to be stemming from a fan fued between RCT and Planet Coaster. I was worried about the whole 'early access' and if this was even goingt o run properly on my older comptuters. I took the Planet Coaster comments seriously and did look into their product (I'm not sure how it is a 'game' yet... seems more like 'build only' platform which does not interest me) - I'll keep it on my Radar. ANYWAYS - the reason I am writing my review, was I almost did not buy RCTW because of all the mud being flung in this fued. It took several youtube video's to convince me that the product was ready... so here is is..THIS PRODUCT IS WORTH IT - PARTICULARLY IF YOU ARE A FAN OF THE ORIGINALS.There is enough working so it feels like a finished product. There are scenarious, multiple (10?+) coaster types, 100's? of rides, etc. The scenery selection is decent, however it is a little light on the themes.The new coaster creator - You can either create a coaster the 'old' way (piece by piece w/ a button editor) or with their new spline based system. I work in 3D all day long, but first started with the 'old' way for comfort sake. In my second park, I only built w/ the new system.There are SOME glittches. Paths sometimes don't want to snap together right, but they will 99% of the time, they just might not be 'pretty'. - they will NOT impeed the play of the game. General sim animation glitches, but again, this doesn't seem to impeed the play of the game.  Food/Drink stands don't snap to the edge of paths, so you need to place them and make a very short path to the path etc. etc. NONE OF THESE ELEMENTS STOP YOU FROM PLAYING!Also, I'm fairly happy to report that so far they do seem to be improving the game w/ updates.ANYWAYS - is you are a fan, and you're getting cold feet based on the reviews from the haters... hopefully this review will help you make a decision to buy. The only type of person I'd not recomend this to is someone w/ OCD that needs their parks to look perfectly symetrically and pretty. That's not going to happen yet. Play for the game itself, or play in sandbox mode to make really really awesome roller coasters. (which by the way you need a hack to use in planet coaster? WTF?)The only thing I may add, is if you're going to have to starve yourself for a week to save up th $50, eat... or maybe eat PB&J and buy RCT3 (assuming it will still run on Windows 10) for the 20 or whatever to get your fix and see where this price will end up - but $50 for a game like this, is not a bad investment.

content:

Early Access Review
								I know the game is still being put together, but i hope it's hardly done because so much is missing. All the features we all know and love from RCT3 like peep designer, etc. are all gone. Hardly a fraction of the flatrides, water rides, pools, coasters, and transport rides are not in the game. The new grid system really takes some getting used to. You can't edit the land square in line with the grid anymore which is disapointing. The peeps walk around with less intelligence than the one's from RCT2. All in all, the game needs drastic amounts of new and old features put into it. I know the cliffhanger ride, the tilt-awhirl, the tumble bug, caterpillar, and the kangaroo have never been in any of the other versions, but id really love to see them in this game. The fact that you cant build custom buildings and walls like in RCT3 makes me angry. I don't like how que line entrances and exits are pre-attatched to the rides. There are so many limits in this game that should be broken through. My imagination is stressed out from running into all these things I can't do which I should be able to. Why can't I build tunnels anymore? On a brighter note, I do love the fact that some of the flatrides left out of all the previous versions are finally in the game, and the newer features such as the variable paths. I will keep this review updated.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Short and sweet; if they fix the pathing issues, add some more scenery options, and allow us to recolor rides (currently you can only change the color of coaster parts)...I'd have no problem fully recommending this. Being that it's still in Early Access, I'm a bit more forgiving. However, by the time the proper release rolls around, if the current issues are still withstanding, then I'd have no qualms about updating my review and recommendation. All in all, do your research about RCTW. Yes, Planet Coaster is all around a better theme park sim as it stands, but it's double the price to buy in to Planet Coaster's alpha. If you're on a budget, and want a new park sim, and can deal with it's quirks, I don't see why anyone shouldn't give RCTW a try. And with Steam now allowing refunds, if you dislike it that much, you can always get your money back.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I was looking forward to a new RCT for YEARS, which is why this game is such a disappointment. It looks really pretty but that's really all it seems to have to offer. As many others who played the first "beta"-weekend says: the coaster editor is a mess. It's hard to use, making cool functional roller-coasters is impossible, nothing really works and building is no fun at all. I really like the concept of spline based building but right now I prefer the old style building as that was FUN.Even if you look past all the bugs that makes your game crash and the loading times that take forever it's still way behind it's predecessors. And calling this weekend a "beta" weekend is a bit of a joke as well, as the game feels more like an alpha or even pre-alpha game looking at it's current near unplayable condition.I'm not a big fan of the UI either. The old UI's made the game look fun and it was easy to understand. In this game it feels like they were trying to be "modern" and not looking into what the fans liked about the previous games. It's really just SimCity all over again...I did like the terrain editor though. Playing with water is super fun, but is it worth 46€? No.I say that if you really want to try this game like I did, wait for the full relase and listen to what the reviews has to say by then. Hopefully the devs will clean this mess up but I doubt they will in only 2 months of time...

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Please note that this is just my opinion... And that I haven't read what they're up to putting into it yet.Pro's:- I love the rides.- I love the fact that now there's actually ''death'' possible when you build a rollercoaster, which makes it more challenging to build one.- You can now move stuff without deleting it first compared to the other RC games.- The campagne is fun, however, I think it'd be more fun if added more challenges to it.Con's:- Even on my brother's game computer it lags. I have one myself, whilst my brothers literally meets all the requirements. It is not recommended for laptops or so unless you got yourself a strong, good laptop(mainly due overheating).- The paths are annoying to place. I tried putting a path from a building to the ''main street'' but it replaced the old path from the ''mainstreet''.- The buildings look all the same, at least for the staff.- I hate the staff buildings. They barely do anything and in RTC3 I really enjoyed the fact you could throw staff in your park and train them etc._I've heard a lot of negative things about RCTW , but keep in mind it's still Early Access. From what I saw, they've improved quite a few things. I see a lot of people saying although Planet Coaster isn't done yet but better. I didn't play PC, and I don't care.Both of them still need to be finished and I'm sure this game gets better as time goes on.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								I held off buying RCTW because of the mostly negative reviews on here. Since buying and playing though, I have enjoyed the game but can see why it has attracted some negativity. I think a lot more work is needed to bring this game up to an acceptable standard but as it is Early Access I am hoping the devs will deliver on their promised improvements, and soon. I have found the game becomes quite quickly boring due mainly to the lack of content, especially park transportation (Devs: please add URGENTLY!!). The lack of flat, water and other non-coaster rides also limits the game severely; I mean, you can only have so many teacup rides and observation towers in a park.The lack of supplied scenery is bad and I have found it difficult to use the workshop items, mainly because a lot of contributors dont proivde any sort of description for their work.  This comment does not lessen my gratitude to the creators of such content for their hard work and generosity in sharing!!The scenarios are somewhat irritating. In RCT3, if you fail a scenario you get another chance in a month or so but in RCTW, if you fail after 12 months, you lose the whole lot and have to start again from scratch. I can usually reach Bronze Level easily in these but then lose everything after the 12 month period has expired when trying for Silver and Gold.I think the animations need some tweaking. For example peeps floating along paths, doors and gates do not open and close with peeps floating through them etc. Small items but important for the overall feel of thepark. Control of park staff is a major issue especially the janitors. In earlier games, I likes being able to assign work areas for staff.I found one "bug" that has been annoying i.e. when placing most of the "upmarket" restaurants, I cannot connect paths to them. Even on a completely flat sandbox park I get the red error indicator when trying to join paths to, for example, the Ice Cream Parlor and Salad Restaurants (and others). I am fairly sure this is a game issue and not my lack of understanding on placement. Rollercoaster Tycoon and Transport Tycoon were the first games I played on PC and I love the tycoon genre. This latest version of the RCT franchise has quite a way to go but overall, I would happily recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								These negative reviews are so bias it is insane.... Everyone of them talks about planet coaster,  a game that isn't even out yet but still people talk it up as if they've played it. I will also be getting planet coaster day one but It is not fair to this dev team who has obviously worked very hard on this.. Plus it is early access! I'll start by saying I did not buy this for $50,  I got it for $20 so that definitely helps make it more positive for me and I believe it's important for me to note that. I am running a GTX 980, i7, 32gb ram... I have yet to run into any major optimization issues. I have the graphic settings maxed out,  the game looks great and runs great. I really like the lighting at night.  If you're running on a much older machine and complaining about optimization issues then you just need to stop and git gud. I don't believe half these reviews on here...Many of the negative reviews have less then an hour played on them or they're from the beta..Gamers now a days hate on anything and everything. Seems people can't enjoy anything for themselves, so they jump on the hate train. Its very evident when half the negative reviews have the same language. Its truly sad. When it comes to this,  PC gamers have always been the worst. This is an early access game and for what it is now,  I think its great and is only going to get better. The development team has already posted a day after release about upcoming updates directly addressing players complaints. I hope they plan on releasing a ton of content. Maybe even some freebies for us early access folks. I'm loving it so far.. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the first two RCT games. I played a ton of hours on both back in the 90s. I know already this will consume me.👍😊

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								There is a lot of negative reviews about rollercoaster world and yes it took me a couple of hours to get used to how the game works, turn rides/shops etc around, but now ive got the hang of it im finding the game quite promising. I think the developers have got the right idea and have done a good job with what they have done so far. Yes its got some issues with gitches and sound and sometimes my people just suddenly freeze but this is early access. I like how much easier it is to build rollercoasters and i like all the personal touches that you can do with them, at the same time im glad theyve kept the pre-made rollercoasters. I also think the detail thats gone into the stations is really good. I was a little unsure about space but after 2 hours of playing i found that this was just me not knowing how to play the game yet, because you can buy more land by going on the terrain tool button, and i found if i pressed the letter n ( i play on my laptop) it allows you to place buildings closer to rides etc. I like what theyve done with the themes, and have been able to make a western and an adventure area with what is available in this early access game. I am looking forward to see what the updates will bring. The only negatives ive found so far is deleting items such as bins, lamposts etc im finding you have to put your mouse in a certain spot for it to highlight. Deleting the trees and bushes one at a time is also a little tedious as i cant find an option to delete a large area at a time, id like atari to look into putting a multi- tool delete option or something similiar to fix this. Ive also found that i cant place rides or anything if theres trees etc in the way without deleting them all yourself and then finding the ride you wanted again so i would also like the rides etc to automatically delete the trees etc for you.  nearly forgot but Im not liking the staff limit, im ending up with lots of staff buildings which only allow 3 staff and the cleaners dont seem to do anything because after placing 5 cleaner buildings my parks still a mess, I see them cleaning but it doesnt seem to make any difference, same for mechanics too. I know there will be larger building available but i can imagine me just having lots of larger staff buildings everywhere. Other than that im happy with what ive seen so far.Since playing further ive had issues reloading a saved game it just crashes saying virtual memory to low to play game, but my virtual memory is fine. Also after being on any rollercoaster every person that comes of is sick which you can never clean up, all cleaners go there so the rest of your park turns into a tip. Also i cant seem to place benches etc on a higher up path.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I've put some hours into this game and I already encountered a lot of game breaking bugs. Peeps that get stuck, a complete reset of the peeps in my park, rides not getting fixed while I have no idea why not and worst of all the frame drops and sometimes even the whole game freezing up. It even managed to crash my computer entirely while saving a game. This only occured when my park was pretty big already though.However, the parts that work are really fun. It feels and plays like a next gen roller coaster game, wich is exactly what I wanted. I don't know why everyone is hating on the new coaster builder. It's actually really fun and easy once you get the hang of it. I also really like the new scenery and it makes it that I want to make every inch of the park as pretty as can be. The steam workshop works really well with this game and while there isn't much on it right now I can't wait what people will upload so I can make my park even more awesome.I'm giving the game a thumbs up because I'm actually really enjoying it, even in it's current state. That said, do realise this is not a complete game yet and if you don't want to be part of the ''play-testing'' phase you should wait until they at least patch out the major bugs. Because there are.. a lot..

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is really good. When it was released there's no doubt it left a lot be desired as there were numerous bugs but having bought the game and played it myself now it is developing into an excellent theme park building game. What is going to go massively in this game's favour is the ease of importing models into this game. Quite frankly the possibilities are endless. The amount of UGC is already quite high and will keep going but it would be nice to see some other tools such as a full map creator. I know you can create scenarios by using terraforming tools in sandbox but nevertheless would be nice to see a map builder. This game still needs some optimizing as well as it can run quite jerkily when on high graphics but seems perfectly smooth on medium graphics. This may also be partly down to my PC although it is quite new. It took a couple of updates to get there but good job Atari and keep the updates and content coming.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								There is a lot of negative reviews about rollercoaster world and yes it took me a couple of hours to get used to how the game works, turn rides/shops etc around, but now ive got the hang of it im finding the game quite promising. I think the developers have got the right idea and have done a good job with what they have done so far. Yes its got some issues with gitches and sound and sometimes my people just suddenly freeze but this is early access. I like how much easier it is to build rollercoasters and i like all the personal touches that you can do with them, at the same time im glad theyve kept the pre-made rollercoasters. I also think the detail thats gone into the stations is really good. I was a little unsure about space but after 2 hours of playing i found that this was just me not knowing how to play the game yet, because you can buy more land by going on the terrain tool button, and i found if i pressed the letter n ( i play on my laptop) it allows you to place buildings closer to rides etc. I like what theyve done with the themes, and have been able to make a western and an adventure area with what is available in this early access game. I am looking forward to see what the updates will bring. The only negatives ive found so far is deleting items such as bins, lamposts etc im finding you have to put your mouse in a certain spot for it to highlight. Deleting the trees and bushes one at a time is also a little tedious as i cant find an option to delete a large area at a time, id like atari to look into putting a multi- tool delete option or something similiar to fix this. Ive also found that i cant place rides or anything if theres trees etc in the way without deleting them all yourself and then finding the ride you wanted again so i would also like the rides etc to automatically delete the trees etc for you.  nearly forgot but Im not liking the staff limit, im ending up with lots of staff buildings which only allow 3 staff and the cleaners dont seem to do anything because after placing 5 cleaner buildings my parks still a mess, I see them cleaning but it doesnt seem to make any difference, same for mechanics too. I know there will be larger building available but i can imagine me just having lots of larger staff buildings everywhere. Other than that im happy with what ive seen so far.Since playing further ive had issues reloading a saved game it just crashes saying virtual memory to low to play game, but my virtual memory is fine. Also after being on any rollercoaster every person that comes of is sick which you can never clean up, all cleaners go there so the rest of your park turns into a tip. Also i cant seem to place benches etc on a higher up path.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								As a RCT fan, I was so excited to play this. I played all of the previous titles of the series and loved every second of them. But when I started to play this, I felt so disappointed.I have a GTX 980. Why am I getting such low framerates with graphics that are so blurry? Take the peeps and workers for example; their textures are pretty hideous. The flat rides flooring doesn’t even match my current path designs. RCT3 managed to do this so why can’t this? I was so excited for the scenarios and when I played them, it wasn’t enjoyable compared to how the scenarios worked in the previous titles. In RCT3 for example; had custom entrances, descriptive objectives on a simple UI objective board. But in this game, every scenario has the same entrance on all three levels with only a terrain change and has simple objectives with ugly white UI. I had to go back to RCT3 and RCT2 and play those scenarios again. I say don’t buy this game now. Wait a few months/year. There are other coaster tycoon games that are currently being developed. Planet Coaster for people who enjoyed Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 (which is in early alpha and it’s prettier than this. However, Planet Coaster Alpha costs £49.) and for people who enjoyed RCT1 and RCT2 there is Parkitect (Alpha cost £15). Those two games are shaping up to be great coaster games. I suggest following their progress.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I was really looking forward to this game. Couldn't wait to try it out. But even though its only an early access at the moment, I'm quite disappointed with it. Even though it has been delayed quite a few times now, it still feels as though not a lot of thought has gone into the game. Like as though they didn't have any coaster enthusiasts to help develop the game.The peeps when you are zoomed out walk like as though you're playing an 8 bit game, the on ride camera doesn't work, due to the fcat that it will freeze on some rides, and the coasters don't have any banked curves when they go round corners. Anyone would know with basic physics that a human body could not withstand those sharp abrupt turns! I know this is only a game, but a game should have more thought into it than what has gone into this. I hate to say it, but it feels like a game for a 6 year old. Like Junior Monopoly!Roll on when Planet Coaster comes out. Frontier know how to make coaster games!

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok, so they must have made some drastic improvements over the past couple of months because all the negative reviews I was reading is NOT what I have experienced thus far.  Yes, it is early release and there are minor things that need to be added but nothing that is game breaking.  I would like to see more finely tuned staff control (a la rct3) and more flat rides.  I would also like to see the fonts fixed for the park details because its hard to read (its not too small, i have good vision, its straight up hard to read, like missing pixels or something).  I also liked being able to run advertising for specific rides in the older titles, that'd be nice to have back as well.That all said, I love all the new features with the terrain, roller coaster builder, and path builder.  It all works pretty darn well and its way more intuitive and efficient than the previous titles.  I can honestly say that I've put in a good bit of time into this game already and am not tired of it yet.  I need more flat rides to fill out my park but I have confidence those are still coming.This is going to be the best RCT game by far, if they keep listening to the players and continue to fix and release content at the rate they are currently.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Before I start, I'd like to mention I'm an avid RCT fan.I purchased the game expecting the same greatness every other RCT title has delivered on. I got freeform coasters, paths, and Part by Part buildings, but the lack of a map editor, small parks compared to even RCT2, insane waiting times for the game to load, not to mention the lack of coasters, rides, terraforming, and the like more than cancel out the few promising features. I'll be going back to RCT3P, because a game 12 years old is insanely more fun than this black hole scrap heap of coding.Where's my ability to make custom peeps? Or design scenarios? What happened to the hundreds of different ride types? Even with all nine squares unlocked, the usable area in the park is horrid, even more so when you add trees, hills, vertical cliffs, and water to your already limited build area. I regret purchasing this game, AND the "digital deluxe" DLC. If things don't improve drastically and soon, I think I might refund my purchase.

Posted: January 18
												I have to say I can totally see why Planet Coaster keeps being brought up in these reviews. This game has horrible performance and is obviously not very well optimized. Even running this on a system with a GTX 1070, i7-4790 processor and 32 gigs of RAM, this game had really nasty lag spikes everywhere. Even dumbing down the graphic settings to the lowest possible didn't help much while making it feel more like I was playing on a game from the early 2000's. It's just not very enjoyable trying to build a park when you're constantly lagging.Going back and forth between this game and Planet Coaster, the differences are very well night and day. I'm sure some people will side with this game and it's developers, which is fine, but believe me and others when we say, once you play Planet Coaster, you won't come back to this. I know I didn't. I'm really sorry I even bought this, but I guess that's what happens when you don't do your homework first.
