content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
THIS REVIEW WILL BE CONTINUOUSLY UPDATEDMost recent update; update #11!Since it's release on March 30th, RCT World has been getting eleven updates. Each update added some content, fixed some bugs, improved the game piece by piece. Workshop integration sort of works without issues now, and a blueprint/piece by piece mode, just as in planet coaster (but without the annoying♥♥♥♥♥denuvo) has been added. While Planet Coaster still has a bit more to offer than RCTW, RCTW doesn't use Denuvo, so that's already a bigger plus than any content PC has to offer. And since frontier develops it, I doubt there will be any more support after the final release of the game. Maybe in DLCs. Keep an eye out for RCTW, because it's slowly becoming more and more of a real RCT title. Previous reviewRCTW is developing more and more, some progress has certainly been made in the past few weeks. Almost 2 months have passed since the originial release of RCTW and the game has been improved a lot from its original state. The devs make use of the bugtracker and have fixed most of the more severe and some small bugs the users have been complaining about whilist still adding new features and improving the overall game experience, which is reflected in the community and the content the users have created. It will still take a while for RCTW to become a solid game, but it gets closer with every update. As of now I will still put a "No" recommendation on it, as it is not completely worth its money yet.Original reviewRCTW got rushed into early access before it was supposed to, as retailers sold the game before it's release. Thus the current state of the game is rather terrible. It has a bunch of bugs, some more severe than others, workshop integration isn't fully functioning and the performance is rather bad.RCTW adds a lot of new features to the RCT series though. More customization, more user generated content, more park management. The coaster editor now features a node based building system, similar to the one seen in NoLimits, which allows the user to create coasters with more freedom than ever. Of course the "Piece by piece" system still exists. Curved paths and grid-less scenario placing allow the player to put more detail into their parks and staff now requires buildings to "rest" in.However, the worst thing about RCTW as of now is it's community. People expected the game to be complete and a fully functional successor of the RCT franchise. Of course they got disappointed when the earlier-than-early access version turned out to be.. not so great.Unless you absolutely want it, I'd recommend you to wait and watch the game develop.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Revised review:  A while back I gave this game a thumbs up, even though it had problems because I really was enjoying playing it and it had more content than the competitor, which I also have been playing since Alpha.  They had been fixing crashes and I presumed that crashes would become rare.  Unfortunately, although they have continued to add content to this game, they still have not fixed the crashes.  The last two updates had almost no crash fixes or optimization improvements - only added scenery.  Many times I have worked on a park only to have the game crash and lose all that I had done.  Today I started a new scenario in the story mode (ironcically called Crash Course) and when modifying the initial coaster the scenario starts with the game crashed several times.  Sadly, and reluctantly I can no longer recommend this game and have changed my review to a thumbs down.  The competitor's game (PlanetCoaster) never crashes on me, is better looking, offers more in terms of management now, has a much better path system and has added quite a bit more content over the past few months (plus has over 100,000 workshop items!)  PC also has another free big update coming next week and they are very responsive to player requests and concerns.  ORIGINAL REVIEWBeen playing since alpha.  It's been improved dramatically.  Hadn't played it much since the full release, but decided to play it some more to see if it really deserved all the bad reviews.  I actually had fun playing it.  It has quite a bit of content (which is something currently lacking in PanetCoaster, which I also have had since alpha.)  At the price it is currently at ($35) or less I do think it's worth a buy if you enjoy this type of game.  If you really enjoy BUILDING things in fine detail, get PC, it's beautiful to look at and better optimized.  But if you enjoy laying out a park and plopping prebuild stuff and scenery, this is a pretty decent game.  The coaster builder is actually better in this game than in PC and you're sure to get a good laugh from the animation of the peeps (some are pretty ridiculous, even though they've been improved greatly from early access).  Note: if you want to build bigger parks with many rides you will really need at least 16 gigs of ram.

number of helpful: 24 of 50 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												First off, this review is for the 1st beta weekend, in which the purpose of the beta is to show off the roller coaster builder and to get feedback. After launching the game for the first time, it immediately crashed during the loading screen. That’s definitely not a great start to a beta. The game is riddled with bugs that make the game unplayable. So far, this game isn’t even up to the quality of early-access alpha games by indie developers.Here is a short list of bugs I’ve run into in just the first 2 hours:Clicking a control point on a track randomly changes it rotation values, making it impossible to tweak the coaster without breaking everything.There are memory leaks that cause the game to crash about once an hour.There are occasional crashes during the loading screen.Cars fall through the track on lift chain hills almost every other run.Cars fall through the track of the station as soon as you hit test.Fast forwarding time completely breaks the physics, causing even the slightest turn to throw trains off the rails.The UI for lift chain speeds and booster/break speeds are the size of an ant. You can’t click it, much less read it.The camera controls don’t work while editing coasters, and sometimes freeze up while editing paths, scenery, or terrain.The rotation arrows for track editing are occasionally in the wrong direction.The rotation values of track control points are almost always incorrect, also causes the white, yellow, and red highlighting to be incorrect. You can have a control point that looks like it should be 0 degree, and it will say it is 35 degree.Intersecting paths of different sizes don’t render properly.Wooden coaster supports don’t render properly.Even with the max brush strength, it takes quite a while to fill a small pond with water. That was a horrible feature idea.I’ve already documented 137 more bugs, but I’m just going to leave the list there. Overall, the camera controls and editing controls are too buggy to use reliably, and the coaster editing features of this game are mostly broken.Since this was a beta to demonstrate just the coaster editor, and it is this bad, I don’t expect this game to be out this year unless they hire programmers just to fix bugs. I can’t even imagine how buggy all the other features are of the game. As it is, it looks like they have pushed the release date back again from Dec. 10th to Dec. 29th.

But EA is what the game needs right now from my point of view. The game is not as bad as 70% negative reviews and seemingly 100% negative since the launch! With lots of effort put into it by the devs and the community this game can be amazing. So be patient, it's the first day of EA and some of the people behave like it was doomsday.

content:
Posted: January 23
												I feel it necessary to post my own review of this game, which seems to be panned for its inability to run on every PC out there. This is NOT RCT2 or even RCT3. But it IS a nice game with great graphics and a very challenging Story Mode.I am an avid, Longtime PC gamer (25+ years). I've played every Rollercoaster Tycoon game, and loved them. I STILL play RCT3 with my children. I am VERY critical of games that don't meet up to their billing. This new Iteration is NOT deserving of the bashing it is getting.Yes, the computer requirements are steep. If you just meet the Minimum requirements, you will have a Minimum game experience. Don't put this game on the Schlock list just because your computer isn't kept "Latest & Greatest".The Story Mode gives you a goal with a challenging start point, and you move from scenario to scenario as you complete the tasks for each level. I like the "Tycoon Points" for purchasing new designs/technologies, as it adds more depth than the previous games had. There IS a sandbox mode, where you can stretch your legs and get used to the interface and perfect your coaster-building before wasting a lot of cash in the Story Mode. You can USE the Tutorial in there to walk thru the various elements of gameplay, and learn just how different it is from previous RCT games it is.Ther may ber a few, minor hassles like dropping a mechanic at a broken ride, then watching him walk completely away from it just to go check on a working ride. But that doesn't warrant a Terrible review.My recommendation: Test Drive it for yourself. Steam guarantees your satisfaction, right? Purchase and play it for an hour. That will let you see if your PC can run the game. Plus, it will give you a quick look into the interface and the Story Mode. If it sucks to you, get your money back, but don't go Flaming it on the reviews.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played all the Roller Coaster tycoon games over the years. This one is a bit tricky at first. Expect to spend a few hours understanding how to make your first coaster unless you get some tips. This is more of a guide and review at the same time. Here are some tips. :)Expect a little frustration building your coaster at first. When building your coaster:  Hold down the shift key, and use the mouse wheel to move it higher or lower. After you click on a peice of the track in build mode you can drag out that track and make curves, etc. and press 1, 2, 3, or 4; all these numbers do different things. Then you use your mouse wheel and to adjust. One of the numbers lifts up the track on one side for example (press 2, and then use your mouse wheel for example).Also the camera is a bit quirky. You can go into options in the game, general, turn off auto focus coaster when building (so it doesn't jump everytime you click on the track), turn off auto zoom out camera if object is to large, and change your camera field of view if you like.Also the graphics can be improved; changing them is a bit quircky. This is done by pressing escape, options, graphics, turn off better fps over graphics.. This makes the graphics settings go lower for some reason though. You then need to adjust higher the other settings AFTER you select this.Placing a ride or object: Hold down the shift key, and use your mouse wheel to turn it around before you place it.Adjusting the size of the map: Click modify terrain, and you'll find the option to expand there.Also when you place a janitors building for example each building is used to hire the number of janitors for that building; differnent than RCT3.This is a great game, but I think the issue is most people aren't taking the time to go through the tutorial. In addition to that the coaster building is a bit advanced; you can do a lot with it, but the key will be the first few hours.For beginners it's a bit tricky. Is it fun? Yes it's a lot of fun to play. I'm enjoying my park the more and mroe I play it. The more I play, the more I want to play. It starts out slow and grows on you once you figure out what your doing. It's also fun to decorate/improve the park.The graphics are pretty nice as well. I'm looing forward to this game growing, but as for now it's a good game if your willing to read a guide like this one and others you'll be fine. :) Also if you enjoy a challenge on coaster building you'll like this game. Expect a lot of crashes during testing, but it's gratifying and realistic.. You adjust angles of track to compensate, etc. It just feels nice, and it's a good sandbox style game.There are a good amount of rides, and park finances.Why are there bad reviews section: Most people don't understand the options they have at their disposal, and haven't read the tips/guides on controls. Changing the graphic options, and adjusting the camera are all fairly easy to do once you have read these trips. I have experienced some crashes for example when making a huge roller coaster with lots of turns, etc. I'd say save every so often in case, but the coaster build is pretty fun once you get the hang of it. The game is itself seems to run pretty smooth though on my system; a 980 GTX, 16 gigs ram, and a 3.4 ghz quad.The problem is if people didn't get it within 1-2 hours many immediately went for the bad review/refund option, but this one is worth digging deeper and playing imo. :)

Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is alright and has potential, but it should look back some of the other games for improvement. Maybe im missing a couple features, but I cant be sure. I didn't play rct3 because It was kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥ Just a note: One of the rides is broken, the one that is supposed to swing the guests with the whole seating mechanism spinning (I cant remember the name). It sits at the top and does not release and just spins at the top of its rotation. Reccomended hardware: Any mouse with an infinite scroll wheelThe one thing I love more than anything is the roller coaster design and the application of mechanics within them (though making loops and♥♥♥♥♥♥is hard).  The path building is also cool, but I never use the curved pathways because they never seem to work or let any other paths snap. You should also allow for automatic scenery destruction when creating the coasters, placing pre-mades or at least expand the destruction to only destroy scenery in xy range. Things I hate are the laggy experiances you get which you can only assume is due to a memory leak or soemthing else. The buildings are cool, though I hate the fact that you need to place a path for each and every one is really annoying. This is one of those features im going to test later with the grid snap and see if that helps out at all. The default station platforms are limiting, but the use of the brakes is a more realistic (and maybe better?).I hate hate hate the use of the word "peeps" and how the "peeps" thoughts don't stack. This is something that is absolutely needed. Also the use of the words People or Guests looks better. Is this game worth $60 right now? Prolly not, just depends if you want to participate in the feedback.

content:

Early Access Review
								So I want to say a few things about this game really quick. First of all I have been a player of this series since RCT1 was out, I've had most of my hours in this series played in RCT2 but I've still played countless hours of RCT3. This new game has put a very sour taste in my mouth and it seem to have done the same for many other fans of the series. but looking at tis game as it is, it isn't awful. The textures and movement of the peeps are my biggest complaint and the pathing isn't very smooth and needs to be fixed. but other than that, this game has a monetary system and scenario and well made terrain deformation and water(even though the water doesn't look very good), It also doesn't run great but the just means it needs to be a little better optimized which is usually the last thing a developer does in a game. This game definetely has some things it needs to fix, but if they can tweak those few things, it'll be a pretty good coaster tycoon game.TL;DRThe game has graphic issues and looks a little weird, but it has potential to be a good game

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								A rather negative, but recommending, review that isn't "helpful", despite stating all the game's current flaws (that I have found).Enjoy.I've been playing RCT games since the beginning; way back in the 90s. Y'know, the days of Chris Sawyer? (pre-lawsuit, of course)Keeping in mind that this game is early access with said early access having been pushed back for months and months by the publisher due to quality control... well, the quality here is, at best, mediocre; probably not worth the wait.Personally, I really dig the game. It's keeps me amused while I have free time before or after work, but I'm unsure if it has that same vibe as any of the previous RTC games as of yet.The graphics are "prettier" than its predecessors, but not optimized in the slightest. At this time, it's remarkably limited (due to early access). Given just how much the early access was pushed back, I did expect a little more refining on what the devs said they had been working on. It feels as if they left some things unchecked on their to-do list.In it's current state, it doesn't even remotely stand up to what RTC3 was, or even the original game (yes, even without expansions, this game could not stand up to it). The graphics and animations are janky, completely incomplete in comparison, though I highly respect the attempts at a more realistic look. Glitches are, obviously, numerous. The controls are offputting to me, but that could just be because it's a new game. My computer, which though isn't amazing, should be able to play it no problem; the optimization on this is currently horrid to flat-out nonexistent (keeping in mind that this is early access and many tools, bits, and bobs can't be fully optimized without tests; it doesn't make it any less annoying to a player [even in early access]). The game will freeze while trying to load a scenario and most campaign maps. For me, it can only load up sandbox mode and the first campaign map without trouble.Due to it's early access state, there isn't much of a campaign mode nor scenarios. If you can't get them to load like me, there's even less of a selection.The delete tool is sort of atrocious; since you have to play on low quality, you have to zoom in to kill some azaleas (sorry, flowers) before you can even build a ride. Yes, you can apparently build through trees no problem, but save the flowers! You can't build over paths if you decide that you like one more. You have to individually delete each path section and then rebuild your chosen path. Individually. Delete. Path sections. Or individually delete trees. Individually. I was hoping for a click'n'drag, delete all the things, KILL IT ALL mentality as it would make clearing an area less annoying. The path issue was fixed in RCT3 with that path tool, but even then you could only individually delete plants and rocks (or have I missed something?)Path building itself can be a bear. Sometimes it says you can't connect paths, but I rarely ever see the reason why. Unfortunately, with each path being a "bone", you can't always add another bone to it. Even though you may just be making the spine longer.While I really dig the coaster builder (I think this will always be considered the "best" part of the game, even in a completed state), it is incredibly awkward to use. There's multiple tabs, which I don't mind, but they make it seem clunky. (Though having it all together would probably be even worse). I feel like the coaster builder from RCT3 was far more refined and usable. It didn't give me a headache. But I also couldn't have made the amazing tracks I can now.For paths and coaster tracks, you can move the mouse wheel to rise or lower the pieces. Unless there's some sensitivity thing I'm missing, this is very slow.You now have staff buildings rather than just hiring staff. And, as of right now, you can't change their outfits. Not even for the entertainers. So in my normal park, instead of having a black'n'white panda like I would in RCT, I get blue and white (which is the "normal" panda for RCT) and. Wait for it. Aliens and owls(I think. Wtf is that thing?). I don't even know what else. I liked having my natural pandas, black leopards, cheetahs, and lions in RCT3. Minor complaint, and probably something that will be implemented later so we don't have owl things walking around in a space themed park.Fortunately, it is early access. Most of this should (hopefully) be fixed in the future.Despite all it's negatives, I currently really do enjoy the game, apparently having been playing RCT games for over fifteen years. I still play RTC1-3. But unfortunately, like I said, it doesn't stand up to these.But, for what this game is, it is enjoyable as a long-time fan. I don't see myself playing a ton of it as of yet given the number of issues and the fact that the older games simply are better right now. I'm just hopeful that there's no more push backs and that the devs stay on it.While I do recommend, I honestly suggest holding onto your money for just a bit (maybe another update or two) unless you remember the days of old and bare-bones 1990's games and don't mind that sort of thing. At this state, it is not worth the money, confusion, or irritation for most people. That being said, I personally do plan on playing the game every now and again while complaining about the weird controls all the way.However, I hope the devs know that I was willing to spend my money in the name of RCT and publisher (Atari) in hopes of a good future game.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been a long time fan of the RCT franchise since RCT1. I was very excited about the RCTW project ever since I first heard the news that there was finally going to be a sequel. RCTW delivers everything you would expect in a modern RCT game. The greatest improvement of all is the absence of the grid. Everything in RCTW is placed and manipulated in a real time 3D environment. The Coaster Editor is the next biggest improvement. Gone are the days of piece-by-piece track building. In it's place, we have a powerful spline editor that makes creating coasters more advanced than ever before. It's entirely possible to build a track piece at any angle imaginable. And thirdly, we have an sphosticated UGC system in place to guarantee that players can create, share, and place virtually any kind of scenery object right into the game. I feel that my top needs have been met so far by RCTW and the project has a very hopeful future ahead. I'm very pleased to be a part of the experience and I'm excited to see this project carry on the legacy of my favorite theme park sim franchise.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I know this is beta and I really was looking forward to it, but I deinstalled it. I hit the minimum requirements for this game and it is almost impossible for me to do anything in there, because it's much too laggy (when it even starts).Loading the game takes ages (it says "can take several minutes" on the loading screen - so it's not me). After playing the series and all add-ons from the beginning, it is surely hard to learn everything from scratch again (e.g. building coaster tracks). But maybe it is nice when you learned it finally.Worst of all is the WASD movement. I want to scroll with my mouse and not with the keyboard. This is no FPS.You can't get into the game options yet, so I have no idea if I can make a better performance with turning the video quality down.To make it short: I can't recommend this for people with old hardware. But finally I have a reason to buy a new one now. -----Edit (20th Oct 2016)I got a better machine now and it's running more or less smoothly. There has been much work done since last year and the game is growing. But my main con is the movement. Why are you able to turn the map with the mouse wheel, but have to move with WASD? That's so far the major reason for me to stick with the "rival's" game, which is developing parallel to this one.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								I am actually quite enjoying the game! I dont seem to have nearly as much trouble building a great looking park and making everything work as some other people claim. There are some visual bugs, the crowd simulation could be better and I've had the occasional crash to desktop, but overall I can obsess for hours just placing fricking vegetation, trashcans and whatnot (try the snap/grid options for object placement) but the object rotation feels a bit slow. I've built some insane coasters (of which there are many types), checked out a multitude of charming rides and there is actually a ton of variety and content out of the box. Whoever complains about things looking similar, has probably only looked at food and merch stores. I've unlocked 5 out of 9 tiles for the park size (which is already quite massive) and I am able to create visually diverse and themed regions (sci-fi, western, adventure or generic). I can also sculpt and paint terrain to create mountains, or even fill valleys with water to create lakes and islands. You just need to progress for a bit and unlock the campaign obectives and you will have more content than you can shake a stick at. Or play sandbox. Game is pretty underrated and addictive if you ask me and people are being quite harsh in their reviews. If you can pick it up for a decent price, give it a shot. PS: you can kill peeps with coaster cars launching off track. Good times.Edit: Now that my park is growing, performance seems to suffer more and more, even on very high end gear with max settings and I get some serious fps drops. I tend to now pause the game when building to alleviate that. Hope the devs can improve that before the full release.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I had a good time playing this.  I played the first 2 RCTs and expansions whay back on thier release and i had such a good time with those ground breaking games.  They were easy to figure out and enough detail and options to keep the entertainment value and replay-ability alive to even this day for many still.  Its a tough job modernizing those yet keeping the same simplicity.  I will admit that even going through the tutorial on the first coaster build, I was slightly getting frustrated...but...it was my first time.  I know eventually it will get easier and if i dont feel like making one then i will just use an existing one...just like i did with the earlier games.I would recomend this to people who get into this type of game, and the ones who don't will just have to sit quietly and listen to me talk about it...because i had a good time playing it and i will put many-o-more hours into it. as far as early release bugs and glitches.....the only thing i noticed in the first couple hours of playing was that when i zoomed out a bit, some of the rides would spin incredibly fast...to the point it just looked crazy.  you can tell there still needs to be some fixes but its definately playable....and fun!one more note:  i would like to see and option for a simple path build.  maybe even a button that will straighten already built paths in accordance with a grid.  maybe highlight an area and snap all paths to make them straight.  maybe that is too hard to program...but would be nice.  Then again...maybe it is there and I didnt see it yet....guess i should get back to playing.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game for my wife. While it isn't quite everything I had hoped for in this long awaited installment, it is still playable and we look forward to the updates and changes to come. My wife finds herself losing track of real time while playing. She's not the biggest gamer, actually, not a gamer at all so if this game can capture her attentionand I know she looks forward tothe next time she has freetime to play then to me it was worth my purchase. I have watched her play and I myself think that while there is still plenty of room to improve, it does look nice and for the most part operates fairly smoothly. The ability to place buildings facing nearly any direction is a nice feature because in previous installments choosing one of four directions became relentlessly boring. That being said, it would be nice to have better graphics options. I realize this game is more for a common crowd with average machines than it is for the game enthusiasts but it would be great for the game to make use of the available resources on upscale machines.So, keep in mind, while this has been a long awaited installment in the franchise, this is still early access and there are going to be glitches and room for improvement. The only way to help shape the game the way you want it is to play, and provide feedback in the discussionboard for the developers.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Edit: 29 februaryNothing new. New screenshots etc have been released - but no dates on either Beta 2 or Release date... Im getting bored and tired.This game got be so awesome when its out. If its ever coming out... My hopes; Will be out before Planet Coaster, which is set to be released Q4 2016Ill go back to bed, cya.-----Edit: 11. january:So, we havnt heard a word since early december. Was promised two beta weekends, got one - and the other one got delayed - but as said: We havnt heard a WORD since the "happy holiday" where absolutly nothing was said.Hmmmmm...-----So I spend 2 hours playing the game tonight and here is my thoughts:I started with the plants, benches all that jazz. Built a nice path to start with, and start placing objects. The first thing that got on my nerves was, even though you promised a non-grid game, everything snaps to everything. The radius of snapping to path is HUGE. You cant even place fences along a curved path.Right, so we had to test the coaster physics. So after I played around with the tools to build it, I restarted and got seriously. I tried guys, I really tried! I got 1 coaster to work(!). That working coaster had one drop and then it ended. I tested it 4 times and 3 times it crashed while being dragged to the first drop.. I mean... It was a straight rail, and it just fell off.Now, the controls and the way the coaster builder works is just hard to figure out... What does the colors (black, white, red, yellow) means? It doesn't mean that, when its red, it cant go that way.. Because it can... sometimes.That being said - its a beautiful game with a lot of potential but I have to say this.. You won't make it to the release date, unless you're having a WAY different version than us. I really don't get how a bunch of developers can sit at a table and agree on: Guys! We release this beta so people can see how awesome it is..!I'm sorry for the negative thoughts - but this was really 2 hours of total frustration. Ill look into this, when we hit release, but for now- its not going to happen.I wish you the BEST of luck - and I hope this game will come out and BLOW us away... I love the franchise, please make it happen. Thank you.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								D I E  H A R D  F A N  H E R E.I have been waiting for RCTW to release and finally get my hands on. To be honest I had struggles if I should give the game ago- I have read negative reviews different platforms and I was worried it would be a disaster; now I have tried the game and I have the following honest feedbacks:I started the series since RCT1, enjoyed RCT2 and loved RCT3.I do honestly hoped that RTCW, 10 years after the release of RCT3 would have been sculpted and upgarded much and have noticed the followings:PEEPS.peeps look terrible in RCTW. I would zoom in RCT3 and just look at happy peeps buying balloons/popping their balloons etc but now I just want to zoom out because they look like zombies. In my opinion, they need more life.ROADS.honestly think its a nice touch for the shift/scroll to lower/elevate ramps, it was a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥to calculate how much angle the ramp for older version. I think this gesture worked. Nice touch for adjusting road widths/ but it is difficult to connect wide roads to attractions/facilities or back to a single sized road.COASTER BUILDER.ok. I have read lots of bad reviews for the coaster builder. After I tried it out myself, I think it is not as bad. The control might NOT be for beginners/new RCT players, but if you were an EXPERIENCED RCT player, I do think the mechanical tool option helped A LOT, esp. to add chained/brakes tracks in a clear manner. I think the tool box is quite neat to me, but I do understand it may cause beginners a lot of confusion.WORKERS. (JANITORS/TECHNICIANS)very nice touch. to just add a hub and let them manage themselves. I dont care if they slack tbh. I just dont care.RESTAURANTS.interesting blend of food and specialities restaurants- but I think the designs are a bit lazy for different themes, and I hope they could be attached to paths at a closer distance. (and i do secretly enjoy the fact that you can manage the amount of sauce/salt/edit the menu in RCT3)Shift+mouse scroll to rotate: i prefer a 90degress rotation in default than the default scroll-till-you-get-the-perfect-angle mode. saves my time. and some players (me) still prefer doing plannings on grid.Snap tool is a bit off - somtimes I misplaced benches outside the path and I dont like it.better to add a drop down menu- to filter themes. showing 4 burger shops in a row with different themes is not kool.TERRIN TOOLS.brilliant.ATTRACTIONS.I MISS THE SWAN BOATS AND METRO TRAINS TO TOUR AROUND PARK.STATISTICS.very clear way of presenting, loan is reasonable. SPECIAL LOTS.I appreciate the plaza blocks that are saved as pre-made blueprinted, saved me a lot of time and they are done beautifully.I MISS THE OPTION TO RE- PLACE ENTRANCE/EXITS. sometimes the location is just not right.CONCLUSION.I think. for 10 years, the game does not evolve as much as I expected it to be (thinking about from RCT2 to RCT3 guys.... the sudden leap from axonometric cubes to first person camera view on rides. thats innovation.) except from the fact that you can change the graphics settings to "very high level of detail" and "very far detailed shadow". This is not a rendering software, and high level of renders always make the game slow/crash. I would appreciate if more effort is put into details (design of rides) and new gameplay experience (like soak and wild for RCT3). It also remided me how great RCT3 is... especially at that time. I have a neutral feeling for this game, I remained nostalgic about the old days I spent managing my park, so YES I recommend for long-term RCT players, but maybe a NO for beginners.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								I personally (i know i am going to get hate for this) dont mind the game. Its okay... not great but okay. It does lag alot and there is alot of problems with it such as guests floating in mid air but overall, guys its an early access. Yes it should be alot further than this but hey, they havent got that far yet clearly. Ive played from Rct2 to this and i will admit it seems a bit of a step down with overall game performence. However, the new variation of rides is good.  I wouldnt say it is worth the money at the moment maybe $20 or so not $40.One thing i am dissapointed about however, is in the flags part of the scenery (dont remember which sub-category it is in) there is no australian flag. There is basically every other flag but Australia. I find this a bit offensive as i know alot of people who do play this series and have for  a long time. Why not put our flag in there to? Atari, how could you not put us in there with the others? I know we aernt huge like America or anything but still, it would be nice to see the Australian Flag at least.Everyone who is hating on it, get over it people. They aernt perfect. Yes, as i said previously there are ALOT of problems. But the new features like new coaster mechanisms (boosters, friction brakes) is cool. The main problem i have noticed is lag. It takes a fair bit of time to load a saved game or even start a new one and when in it, it tends to lag quite a bit to the point where guests float or you cant move around the map. The coaster builder is definetley a step up from previous versions. It is a bit confusing at first to use but after a couple of times you adjust. I will admit however, the variation of special coaster parts such a helixs and loops and twists is alot more limited in this game. Overall this game is OKAY. I would recommend it simply because it has potential. (in my opinion) It is still very buggy and laggy however.  If you have patience to wait and play through bugs and a bit of lag, buy it. If not, dont buy it. Simple.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Im loving every single minute of it, glad I bought it, only *issue* ive run into is when the park reaches 2,000+ peeps, the lag is unberable, and it crashes. Other than that I enjoy customizing the cars for the coasters or the colors of the paths or que lines. I enjoy the fact that the peeps have a mind of their own. Some dont like to ride certain rides, some only like roller coasters.The Coaster Builder. - Took me alot of time to get used to, forgetting to use shift to make it rise, or tilt. I enjoy the fact that some coasters can spin, reminded me of *Thrillville off the rails*.I enjoy the fact that the mascots seem to make everyone happy. I also enjoy that there are SO MANY differnt food buildings, theres like 4 different buildings just for tacos and salads!!!One thing that I really really enjoy is that I can ramp the paths, like, I made a little river, so I boosted the path up to go over the river, and I put a wooden rollercoaster track under and over it, so My peeps can enjoy a good coaster on the entrance of the park. The performance isnt 10/10, nor is the FPS, but it is playable....Im surprised my FPS lasted pretty good with the ammount of items and peeps in the park, there were around 1,800 peeps in the park and over hundreds of differnt pieces. 6 Roller coasters spread out all over. 60+ food buildings, 8 mechanic buildings with 10 mechanics for each building. 5 entertainer buildings, once again 10 entertainers for each building. 9 Janitor buildings, 10 janitors for each building. atleast 80 plants and trees, a lake, and over 10 thrill / family / and Junior rides..... Peeps arent to bad, yeah they walk through each other, but eventually theres so many peeps in your park you dont even notice it. Peeps - 8/10Id rate the game 8/10Path Placement - 7/10---------------------------------------------------------------------------------UPDATEDIve had enough with this game, the first part that got under my feathers was. I was at a halloween party in october of last year, got home got on youtube and saw this game. I thought OMG this game looks amazing, looks so awesome. Said the release was DEC 12th and that was right around the corner!!!!!! But then that Beta weekend came up, and I started watching gameplay videos and stuff and I mean almost every youtuber that had a gameplay video for this game were just HATING on this game.... Looked at the steam reviews (Atari should have never opend the reviews up for the beta testers to enter their reviews) it went downhill quick, there were a few good reviews "From kids that had hope". The rest were just negative nannys. Watching the gameplay for that beta weekend I knew immediatly that the game was just NOT ready for beta, and with release just around the corner I knew it was going downhill quick.Dec 12th came around and turns out they had to delay the release. I was saving my money for when the game Actaully came out so I could be sure. Months passed and we barley recieved any news at all. April came and they released the game into EA, I buy it and lord and behold, game was still very broken (Still is). OMG I tell you, I had so much hope for this game. SO MUCH. Every day id say (Give it some time and theyll eventually fix this game). Its almost been a complete year since the beta in October of last year and barley anything has changed. So, I hope you guys can eventually fix your game but youve lost a customer for now. Here I come PC.... Now im going to hit that refund button and get the $50 I should have spent on Planet Coaster

content:

Early Access Review
								The game is early access, people! EARLY. ACCESS. Of course there are bugs. Of course there are features missing. That's what early access means.Yes, load times are long. Yes, paths are buggy sometimes. Yes, there are some framerate issues. None of them are bad enough to make the game unplayable in my opinion. I've been having a ton of fun with it, and I'm very much looking forward to future updates. Take the time to enjoy the rollercoaster builder. Have fun with the campaign mode, building a park from nothing to giant. Go on the community section and visit other people's parks and ride their coasters! And, above all else, remember:EARLY. ♥♥♥♥ING. ACCESS.

When you think about this game coming out in a month you'd think this "beta" should be a teaser or a fairly polished beta. This game does not live up to it's former games and they constantly lie about the whole thing. I'm refunding this game unfortunately and waiting for planet coaster (same people who made rct3). This game was rushed and is no way shape or form ready for even a late alpha needs some more years. The camera control is terrible so don't expect to feel good at all. Also do not expect to ride your rides. You'd think with them working on this for a year they would read their forums and make sure you could ride your own rides as a majority of people have requested but no. This is basically a terrible version of no limits with the ability to make paths. I do not recommend this game at all. It's a huge disappointment and I wish they would take the rollercoaster tycoon franchise out of this as this game will absolutely ruin the name for previous games.

												Save Your Money*I completely understand it's a beta, but given how bad everything is so far there is no way it will be complete/playable by December 10th. Also, idk why my playtime hours are much smaller than they should be*After trying this beta I can easily say that the coaster builder is a total trainwreck. There are tons of graphics/performance issues (which are to be expected in a beta), but rides fail for no reason whatsoever (i.e. work in one section during a test and fail the next test even though the track was unchanged) and whenever a ride crashes the train remains on the ground and makes the area around it invalid to place track there from then on. They should really consider trashing the current control layout and go for something similar to Theme Park Studio's, which is simpler and much more precise/powerful. I had such high hopes for this game, but now I don't even care anymore and will be getting a refund. Way to let down a diehard RCT fan Atari...

content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ok so it has some bugs. But what game doesn't in the early stages. It is enpowering to see so many people are actually getting behind this game and generating content already and barely days after it's realise. Whatever the politics regarding this game and it's development thus far, do you know what, I honestly don't care. Do you know why? It is because I have played it for more than 2 hours, unlike those that slate the game. You would have to be blind if you thought the rival didn't have it's fair share of issues too. Infact uless you have a stupidly high spec computer then you will find that you won't be able to play that Alpha very well. Both games are in their early stages so expect problems. Expect content not to be there yet. Expect there is still lots of work to be done and expect both games to grow with support.  Some people like to use Macs others like to use PC's at the end of the day each to their own regarding who comes out on top. But it is early days for both hense the early release drr.RCTW has its menus all ready and waiting for content to be uploaded. The bare bones of the game is ready. The graphics are there and if you are creative or know a thing or two about design then every file and every component can be updated at a flick of the switch once the main game is stable.I get the impression from Atrai that there will be a lot more on it's way and they will be updating things as new things get added and the overlays for rendering are added. Something that is very difficult to do as I understand it if the main 3d forms aren't there and the coding is unsuccessful in the first place.As for the peeps they are at present a representation of the final render at this stage and not the final look because.....the game isn't finished. Once RCTW and it's rival sorts out it's crash issues and bugs then and omg then can you image the content that will come flooding our way.If you are passionate about gaming or creativity then not only watch this space but be constructive with your critism and post it on the forum so that developers can improve and keep improving the look and the content of the game.Oh and to those that have slated the game so where exactly is your theme park simulation game that you have been developing? Oh that's right you haven't been have you. So lets leave the game development to the experts. Atrai who have been making games for over 30 years and whose systems are the key component of every game you have probably played to date is based on from their invention back in the early 1970's.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								It has a few bugs, the paths are a pain and i wish i could  add sections of track in whichever order i liked so that i can build critical sections first and get them right. It also can be slow (gtx 980ti + AMD FX8120), especially while loading. But, it is an early access game, i don't expect it to be perfect yet. It is also a significant improvement from RTC 3 (although i wouldn't mind having the addons for that in this game). I wish they had built in the bug tracker into the game to make it easy to report problems. This game has allot of potential, not there yet, but well on its way.23/06/2016On a large campaign park it will take around 10 minutes to load. I think this is because it is trying to keep track of absolutely every peep in the park at once, so it bogs down. It would be better if people were enabled in waves on startup. you could reference against average FPS to ensure it doesn't drop too much. I am starting to run out of new things to build into the park, i think im going to have to repeat some of the rides. My biggest issue at the minute(besides the load time) has to be that most of the larger food stalls won't connect to paths at all, but there are plenty of others to use for now.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								PROS- Coaster Builder: It's always been so easy to create a roller coaster in RCT, and this coaster builder definitely adds a challenge and makes me want to get better at making them. It can get very complicated though, particularly when the supports of (most noticeably) the wooden coaster get in the way and you actually can no longer see what piece you're making. I also found that when you ride the coaster in first person  there's alot of little bumps and mini-twists in the track that I hadn't noticed before, making the roller coaster seem really unnatural.. this may, however, be down to my inexperience with the feature.- Variety: Not too bad, only about 8 types of roller coaster, such as Stand-up, Hyper, Wooden, Flying etc. I'm sure this list will grow however. Also a few flat rides which, again, will grow in time, but for now it's enough considering it's EA. - Realism: Everything ACTUALLY looks right and feels real, everything is bigger, MUCH bigger, with realistic, big roller coaster stations, buildings take up way more than one square on the grid.. everything is just BIGGER. The parking lot out the front, the entrance itself.. the scale is just massive and really feels like a real theme park.Music: Seemingly unimportant but I like it.CONS- Not as developed as I was hoping for: I honestly thought the game was WAY more developed than this.. it still feels like a skeleton. Know that I didn't play the beta though, this is a brand new experience of RCTW for me, so I can't compare it to that. I've been following the game since it's announcements but have nothing more to go on than screenshots and trailers. I was a bit gutted when I discovered the game was coming to EA.. Atari really do have no excuse for being this slow, I think they announced the game way too early that now it's annoyed people so much a lot of us WANT it to fail. I'm not one of these people, but I sense from other people's comments that they just want to see this game drow after putting so much hope (and a bit of money, too) into it! So yeah, this far down the line I expected much more meat on the bones.. but alas, it still feels very empty. (This may contradict my PRO for variety, but in that sense I understand the game is EA and will have little variety, despite the fact I wished it was further into development than this)- Paths: oh my god. Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god. Words cannot describe.. They're the most infuriating thing and I can't explain why.. They've been very lazy with the paths, they don't build right, they mess up all the time.. oh my god, just paths. Sort it, please.. There was nothing wrong with simple click and place in the previous games or, heck, ANY other simulator! The grid also needs revising, I think, nothing seems to fit nicely. - Visuals, ie menus and HUD: Wooowwww it's hideious. Like, actually hideous.. I don't know if they're going for a Sims 4 kind of minimalistic display in-game, which would look good.. but it just looks so random, maybe like they haven't really focused on that yet. The menus look cheap and Alpha-like.. think Cities:Skylines, just a grey, rounded text box with some words in. Put some effort in, Nvizzio! Get some sort of theme going with the menus, like the blue bubbles in RCT3! It just makes it look.. like a game!?- Buggy: Yes yes yes, it's EA I knoooww, but considering (again) how long this has supposedly been in development (I get the feeling they just go into the office every Sunday or something to do 2-3 hours worth of actual development on the game) it's a bit odd to se a mechanic floating around and attempt to inspect a ride whilst it's mid-flow, getting kicked in the face multiple times by the flying chairs.. silly. The game just crashed on me for no reason either, to be expected in EA I know, but this far down the line? Not sure.VERDICTI want to give this games a thumbs up, just to show them that there IS somebody still rooting for this game. My biggest worry is that all these (overwhelming amount!) negative reviews will make them think "Ah screw it, we're giving up. Nobody cares anymore, we're only going to be slated for everything.." and BOOM, there goes RCTW. I know this won't happen, I trust the developers are passionate about this game and want to make it better.. just please do it, listen to the fans and start righting your wrongs. We WANT to like this game, I want to LOVE this game.. and I will still hold on to the hope that one day, maybe soon, I will. RollerCoaster Tycoon World could be amazing.. just look back at what made the first three games so good, and do it better. I have faith in this game, and when it's at a stage that I can reccomend it to other people.. I most certainly will :)

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												OK, background first: I loved RCT2, played it tons and just wanted a newer up to date version on that. The beta is not this!There are 2 main issues that probably won't be resolved because I disagree fundamentally with what they have done.1. The Artwork resembles any bland MAC application with some grey boring icons and grey paths, grey coasters, low colour vibrancy where there is colour. It's like they looked at RCT2 and thought 'No, we dont like colours. We like grey and black and white. Borders? No, we don't like borders, we like MINIMAL feel'. End result: the game has no soul, no feeling of Theme Parks, you are like an engineer or town planner, NOT MR Eccentric Tycoon with a funny moustache and wacky clothing! And the game is called TYCOON, you would think the devs would know this, but apparently smart people can be stupid!!!!!2. The coaster building is slow and fiddly. There's a number of reasons for this, but it's never going to be fixed as there's no QUICK way to build coasters like in RCT2. You have to do tests and after waiting 3-4 mins for the carriages to get to the corner in question, only then do you find out if it works or not. Then you spend the next 5-10 mins trying to minimise the g-force (which is the usual issue), but you have no idea if you have done enough until you do a test! This feels like a 'Pro Mode', or Kerbal Space Program, with realistic physics, and no way for you to easily tell if your track is ok. And I'm no idiot, I built 3 coasters today and first one only took 15-20 mins, but it was just stupid the effort I had to put in!!No-one should fork over money for this if they liked RCT2. I loved that game, so the choice is yours. If you want a bland simulator then buy this game, if you want a game that is, you know, FUN, then play something else.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I'm not sure where some of the reviewers are seeing that this game is due out in 40 days or 'a little over a month'.  The release date is 12/29/2015 which is almost TWO months prior to realease (from 10/31/2015).  Apologies to the prior reviewers as I did not see the first release date of 12/10/2015.Is it ready?  No, but I think in TWO months it could be.  There are some definite issues in the current state.  Coaster building is very different from the prior RTC games.  I wouldn't say it's necessarily harder, just different.  It's just going to take some time to get used to it.  The camera / scrolling needs some work in that it isn't intuitive or user-friendly (for me).  I did not experience any lag.There isn't much else to review at this point.  All-in-all I think the game looks like it could be great.  I think it would have been nice to know what the developer's intent was with this beta weekend...to test a particular aspect of the game or just give us a small taste of what the game has to offer?While I'm in the minority for recommending the game, I do so with the caveat that we still have two months prior to release.  There is another beta weekend in December if I'm not mistaken and I feel that will be a better indicator of how we'll see the finished product.

								Honest Review-Game Release- Early AccessTime played  5-6 hoursI personally think it has potential. number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wanted to write a review on a variety of features of the game!  So far, I'm very much enjoying this with 18.5 hours played.ScenariosI like these.  It is fun to have a pre-built park and take on different challenges. I hope they add more to this or even allowing players to create their own scenarios that other people can play.  Campaign and Sandbox mode also available.Social HubEasy to use and get other player's or friends rollercoaster creations in my game.  Amazing how talented some are with their custom rollercoasters.GameplayWhen I first started I went right into the game.  There were a few things I was annoyed that I couldn't do well, like how shops or rides were placed.  Once I took the time to actually go through the tutorial, I solved most of the issues I was having.  Take the time to go through the tutorial, it will help you and you can open any of the various tutorials at anytime in the options.  Like I didn't have snapping on at first until I realized I needed to turn it on by pressing N once to set it on.Coaster BuildingI found it difficult at first and it definately can use some work still.  The more you use it, the better you will get.  I'm sure this will be a feature that is heavily worked on throughout early access.PeepsA nice diverse bunch of peeps are within the game.  They give plenty of info of what they like and don't like.  As well as a number of variables depending on what they are doing in your park, eating, etc.  I found peeps to be the most buggy aspect of the game and the developers will need to improve them.  They graphically glitch out often like on ride cameras or sliding around when walking.Graphics OptionsI saw a lot of reviews saying they were having issues and listing beasty specs.  I have an average PC and I had no problems, minus frame drops here and there.  The frame drops seem to increase with the more peeps in the park or possibly just the park getting larger.  The developers will need to optimize, but it is still playable.  Make sure to look into the graphics settings where there are a variety of options.  There is one where you can favor fps and some others depending on what you are looking for.DevelopersThey do seem to be taking feedback seriously and giving updates.  Let's hope they keep that up as it is vital to most early access projects.User InterfaceThe menus look fantastic!  Icons are easy to understand.  The second you get into the game,  you will understand what options are for what. Mouse MovementGood.  The zoom in and out with the mouse wheel is sensitive until you get use to it.  I'd like to see edge-scrolling available like on the Sims.  Maybe there was an option for it, but I don't think I saw it.KeybindingsYes!  They are available.  It sucks to get an early access title and those aren't available yet.  Luckily, they are here.PathsPaths are slightly tricky at first, but you will get better at them the more you play.  I think the developers can do some slight adjustments, but overall, the paths are decent.  The textures are attractive as well.Rides, Objects, Terrain, BuildingsThere is a good amount of rides, coasters, buildings, and objects available with a variety of themes (also consider Steam Workshop).  Coasters sometimes seem to freeze and stop running, but it usually corrects itself after a while.  The developers will want to look into that.  I was happy with the ride variety currently in the game.Overall Thoughts After 18 HoursThis is an enjoyable game and I wanted to keep playing it and growing my park.  There is tons of potential here to grow what is already a decent base for an early access title.  There is clearly some specific graphical bugs that can look silly and the developers will want to get on that as well as further optimization on a variety of features.I would recommend RollerCoaster Tycoon World and I'm rather surprised by the amount of very negative reviews.  Many with little time played.  Again, as I said above, I was a little annoyed at first when I started, but going through the tutorial solved many issues that I thought the game had.  The issue was that I though I could jump right in with no problems.  Take your time to learn how everything works and you will have fun!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been reading alot of the reviews already about the game and there seems to be a lot of hate and lack of understanding coming from some of the people who have played this game. Let's start with the obvious, It's early access. Yes there is things that work really well and things that don't. it's all part of the development process and I'm sure the devs will get onto improving these features over the next couple of weeks and months leading up to the V1 release. The gameplay for me so far has been relatively solid and no major problems that disrupt the game completely if anything it's mainly just minor superficial things so I'm going to list them out below. #1 Pavements: These are the most frustrating parts of the game to build as far as I'm concerned and as a person who likes to keep things looking smart and symetrical this has been a hinderance does present a problem placing buidlings next to each other. my recommendation to the developers, allow pavements to connect to each other at any point instead of somewhere randomly in the middle. #2 Bulldozer tool: I had to remove some trees and shrubbery in some areas to make space for rides, buildings etc. The bulldozer only lets you remove one object at a time with can be tedious when there is smaller things hidden behind trees. If there is possiblity for a bulldozer brush tool to remove large areas of clutter quickly that would be appreciated. Overall: I think RCTW is quite a good solid build for an early access and it has potential to to get even better, I implore anyone that is thinking about buying this game that you should consider the early access tag and please make notes of any bugs/defects or anything you think would improve the game and let the developers know so it can flourish as a sequel of the much loved series.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I feel like this game is going down a similar path to Diablo 3. The games and their developers have nothing to do with each other, but D3 received such a poor reception after it came out, and probably deserved it, but Blizzard fixed its problems. D3 is fantastic now.This game is early access, and people argue that it is NOT complete enough to even -be- in early access, but honestly I'd compare this to Ark's early stages. The game is bug-ridden, poorly optimized for performance, has unbalanced systems and an average amount of content. It's being actively developed though: they release patches regularly for issues and consistently add new stuff. They don't address all the bugs each patch, but it's a process. RCTW definitely has a chance. I'm willing to give it a 'Yes' now and see what fixes come out. I do believe that they can still change stuff like path building being wonky, having to remove every single little piece of foliage one by one to place stuff, and even some of the performance issues once they get proper feedback. TL;DR People are mercilessly slaughtering this game without giving it a chance, but I think it's worthwhile to keep an eye on.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Alright, I'm gonna try and be as concise as possible here...THIS GAME IS UNBELIEVABLE!! XD I LOVE IT!! Overall I felt it really stayed true to the RCT franchise while maintaining all the fun and possibilities and amazing new content I'd expect from it!Now to battle the bad reviews....Guys, give this game TIME! Have you ever tried developing a game?!? I've only been just starting to teach myself 3-D modeling and it's so challenging! These guys have AMAZING graphics for what it is, and, they keep improving it!! It's in EARLY ACCESS for StarClan's sake!! (For those who get that reference, kudos to you, you're a new best friend! xD :3 )They'll be constantly releasing bug fix updates, new content updates, and graphical/performance improvements as it goes through this rigorous playtesting, so PLEASE just be PATIENT! It's a virtue right? :)Plus, I tried this game from the very instant my friend bought me a code as a gift, I was so hyped! And to be honest, the beta version prior to this early access version was a bit frustrating. Way too many bugs and issues with that (Flying coaster cars ftw!!). It also took up a ridiculous amount of my RAM and CPU power on my gaming rig for a playable game (Nearly 100% in both).Since that update, these guys have brought LIFE to the game! Literally with peeps, flat rides, scenery, theming, shops, stalls, staff, scenarios, objectives, user-generated content, and MASSIVE performance upgrades. (It now only takes up about 50% of my RAM and less than 40% of my CPU)Sure there's the ocassional thing that bothers me, but I can already spend HOURS upon HOURS desigining the park of my dreams! That's the overall point isn't it?!?Do I reccomend this game?HECK YEEEEAAAAAAAAHHHH!!! (Shouts/screams as he rides over the first drop of a wooden coaster he built)

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												As a huge fan of the RCT series, I am extremely disappointed in the first beta. The interface for building a coaster is extremely confusing and not straightforward in the slightest. There's no simple way to build a loop, delete a piece of track, or edit a piece that you've already created. It's almost impossible to build a coaster in a straight line, even with the grid tool. I was only able to 'ride' my coasters once and there was a weird box around the train that interfered with the line of sight. On top of that, the game is just buggy and runs really slow. At this point, RCT3 stands as a better game. I honestly regret pre-ordering this considering the state it is in right now, and I highly doubt this game will be playable by its release date.

								I have to say after all the bashing this game has received prior to early release i was wondering if my £14.99 was going ot be wasted, having played for a few hours and got a feel for the game i have to be honest its not all bad, in it current state its hard to give a full and final report but to say there is a bit of work to do yet is not stretching the truth.So far i have seen the cleaning staff walking the park cleaning without actually moving there legs, lots of peeps bounching and jittering but i guess those kinds of things will be fixed.  Sound seems to travel a lot from quite a distance away i could clearly hear the wooden roller coaster climbing a hill which should not be possible.I would like to see mouse edge scrolling as well in the final game it seems to be missing from this version.Yes the graphics are a bit roapy but not rubbish by an stretch of the imagination.  In general if like me you paid half price you wont feel quite so naffed of its not the best game in the world, had i paid full price maybe it would have been a different story. content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay, here's the deal. Every aspect of the game needs work. However, that being said, there are some very promissing aspects of this game. For example, the coaster building mechanics are top-notch. It combines the ease of piece-by-piece with the fine detained spline based editing to easily create specific track. However, you cannot "delete" a part of the track, only mess around with the nodes, which makes sense. Also, because it's so "realistic," you have to create realistic tracks, or it's not going to work. In the previous RTC games, you could slap together parts all willy-nilly and as long as it was a completed circut and didn't stall anywhere, it was "rideable." Not the case in this game, but I think it really makes you consider aspects you normally would not, so at the end of the day, you're more proud of what you've done. So good coaster building mechanics, but implementation still needs work.Another example is the staff, I don't have much to say other than I'm not a fan of the "huts-that-take-up-space-and-provide-little-help-and-organization" way of doing it. I think parkitect has an amazing system where you just had break rooms placed about that increaded productivity.The path placing and using is really the worst part. It's the only thing I absolutly hate about this game. It's extremely tempermental and I am always fighting it, sometimes to the point of tears. It's very annoying. (Pro tip: the large paths are the worst offenders, so just don't.) Also, because of the sudo-grid system, it's much more time consuming to place benches, trash cans, and lights. In RCT 1,2, and 3, I just went "lamp, bench, trash, repeat." With one per square, it was quick and painless and provided a system that met and exceded the requirements for the needs. Now, you have to pay super attention to place it exactly, and because paths don't like being even and symmetrical, it never looks good. And that's if it lets you place it! Yeah, it's really only a problem if you have OCD, but lets be real, that was one of the good things about RCT 2. I would like to see a mod or something that uses a more rigid grid. Also, while I'm on the topic of OCD, the grid that follows your mouse around (really nice, actually) has different weighted lines to mark large squares, which is normal. Well, the center line of the park DOES NOT MATCH UP WITH THE CENTER OF THE ENTRANCE!!! HOW?! WHY?! WHO?! And you can't extend the first bit of path and keep it striaght! IT BOTHERS ME SO MUCH!Anyway, I can go on, but I think I'll leave it at this: It's very promising, and I'm really excited for a polished version. I'm going to recommend this game not because of it's current state, but because of it's potential. All of the bad reviews bring up fixable problems, and over time I'm sure they will get fixed and the final result will be a great game.

In RCT 1,2, and 3, I just went "lamp, bench, trash, repeat." With one per square, it was quick and painless and provided a system that met and exceded the requirements for the needs. Now, you have to pay super attention to place it exactly, and because paths don't like being even and symmetrical, it never looks good. And that's if it lets you place it! Yeah, it's really only a problem if you have OCD, but lets be real, that was one of the good things about RCT 2. I would like to see a mod or something that uses a more rigid grid. Also, while I'm on the topic of OCD, the grid that follows your mouse around (really nice, actually) has different weighted lines to mark large squares, which is normal. Well, the center line of the park DOES NOT MATCH UP WITH THE CENTER OF THE ENTRANCE!!! HOW?! WHY?! WHO?! And you can't extend the first bit of path and keep it striaght! IT BOTHERS ME SO MUCH!Anyway, I can go on, but I think I'll leave it at this: It's very promising, and I'm really excited for a polished version. I'm going to recommend this game not because of it's current state, but because of it's potential. All of the bad reviews bring up fixable problems, and over time I'm sure they will get fixed and the final result will be a great game.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I would have to say I was a bit nervous purchasing this game. Seeing as basically every review is a thumbs down, spending $50 was a large "gulp" in my throat. However, I am very happy with this purchase and I'll tell you why.I've been playing RCT all my life. Still to this day, I play RCT1, and make my wonderful parks. I probably got the game in a cereal box, I can't remember; but it's incredible. I also own RCT2 and RCT3, and being a huge fan of the franchicise in general, I bit the $50 and went with this game.The first complain I see from a lot of people is about lag. Either those claims are overdramatized, or some of the later updates have fixed the issues. Don't get me wrong, it IS a graphically intense game. Running medium settings with an R9 390 (I also have an I5-4460) gives me less than 30FPS. I still have yet to try low settings, but my point is that this game is completely playable for any modern day system with a medium to high end graphics card. If you have a cheaper GPU, you might want to upgrade for a more playable experience.We don't expect a game like RCT to be this way, but we have to realize that it is worth it in the end. Yes, RCT1 and RCT2 were programmed on a 1995 engine so efficiently than the weakest systems back in the day could run them at ease. RCT3 also was not bad, I ran that thing on an integrated GPU in a laptop. But RCT World is different. The graphics, for one thing, are better, so this is why it is more intense. Will there be future optimizations? Of course there will. Plus, Atari will probably add DirectX12 support, which should ease the game's frame rates and enhance graphical quality even more.A major plus of this game is the 1.2GB download size. I'm tired of 50GB games, this is a very nice download size. Once you are in the game and get the hang of stuff, you start to realize how much potential it has. The coaster editor is very nice. It may be more difficult to use than the old RCT games, but that's because it has so many more capabilities. The curved paths are another nice feature.If I had a complaint, it would be that there needs to be more and more scenary and rides! The more the merrier. But the truth is we all know this stuff IS coming. Atari will keep adding more content. Another pro is the peeps look really nice, good graphical detail to them for there being hundreds in the park. Also, did I mention there are recycle bins now? And you can place bins either on the path or off to the side. You'll notice nice little features like that. With some touchups, this game will be rocking and rolling!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Bearing in mind this is Early Access I do find the current state to be playable.  There are still many bugs to be worked out.  My hopes are the developers will address issues reported by players and longtime fans.  I don't have a huge complaint on graphics as I expected the cartoonish style of art.  However, the details and movement of the people are bleak.Some things to think about:Poor optimization.Road system isn’t always ideal.  IE: Doesn’t align or connect to grid."Snapping" isn’t very intuitive and poorly aligns.People are poorly animated.Not a lot of content but there is a built in social share system, although it was empty for me.Lack of in depth management tools (staff management, etc.)Poor optimization. (Yes, I said it twice)Deleting can be a pain.  Would be nice to see a drag and delete feature. The concern is that it was previously said to be near finished.  I truly hope that was said in error and that development is still moving forward and we can expect to see updates and patches.Unlike some others I find the Rc builder to be quite nice and challenging for a game that offers little challenge at first to even a novice as plopping down a few ready-made rides will easily get you by money wise.  4-5 out of 10 for me.  Disappointed but hopeful will be my mindset on this.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								RollerCoaster Tycoon World in it's current state is a difficult game to review because while the game has so much potential, it is marred by technical issues, and lack of content. When you see that this game is an Early Access title, they mean it. The game is very much unpolished, buggy, and lacks content. Atari still has a lot of work ahead of it to fix all of the bugs, add content, and optimise the game. Otherwise, the game has a ton of potential; the coaster builder, once you get used to it, is incredibly intuitive and customizable. It's a lot of fun to build a rollercoaster and test it. Operating your own amusement park is also fun, interesting and challenging.Overall, I give RollerCoaster Tycoon World a qualified recommendation; if you can ignore the current issues right now in the Early Access, buy it. But if you want a more polished game, look elsewhere or wait.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 12
												It is time to write a new review.  You ask should I get RCTW or Planet Coaster.  Planet Coaster is, I am persuaded, an awesome game (and I would love to try it), but you should know it requires a more robust machine than I have to run it.  I contacted the Team at Planet Coaster enquiring whether my machine would run their game.  This was the gracious reply I received,  "After reviewing your DxDiag report, I regret to inform you that you are quite significantly under our minimum specifications for the game. As such, I would not recommend purchasing the game if you intend to run it on your current computer".That said, RCTW runs wonderfully on my machine.  The only issue that I find a bit annoying is that after the Unity upgrade my PxP building tiles flash different colors detracting from the park's beauty.  At this writing, I have not tried the Valentine's update.  RCTW is in many ways as good as, and in many ways better than RCT3.  It does not possess all the content or capabilities as RCT3, but the developers are still updating this wonderful game.  Even if your machine will run Planet Coaster well, you still can enjoy this game.Do I recommend RCTW?  Yes, a thousand times yes!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												It's just plain not working yet. This is a review from the october beta. Issues:-No sound or graphics options, which should be in any build of the game. -If your coaster doesn't work, may as well just delete it.  -When you delete a part of the path it auto fills in between the two places, making it imposible to make mid coaster edits.  -The coasters fly off the curve way to easily, and there is no way to adjust the bank of a curve after you've moved past that part-The physics need some work. There is no sense of gravity on the cars when they fly off-There is no way to pan the camera on the mouse-There is no real way to control the angle of the drop-There is no real way to control the angle of the turn-The graphics are in desparate need of AA.-Once you make supports dissapear, you can't get them back-The camera messes up where your mouse is poiting when you are building the coaster.That said, I still have hope for this game. The devs really do seem like they care about the game, even if they have to work for the wonderful publishers of games like "Alone in the Dark Illumination" and "Haunted House: Cryptic Graves." Some things that lead me to have hope are:-They are planning to update the game a lot after launch-The overall engine seems like it is a decent base for the game-The park management and modding tools they have described are promising-Atari doesn't seem to be pushing them to add microtransactions-The devs seem to want to make a good game.-They said that the old way of making coasters will also be in the game (I'm pretty sure I heard this, but I don't remember where). When combined with the current coaster editor this should help the game a lotSource: 


YouTube™ Video: RollerCoaster Tycoon World @ PAX Prime - Alienware Livestream 

			Views: 47,022		

			ESRB RATING: Everyone with Crude Humor Matt and Andy from team RollerCoaster Tycoon World sit down with Alienware at PAX Prime for an in-depth look at RCTW. Coming soon for PC!		

Conclusion:For now, stay away. I will be returning my copy. Wait to see how the game turns out, and if the devs are providing consistent and meaningful updates. If they get the game to a decent current state and are showing care to the game, I will purchace. Until then I'll be playing RCT3 and RCT 2. (screw RCT 3D and RCT 4 mobile :<)EDIT: Removed the part about the game launching in early access. I know this was stated at some piont, but I don't remember when. Thanks for pointing that out to me, Mr. Nekk.
